Ottawa, January 7, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, with reference to improvements at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I am returning your file, and I am today writing to Mr. Inspector Bunn, authorizing him to purchase the metallic ceiling, the tables and benches and the mower and rake. Please let Mr. Bunn have access to your files showing the prices you have received, as this will help him in awarding the business.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Bentgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
39-43, The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Ottawa, January 7, 1929.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has decided to ship in some materials to the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School before the winter freighting is ended. Dr. Westgate has secured prices, and he has been requested to let you have access to his file, which will help you in awarding the business to the best advantage. You may purchase the metallic ceiling required for the dining room, at a cost of $96.09 F.O.B. Prince Albert. You may also purchase a 3½' mower and a 9' rake. This business should be awarded to either the Cockshutt Plow Company, Winnipeg, who have already quoted to Dr. Westgate, or to the Saskatoon office of the Massey-Harris Company, who are going to quote. You, of course, will select the lowest quotation.

You may also arrange with either the Cusson Lumber Company, St. Boniface, or Cushing Bros., Saskatoon, both of whom have been asked to quote, for the supplying of 12 dining room tables and 24 benches. The dining room tables should be 5' x 6', with brown battleship linoleum tops, properly bound with brass. Cushing Bros. of Saskatoon have not yet quoted to Dr. Westgate. The Cusson Lumber Company of St. Boniface have quoted, but have substituted oilcloth for the linoleum. Have them amend their quotation so as to conform to the specifications, i.e., battleship linoleum, bound with brass.

Your obedient servant,

J. R. Bunn, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Commercial Bldg.,
St. Boniface St.,
Winnipeg, Man.

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, January 29, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

There has been considerable correspondence concerning the need for an infirmary so that the pupils of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School could be isolated when such action was necessary. In your letter of the 9th instant, you ask the Department to reimburse your Society for food supplies for patients. This suggests that Indians, other than pupils, are being given hospital treatment by the nurse. The Department wishes to know what building is being used. Further, if the practice of taking in out-patients were discontinued, would there be sufficient room for the proper care of pupils who are sick?

Your Society has lately indicated that a hospital is required for the Indians of this community. As it may be some time before the Department can give consideration to this proposal, which involves a large appropriation, I am writing to ascertain the exact situation, so that a decision can be reached regarding the infirmary accommodation for pupils of the school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

I enclose herewith a duly certified bill for $50.00 incurred in connection with the water system at our Lac la Ronge School. On Jan. 26th, the Rev. C. F. Hives, Principal of this institution, sent a telegram stating that the water in the well had given out and that he feared it would be necessary to connect the pumping system with the lake. He estimated the expenditure involved would be $70.00, and in view of the urgency of the situation, our Commission authorized him to proceed immediately.

In the covering letter which accompanied the enclosed account he writes, in part, as follows:

"I may say that our well gave out right in the very severe weather. We were unable to supply the building adequately, and the situation looked very serious. My first thought was to extend the pipe into the lake, and I estimated the cost at about seventy five dollars. Hence the wire to you. Then I thought that if it could be managed, the further sinking of the well would be the more permanent. The only thing against that was the very severe weather. But I got the men, and opened up the well. We made a crib, and sank the well until I was quite sure that we had an adequate supply. I was in the bottom of the well for two days. I am very pleased to say that we are now able to put on full pressure three times a day if need be, and I believe there will be water for all time to come."
In view of the prompt and energetic measures taken by the School Management and the success which attended the same, I trust that my request for the payment of this account may have your favourable consideration, and that a cheque for the amount in question will be issued in favour of the Hudson's Bay Company, Lac la Ronge, via Prince Albert, Sask.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
With Cheque

Ottawa, March 5th., 1929.

Rev. Sir,

The Department has received through the Rev. Mr. Westgate, Field Secretary, H.S.C.C., an account in favour of the Hudson's Bay Company amounting to $50.00 for expenses incurred in connection with the water system at the Lac la Ronge School. I herewith enclose Department's cheque in payment of this account, but as it is not satisfactory for the Audit Office, I would request you to obtain from Sanderson Bros. a statement in duplicate showing in detail how this amount is made up. The statement should be certified by you and sent to the Department with the least possible delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

AGENT'S REPORT

Respecting the Iac la Ronge Indian Residential School
For the month of July 1929

ROUTINE

At the time of my visit there were:
- 101 pupils in the classrooms.
- Are the classroom registers kept up to date? Yes.
- Pupils in vocational training departments.
- 1 pupil sick.
- Pupils absent. Reasons: The June return shows average of 103 but some of the pupils are not carried over into July—discharges, deaths etc.
- Total number on roll: 102.

Are there any pupils in residence whose admission has not been approved by the Department?
One pupil is being kept for a time as his parents are away from the reserve, he is not on the roll, being just a visitor.

HEALTH, SANITATION, Etc.

Appearance of pupils: Neat and healthy.
Cleanliness of school: Very clean. It can be seen that the school is always clean; it is not just tidied up for my visit.
Appearance of school grounds: Grounds are clean, no refuse around the place anywhere.
Care of the sick: The nurse attends to them but has no accommodation of any sort for sick children.
The meals at present are cereals, bread, peas, puddings, with fish as main food.
These are in good shape.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING

Domestic Instruction: Making and mending clothes, Laundry and kitchen work, Basket and weaving.
Instruction in Farming and Gardening: Very slight as no land for the purpose except small garden. The hay is cut 20 miles off.
Training in the care of live stock: Just a few animals, no chance to keep many number as no feed available.
Hauling wood, Fishing, Gardening, Swimming.
Care of agricultural machinery and other equipment: What is here is kept neatly.

GENERAL

Discipline at the school: This is of the best. At same time the pupils are friendly and happy looking.
Efficiency of the staff: This appears to be all right but two teachers are being let out for some reason other than their teaching.
General management: The Principal here cannot be improved on, he is of the best type; a good all-round man.
Suggestions: Letter attached.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to enclose the report on Lac la Ronge Residential School. The children in the class rooms were all examined on the 10th. The class rooms were clean, well ventilated and the teaching was efficient. The senior teacher especially has brought her pupils along in good style; I am sorry that she is leaving. I put in the whole day in the rooms and can state that the work in every class is satisfactory. The pupils are only up to the sixth standard but if they get this far and understand the work it is enough for this district.

The hospital applied for here seems to have been refused. Some accommodation should be put up for sick pupils. The Principal recommends the following, and I think he is now agreeable to it in lieu of a special building. Put up a two story room at end of each wing, there is room between the windows etc for a place 16 X 20. One extension would contain nurse room below, ward above; the other a dispensary below and ward above. Mr. Hives says he would get it completed for $4000.00, furniture extra.

OVER...........
Six dozen hospital bed mattresses are required here, it is of no use to send mattresses unfilled, cases etc., as no material is available locally to fill them.

One hundred blankets are required here from some source.

Eighty-four (84) rubber stair treads 7x17½ with same number brass nosings 18" are required for stairways.

Twenty (20) bushels lime required for plaster repairs.

Three thousand (3000) feet B.M. fir flooring is required for classrooms and playrooms. The present flooring is worn out and is very dusty on account of open places in between old boards.

I asked for church pews or seats for the pupils last year, they were not supplied. They are still needed.

Practically all other items asked for were supplied.

The school is in good repair generally.

The Principal tells me he has asked for an appropriation for supplying food to sick Indians. He sends the cooked food to them when they are bed ridden on the reserve close by. This is not really a school matter but I thought I would mention it. He does supply this service and it is quite a drain on the school finances.

I beg to say that your letter of July 15th, received today was very greatly appreciated, as also your letter of July 24th, also received today. I assure you that the thousand dollars you have kindly granted for clearing will be of great assistance for that purpose, but more so will it be so greatly appreciated by the Indians who are in very poor circumstances, and need the money which they will get for work executed.

The $2000.00 for the purpose of providing accommodation for sick pupils should help us in that respect, and I assure you that it will be used to the best advantage. We are also thankful for the fir flooring, stair treads, and I do sincerely hope that you may see fit to provide the mattresses. I may say in this respect that we have not anything in the way of filling for mattresses in this country. We have no grain field nearer than one hundred and fifty miles away.

May I say a word in regard to the request for blankets. When our pupils are sent away on their vacation they are given a quilt each. I find that this is really a necessity. The parents of these children are poor. They have nothing but just what they actually need themselves, so that when an extra child comes into the home, unless it brings along with it what it will require in the way of bedding, that child has to either go without and suffer discomforts or even worse, or share with someone else. We have always tried to provide one quilt each for our pupils when they go on their holidays, and when they leave school after graduating, we give them two. I may say that there is also another side to this matter beside guarding the child against discomforts etc. Many of our pupils are growing girls verging on to young womanhood. If such a girl has not anything in the
way of bedding you may realize how dependant she is upon other resources. I have known of a great deal in the way of immorality amongst our young Indians, and have traced its origin in a number of cases to the fact that the poor girl had no bedding. Our Indian girls and boys are very anxious to keep straight. Just as anxious as we are to help them, and no matter what the cause may be that would bring about the downfall of a girl's character, I feel we should guard against it.

After a child has been home for six weeks, I mean for his vacation, the quilt is almost useless. This is easily accounted for when one considers the roaming life they lead, and the poor accommodation they have. Last year we gave out a quilt to each child, and out of the hundred or more given out there were not more than half a dozen fit to be taken in again.

This depletes our supply of bedding until the situation is becoming serious. For that reason I asked Mr Indian Agent Waddy if anything could be done to help us out.

If after reading this and appreciating the need we have for extra blankets, the Department can see fit to provide us with what Mr Indian Agent Waddy asked for, I assure you that we shall be very greatly assisted in our work with our Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. F. Prince
Principal.

Reverend Sir:

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of April 23rd last, re the unexpended balance, etc., of the grant made by your Department last year for an infirmary at our Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, I beg to state that immediately after receiving your letter I wrote to the Rev. C. W. Fisher, principal of this school, and asked him to take in hand at once the work of completing the infirmary, so far as the unexpended balance of the grant would meet the same.

It would appear from information received from the Principal that the unexpended balance amounted to $458.00. He immediately placed an order for the items given on the enclosed statement from the T. Eaton Co., and which amounts to $198.46, including the commission on his cheque which accompanied the order. This would leave a further balance of $254.54. As the freight has to be paid on the shipment all the way through from Winnipeg to Lac la Ronge, it is probable that the greater part of this amount will be required to meet the same. The weight according to the enclosed bill of lading is 1,925 lbs., and the summer freight rate from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge is 7½¢ per lb. This charge, along with charges for handling in Prince Albert and the freight from Winnipeg to Prince Albert, will probably consume the greater part, if not the whole, of the balance mentioned. A further statement will be submitted to you when the goods have been delivered and the freighting and handling charges met. I have thought it well, however, to forward to you the enclosed bills which I have certified, in order to avoid the delay which would be involved if they were returned to the Principal for his certification.
Trusting this may meet with your approval,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Re Lac La Ronge School

In visiting this School I found that they have 118 children on the roll, and that the average daily attendance for the quarter just ended is 106 3/10.

The pupils are apparently doing very well under very capable teaching and management. I find that there is considerable repair work required for this School in a small way, also some interior equipment.

Dear Sir:

Re: Improvements Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

With further reference to your letter of October 8th, #132-2-5, and my reply to the same on October 14th., relative to certain improvements at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School advised by the treaty paying officer, I beg to state that I have just received from Mr. Fisher, Principal of the Lac la Ronge School, a letter dated October 13th. in which he furnishes me with much of the information requested with regard to the improvements in question. The information is not complete as he wrote his letter before he received the one I had addressed to him, but in view of the urgency of some of the requirements, I thought it well to forward to you at once the following extract from his letter:

"You will note that I am asking for a 300 gallon hot water tank. I feel this is very necessary, for at the present time all the hot water for the children's bath has to be heated on the laundry stoves, and carried up in pails. This not only entails a great deal of work, but I feel sure that the amount of water used is not sufficient, when one considers the number of children we have in the school. I have no means of ascertaining just what this tank will cost to instal. I would judge however, that including the necessary pipes and fittings, together with the freight, it would amount to $350 to $400. I do hope the Department will give us this.

"With regard to our kitchen range, it was felt that by inserting new fire brick (or linings to the fire boxes) this would do for quite a time. But I am sorry to say..."
the range is getting worse all the time. Mr. Hastings did put in a temporary lining of asbestos pulp, but this has already burned out again. I would like to suggest that the Indian Dept. be asked to supply a new range. Here again, I have no way of finding the cost.

"I have also had many complaints regarding the bread oven, and from personal observation, I would say that the bread does not appear to be all that it should be. I am informed that this is due to the oven. The doors are warped and much of the necessary heat escapes. Will you kindly ask for a new one. The present oven is certainly very far from satisfactory.

"We are also badly in need of a refrigerator. Would the Department supply this? The one listed on page 392 of Eaton's Spring and Summer catalogue, No. 424*M-230 would do very well. Its cost is $32.00.

"Attached to your letter dated April 26th, there is a copy of a letter from the Dept. in which it states that $500.00 was granted for building of an ice-house, and $800 for general repairs. Am I at liberty to prepare to use this money for the purposes mentioned. We are certainly in need of a new Ice-house, and with your permission, I think I could manage to do something towards it this fall. This letter is going out on the last plane to leave here this year. We expect the last mail by open water tomorrow, so if I am to do anything in this matter, it will be necessary for you to wire your instructions.

"During the past summer, I laid new floors in the two play-rooms, and in the junior class-room. This means that we have perfectly good floors in all the rooms downstairs except the Senior class-room. I would like to put a new floor there next summer. I would be glad to have you purchase 800 ft. of fir flooring. This could be sent in either in December or with the main freight in March.

"There has not been time since receiving your letter regarding the hospital to go fully into the matter. I will write you fully in the regular mail. I would like to suggest however that you ask an architect to draw up plans and specifications. (1) For a one storey building containing two wards, a nurse's room; dispensary; two bathrooms (one attached to nurse's room) with a full basement, heated by
"a small wood burning furnace, or (2) for a two storey building containing the same number of rooms, the nurse's room to be upstairs, and the dispensary downstairs. Of course a small kitchen would be necessary. I feel sure that we could manage to put up the building.

"I should have said that after consulting Nurse Patrick, it is thought that two four bed wards will be ample for our needs here.

"While I have no doubt that I could draw up a plan for the building, I feel very strongly that it might be cheaper in the end if a qualified architect were asked to plan the building. It would be easy for him to estimate costs on materials which would have to be shipped in."

In addition to the above the Principal has furnished me with a copy of the list of requirements which he sent to Mr. Walter Locke of Prince Albert who acted as treaty agent. As this list specifies in detail the requirements taken by the treaty paying officer, I am enclosing a copy of the same for your information, and trust that an authorization may be received to provide the same.

I note that a kitchen range and a new bake oven are not included in this list, but after reading the Principal's letter I feel sure that both are required. With regard to the bake oven my recollection is that it was sent first to our Elkhorn School but being unsuitable for that institution, it was sent to the Lac la Ronge School. I am unable at present owing to lack of time to confirm my recollection in this matter, but in view of the danger which arises from the use of a defective range, I beg to recommend that the Principal's request for a new one be given sympathetic consideration.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

MR. WILLIAMS:

For several years the Missionary Society of the Church of England has been urging the Department to build an infirmary or small hospital at Lac La Ronge. During the fiscal year 1929-1930 an amount of $2,000.00 was provided for this purpose and it was understood that it was to be expended on a small addition to the school building for hospital purposes. The building was not completed and the money was not re-voted in 1930-1931. Arrangements were made, however, to use part of the money provided for general repairs at the school to complete this work during the present year. Some material was bought and forwarded to Prince Albert, where it now lies waiting for winter freighting.

In September Dr. Westgate was here and said that as there were other matters more urgent at the school, and as the season was too late in any case, it was not proposed to complete the infirmary this year. Up to this point the matter has been in charge of the Schools Branch, and it was school funds which were to be used.

Dr. Westgate has now got a new report from the principal of the school, and we are asked to provide funds and to make a plan for the erection of a small hospital. Mr. Ferrier takes the apparently reasonable view that the greater part of the work to be done is not school work and should not be carried out under the auspices of his Branch.
The present situation is that we have a nurse at Lac La Ronge, who lives at the school but who gives attendance to all the people in the district. The work done under the original scheme does not seem to have gone beyond the getting out of some legs. There is some material at Prince Albert waiting to go in. No funds have been requested in the main estimates. I should say that it would take at least $10,000.00 to erect any sort of suitable building at Lac La Ronge.

I have just received a letter from Inspector W. Morrison, from Lac la Ronge, and append an excerpt in regard to the Residential School there, Mr. Morrison writes in part as follows:

I would like to draw your attention to two things which should be arranged for before the cold weather arrives.

The school is heated with three hot air furnaces and the firebox in one of these is so badly burnt out as to be unsafe to start a fire in. Dear Sir:

During the latter part of July and the beginning of August, I visited our Society's Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge, Sask., and reported the following requirements to our Commission:

(1) New batteries, 48 Exide, and new switch board for the lighting plant,
(2) New bread oven,
(3) Metal lining and flooring for the store-room,
(4) Lumber lining for the grain and feed room,
(5) One enamel bath and two toilet bowls with fittings complete,
(6) Wire netting for the upper verandah of the main school building, and also for the verandah at the Principal's residence,
(7) 4 dog bedsteads and 2 dozen mattresses,
(8) 3" valve for Globe washing machine, No. of valve 1215½ for machine M7185
(9) 1000 shingles for repairs to roofs,
(10) Increase in the school land from 75 acres, this being the amount attached to the school at present, to at least 640 acres,
(11) Clearing of more land, say 25 acres so that hay and green feed may be grown for the stock,
(12) A supply of creosote or paint for roofs, paint and asbestos for outer and inner walls of buildings, especially the main school building.

As I was informed by the Principal that Mr. Inspector Murison, who accompanied the Treaty party this year, had given careful consideration to most of the above requirements, and undertook to recommend to your Department...
that they be supplied, I do not consider it necessary to do more than to state that when I reported these requirements to our Commission, I was instructed to forward the list to you and ask you to kindly endeavour to provide the same.

The storage batteries and switch board should be sent in as soon as the winter trail opens next December. These items should have priority of claim over all the others. The other items are arranged in the order of the urgency of their requirement.

With regard to the clearing of more land, our Commission instructed me to make known to your Department the serious problem they have to face from year to year in securing an adequate supply of hay for the stock. The school management now go from island to island in the lake cutting a little here and there, whenever it is to be found. They are experimenting with oats on a small piece of ground, and from results obtained, feel confident that the hay and green feed problem can be solved if more land is cleared. Your Department made a grant for this purpose a few years ago, and the money was well spent in clearing about five acres of land near the main school building. A great many stones, however, will have to be removed before this area can be seeded to advantage. The bush fire of 1927 which destroyed the forest around the school and endangered the school buildings at the same time, revealed considerably land about a mile or two behind the school, which could be brought under cultivation if properly cleared of stumps and shrubbery, and as this would afford employment for the Indians in the settlement, our Commission strongly recommend that not less than 25 acres be cleared as soon as possible. As this area does not at present lie within the boundaries of the school property, our Commission feel that steps should be taken to have the school land increased sufficiently to enclose it, and they trust that your Department may be able to help them in the way indicated.

During my visit, which is the third I have made to this school, I received the impression, based on very careful observation, that this is a work fully worthy of your Department and of our Society, which is being accomplished
at this remote centre, and it would be an encouragement to the school management if arrangements can be made to supply the essentials required to expand and consolidate this work.

Trusting that all the items listed may receive your sympathetic consideration, and some means found to provide the same when the winter trail opens next December.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

LAC LA RONDE CHURCH OF ENGLAND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

I visited this school on July the 10th. It is nicely situated, facing the lake. It is under the auspices of the Church of England, with the Reverend G. W. Fisher as Principal.

The male members of the staff include an engineer, farmer and fisherman. The female members comprise a Matron, Miss E. V. Williams, two teachers, a Girls' Supervisor, Boys' Supervisor, Laundress, Kitchen Matron and a Graduate Nurse.

I spent four
I spent four days at this school, and was greatly pleased with the general atmosphere. The staff impressed me as being capable and interested in their work, and appear to get along well together. The teachers have both had normal training in Saskatchewan.

I found the school building clean and tidy throughout. The pupils presented a clean and healthy appearance. I am attaching a snapshot which I took of the girls, to this report, and you will see that they are a good appearing lot of children.

I visited both class-rooms and had an examination in each. The pupils spoke up well in the senior class-room, but the teacher in the junior class-room informed me that she had great difficulty, even when alone, to get the junior pupils to speak above a whisper. I talked to the pupils of both class-rooms, pointing out the value of obtaining a thorough knowledge of English, as well as a training in domestic work. I was present each day during meal hours, and noted that the meals comprised plenty of good wholesome food, including meat, fish, vegetables and preserved fruit. Fish comprises a staple food for these people, and the children, I am informed, never appear to get tired of it. Most excellent whitefish is obtained from Lac la Ronge, and the fisherman keeps them supplied daily with fresh fish. The meat diet is varied with moose meat, which is not...
meat, which is not difficult to obtain at this point.

They have a large and well-kept garden, which provides an ample supply of potatoes, roots and vegetables for the use of the institution. The school stands on rocky ground, and I was very much interested in learning that the soil for the garden was brought in by canoe, a good many years ago. You will note from one of the snap-shots that I am enclosing that the outside of the garden fence is solid rock, while the garden itself has a good appearance.

Owing to the difficulty of obtaining feed for stock, only four cows, one bull and two horses are kept. Therefore it is impossible to supply the children with any quantity of milk for drinking purposes. The hay supply has to be purchased and brought across the lake for about fifteen miles. It costs the Principal $300.00 to provide hay for the seven head on hand during the past winter.

The land which was set aside for this school is all rock and muskeg. I went into this matter very closely and was informed that there was some land about one-half mile north of the school where a sufficient acreage could be cleared to enable them to grow their own feed for stock. I walked over this land in company with the engineer and found that his statement was correct. It would be quite possible to obtain the clearing of 25 or 30 acres, which would meet the requirements. In order to provide this, another quarter or half-section might be set aside for the use of the school. The land I speak of, I am satisfied will never be taken up by settlers.
up by settlers, as owing to the fact that it is surrounded by rocky land and muskeg, and has no lake frontage, it is practically valueless as it stands. I was informed that this land could be cleared with the help of the big boys at a cost of about $20.00 per acre. They have already cleared about three acres of this, but the Principal does not feel that he would be justified in spending any considerable amount until they have a proprietary right to the land. Unless some such arrangement is made, it would be impossible to increase the number of cows.

Main Building,

The main building, which is a frame structure on a stone foundation, is 65 feet X 105 feet. It comprises a basement, first and second floors, and an attic. It is heated with three hot air furnaces. I noted that one furnace fire-box is burnt out and should be replaced at once, as it is unsafe. The furnaces have been in use since the school was first built. The furnace pipes from two of the furnaces are 18 feet in length, and in the event of a fire starting in these pipes, there would be a great danger of the building catching on fire, as they are unprotected, and in order to make them safe, either galvanized iron or asbestos paper should be placed on the joists, above the pipes, as a measure of protection.

The ground floor provides two class-rooms, two play-rooms, as well as the office, staff sitting-room, bathroom and staff rooms. On the first floor there are two dormitories, each 56 feet X 26 feet, with a 12-foot ceiling. These dormitories are placed at each end of the building to give separation, are provided with bathrooms.
with two bathrooms, with two tubs, four basins and one toilet in each. The attic is used for storage purposes.

Fire protection is provided by a stand-pipe, with hose connections on each floor. There is an ample supply of pyrex and chemical extinguishers on each floor and in the basement. In the centre portion of the building there is a wide verandah, with a balcony above it. There is access to this balcony from the attic, and from the dormitories by means of four pole fire escapes, which continue on down to the floor of the verandah. There is also a stairway at the rear of the building, with access to it from the sewing-room which is used as a fire escape as well. The pupils are given occasional fire-drill. Each member of the staff has his given station, and understands his duties.

There are two chimneys in the building, and I noted that one had been cracked by fire, and should be re-faced with cement.

An addition at the rear of the building provides a kitchen, laundry and engine-room. The laundry equipment provides a large sized power washing-machine, extractor, mangle, two set tubs and three stoves. One of these stoves is equipped with a coil, and attached to a hot-water tank.

Upstairs over this division is situated a drying-room and an extra sewing room. I have already reported on the condition of the electrical plant, and the repairs required, are being sent forward.

While I found the school clean throughout, I may say that it has not been re-decorated for a long time, and the interior walls require re-decorating badly.

The water supply is obtained from the lake, and their pumping
and their pumping equipment is giving good satisfaction.

The outer buildings are adequate for the present requirements. The principal resides in a separate building, which is a neat and comfortable house.

There were 39 boys and 35 girls present on the date of my visit, which was the last day the school was open before the summer holidays.

There is one point which was brought to my attention here, and one I have mentioned in my general report: The fisherman who is employed by the school states that it is becoming increasingly difficult to catch sufficient fish for their requirements with a 5-inch mesh net, which is the mesh of net called for by the Regulations, and he further stated that if the size of the mesh were not reduced to 4½ inches, the Indians and the school would find it very difficult to obtain an adequate amount of fish. To use his own words, he said that the Indians would starve. As the Indians and the school officers catch fish for food only, and not for commercial purposes, it appears to me only reasonable that they should be permitted to use a net with which it is possible to catch fish, and I would suggest that the Department take this matter up very strongly with the Fisheries authorities.

Another point which was brought to my attention was: The principal of the school is required to obtain a permit, which costs him $15.00 per year, notwithstanding the fact that this is an Indian School, and the fish is being used to feed Indian children. Therefore, would it not be advisable to take the matter of granting a free
of granting a free license for this purpose.

Owing to this school being so remote from the railway, the matter of transporting their supplies from outside is an expensive one, particularly in the summer time. I am informed that the freight rate in the summer is 7¢ and in the winter 3¢ per cwt. This work has, in the past, been given to Indians, as far as possible. When they have to use the regular transportation companies from Prince Albert during the summer, they are called upon to pay 5¢ per cwt. There is a radio station about one-half mile from the school, from which it is possible to send out messages. The Post Office is about one-quarter mile distant, and the Hudson's Bay Company, Revillon Freres and an independent trader have stores in close proximity to the school.

There is a point that the Principal brought up with regard to the balcony being floored and ceiled, and he wishes to convert the extra sewing room in the back wing, into staff rooms. He can do this work with the aid of the staff, and has lumber and other material on hand, so that it will not be necessary to incur any expense in this connection, but he does not like to use this material without first getting authority from the Department to do so. I believe that the material in question was shipped in with the object in mind of making some addition to the school, which has since been thought inadvisable.
Dear Mr. Scott:

With regard to the Lac La Ronge School, it will be noted that the situation of this school is not by any means as favourable as that at Beauval, there being very little land under cultivation, or fit for that purpose. The Inspector points out that some might be obtained if the Department could arrange for the purchasing of same, or for having it set aside. I do not know how this affects the arrangements made with the Provincial Government re setting land aside for the Indians, but would suggest that it be set aside as an Indian reserve, and the school then allowed to use it. I would be glad to be advised in this connection, and I will then take the matter up with the proper authorities here. We should certainly provide for the growing of hay for feed for the cattle, so that the children could obtain milk as part of their diet.

The Inspector gives a description of the building in his report. The furnaces that are out of order should be repaired with the least possible delay, and either the Department should provide for this work, or they should see that the school authorities have it done, as a fire at this point would be a very serious matter. The chimney should also be repaired.

I will take the matter of reducing the size of the mesh of nets from 5 to 4½ inches up with the Fisheries Branch, as, in any event, it will have to be dealt with here in Regina.

With regard to the suggestion that the balcony be floored and ceiled with the material on hand, and with the help of the school staff, I would be glad to have your instructions in this matter. I would say that I think we should act on the suggestions of the Principal, in this connection.

W. M. Graham.

Dear Sir:-

Re - Wood burning jacket heater for
Lac la Ronge School, C. of E.

In your letter of December 5th, 1930, 132-2-5,
(see also your letter November 6th, 1930, 132-2-5) you
authorized the installation of a hot water tank at our Lac
la Ronge Indian Residential School. In my letter to you on
December 24th, 1930, I quoted an extract from a letter received
from Mr. Principal Fisher, in which he stated, with regard to
the heating of this tank, that "it would be better to have
a dual system of heating - one attachment to the furnace for
use during the months of winter, and the other for use when
the furnaces are not used. If a heater to burn wood could
be obtained, that would be best, but whatever kind of heater
it is, it should burn wood not less than 30" long".

The hot water tank authorized was installed, and
arrangements made for the same to be connected with the
central furnace. In a letter recently received from Mr.
Principal Fisher, and dated October 15th., he writes, in part,
as follows, with regard to this matter:-

"I am sorry to say, from the heating standpoint, the
hot water tank is not a success. When Mr. Inspector
Murison was here he suggested sending a jacket heater
to attach to this tank, but from what I have heard of
jacket heaters, they will take only small pieces of
wood. I recommend that instead of a jacket heater, a
large-sized box stove that would burn wood 3' long,
be supplied. I am afraid we will never have real
heat water until we have additional means of heating.
The firm who supplied the tank would be able to
advise you with regard to the best kind of heater to
secure."
On receipt of the above letter I took the matter up at once with the Marshall-Wells Company, Ltd., the firm that supplied the tank, and they furnished me with the following information and the enclosed blue print drawing of the heater they recommended. Their letter reads as follows:

"We are pleased to quote you a price of $333.00 f.o.b. Winnipeg, sales tax included, for one only wood burning jacketed Hot Water Heater, having Furnace thirty inches in diameter by five foot length, equipped for burning cord wood, as per blue print attached No. P.943, to connect up to large tank supplied you some time ago. You will note that the inlet is two inches and the outlet for the hot water is two and one-half inches. The smoke collar is ten inches in diameter. The weight of this Boiler is 2660 pounds.

Trusting our quotation will meet with your approval, and hoping to receive your valued order."

You will note that the price of $333.00 for the heater recommended is f.o.b. Winnipeg only. As the weight is given at 2660 lbs., the freight charges from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge would amount to, at 3¢ a lb., $79.80. To this would have to be added transportation charges from Winnipeg to Prince Albert, and handling charges there. To cover the total cost of transportation charges from Winnipeg to Lac la Ronge, the sum of $433.00 would be required, and possibly a little more.

As the heater is very urgently needed, and as I gather from letters recently received from your Department, that your appropriation for the current fiscal year is limited, I shall be obliged if you will inform me, if your Department will refund to our Society at the beginning of the fiscal year 1932-33, the total cost of purchasing and delivering this heater, with the necessary connections, if we place an order at once, and pay the bills, should the Marshall-Wells Co., ask for payment in the meantime. This suggestion is offered in view of the urgency of the need, and in order that the shipment may go forward as soon as the winter trail is open. A prompt reply will oblige.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, relative to the supplying of a wood burning jacketed hot water heater for the Lac la Rouge Indian Residential School. In this connection it is noted that the hot water tank which was installed is not a success and that the jacket heater is badly needed.

You may place an order for the supplying of one only wood burning jacketed heater, of the type as mentioned in the quotation which you received from Marshall-Wells Company, Limited. The price should not exceed the quotation which you received, viz.: $335.00 f. o. b. Winnipeg, sales tax included. You should arrange to have the heater forwarded to the school.

The Department will pay the cost of supplying this heater, together with the freight charges thereon, from Winnipeg to the school. Please obtain an account, in duplicate, from the firm from which you make the purchase, as well as receipts for freight charges from Winnipeg to Prince Albert. These accounts, you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department, when payment will be made. The amount of the freight charges from Prince Albert to the school has been noted, and this will be paid upon receipt of the account, in duplicate, properly certified.

Funds for the above purpose can be found in this year's appropriation, and I would request, therefore, that the accounts be forwarded soon after the purchase has been made.

The blue print drawing of the heater recommended to be supplied, which you enclosed in your letter, is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Murison,

I beg to submit the following report on the schools which I inspected during the time I was Paying Officer for the Ile a la Crosse Agency.

LAC LA RONDE CHURCH OF ENGLAND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I arrived at this school on the night of July 8th, remaining here until leaving for Stanley on July 12th.

Owing to the school being closed for the summer vacation and rainy weather, the Reverend Mr. Fisher, Principal allowed me the use of one of the classrooms for the purpose of making annuity payments and holding band meetings.

I found the Reverend Mr. Fisher conscientious and keen in his service to this institution. This was reflected in the general atmosphere of keen co-operation apparent between this man and his staff, which included Miss E.V. Williams, Matron; F.E. Simmon, 1st teacher; Mr. Crozier, 2nd teacher; C. Pinney, Girls' Supervisor; B. Baird, Boys' Supervisor; E. Smith, Kitchen Matron; D. Mathews, Laundress; N.L. Patrick, Nurse; A.C. Hastings Engineer; T.A. Mills, Farmer; and C.C. Brown, Fisherman.

Owing to the school being closed as already mentioned, I did not examine the class work of the pupils. However, during the payment here and at Stanley I came in contact with many of them. In addressing these I found them well mannered, clean, tidy, neatly dressed and apparently well nourished, and I found they would join in conversation more readily than many Indian pupils I have met. They expressed a keen interest in their school work and seemed very loyal to the institution.

I found the school and other buildings pertaining thereto clean and tidy within and the grounds without very nicely kept.

The Reverend Principal informed me there were about 2000' of lumber left over after using that authorized by the department. This surplus is being used to good advantage, mainly in building partitions in the upper dormitory for the girls, which will accommodate two full beds and a staff room. Partitions are also being built to separate the smaller boys from the larger, and any surplus lumber left will be used for general repairs to buildings. The floors and ceilings of the upper balconies were not completed. I was advised they will be this fall. The Principal requested that wire screening 6' x 65' be provided for this. It could then be used for isolation cases during the summer months.

I found the chimney of this building has been repaired, but does not draw well at times, resulting in soot overflowing and running down it; and on these occasions the building becomes smoky and the inside walls thereof are stained. I also noticed the basement joists have been protected with asbestos from the heat of the furnace pipes also a new fire box installed in one of the furnaces. In checking over the fire protection equipment I find further protection can be given by supplying a 50' x 5/8' garden hose and placing it in the upper dormitory to be used in case of chimney fires, also that recharges are necessary for the following fire extinguishers, 24 recharges Guardene Fire Ext. No. A. 606201 capacity 2½ gals., 12 recharges for Pyrene No. P 204697 1 quart type.
The interior of the school building should be redecorated in that many of the walls are stained, and paint worn off some of the floors and part of the wood-work. I also noticed moss growing between the crevices of the shingles on the roof which should be stained or repainted.

My attention was also drawn to the fact that some of the dormitory beds need replacing badly, whereas a little enamel paint would improve the appearance of others.

The farm stock consists of 4 milk cows, a team of horses, and 36 hens. These are not adequate to supply the general demand made on them. I find the nature of the land here is not adaptable for cultivation and the Principal informs me that it is only with some effort on the part of this institution that enables them to maintain what little stock they have. In this I concur.

In going over the land I was forcibly impressed with the fact that this institution will never support its staff and members by any produce derived therefrom, regardless of the amount of labour expended in any attempt to do so. While here, I was questioned concerning a further grant of land to them.

Apart from the requirements already mentioned, I find this school require the following:

- New Rear Start for Fairbanks Morse 52 volt Lighting Plant.
- 2 toilet bowls with flush tanks (as replacements)
- 1 wash basin with fittings (as there is only 1 toilet room for staff in this building)
- 2 doz. beds and mattresses 6 x 2½ for replacements
- 1000 shingles for repairing roof.
- 50 gals roof paint - green or creosot
- 1½ gal white enamel paint for bedsteads
- 15 gal floor paint - grey for dormitory floors.
- 3 gals turpentine.
- 5 lbs dry burnt umber.
- 7 gals. floor varnish for halls and dining room.
- 3 furnace door linings for McClary's Farnour Magnet Furnace No.H19A.

In view of the effort involved by this institution in an endeavour to carry on the good and only work of its kind in this section of the North, I would respectfully request they be given special consideration in grants the department may be considering for these institutions.

S. M. Simpson.
Paying Officer.

Dear Sir:

The Rev. G. W. Fisher, Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, Sask., has directed the attention of our Commission to the urgent need of a brick chimney for the main school building, and I am writing for the specific purpose of asking your Department to authorize the expenditure involved in providing the same. When this school was built, it was built at a comparatively small cost to your Department, as practically all the lumber and timber required for the same was cut and dressed in the school saw-mill. The iron Hudson's Bay chimneys which were installed, however, have never been satisfactory. Wood is used as fuel, and the school management have had great difficulty in keeping them free from creosote, which chokes them up, with the result that the building is filled with smoke whenever the fires are being made up. There is also a constant danger that the creosote encrustation will itself catch fire, and, in turn, set fire to the roof or some other part of the building.

Our Commission have secured from experts in Winnipeg the following information with regard to the materials and cost of building a 56' chimney which would have 3 flues, all of which are necessary, because of the number of furnaces in use, in addition to the hot water heater and the kitchen stove. The bricks and other materials mentioned make provision for a chimney with 9" walls, other than the parts between the flues, and the flues themselves are to be 13" x 13" square. The inside of each flue is to be coated with cement plaster and flue lining. The Principal submitted the sketch of the chimney of the three flues, and you will notice that he indicates the flues which are to be 9" square. Our expert declares that 9" flues are much too small, being smaller than those used for...
dwelling houses in the City, and he recommends that the flues should each be 13" square. The list of materials he made out, and which is given below, was based on 9" flues. If 13" flues are made, and I recommend that this be done, there will be an additional cost for materials amounting to $87.75. This is the list:

3600 Bricks (Snyder) .................. $67.35
133 Fire Bricks (St. Louis) .......... 14.65
10 lb. Fire Clay ...................... .30
58 Bags of Lime - 100 lbs. .......... 54.25
30 Bags Cement ....................... 25.40
150 Lin. ft. Flue lining 8½"x8½" ..... 90.75
3 - 9" Thimbles ....................... .85
3 - Clean out doors with frames .... 2.65
16 Lin. ft. Galv. Iron 12" flashing ... 1.95

Freight charges to Prince Albert ...... 108.00
(26160 lbs. 10th. class 36¢ rate)

The total cost for materials delivered at Prince Albert would be $423.90. To this must be added say $900.00 for freight from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge.

With regard to the cost of building, the Principal states that there is a competent brick-layer at Lac la Ronge, who, with the assistance of four laborers would build the chimney for $250.00. This would bring the total cost of building the chimney up to $1,873.90, and I shall be glad to have your authorization to have the work undertaken at once. The freighting season is getting shorter, and there is very little time to order the materials and have them put through before the break-up. The amount, at first sight, may appear to be quite large, but to my mind it is better to provide this school with the comfort and safety which the chimney will afford, rather than run the risk of losing the whole school building and of endangering the lives of staff agents and pupils. An authorization by telegram to have the work undertaken at once will be greatly appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Dr. McGill:

With further reference to my telegram of March 29th, and your reply to the same on the same day re (1) the loss by fire of the Principal's residence at Lac la Ronge, (2) authority to spend a sum not exceeding $700.00 for a new chimney on the main school building, and (3) authority to close the school until a new chimney can be erected should the fire hazard be as great as stated in my telegram, I beg to submit the following information:

1. With regard to the loss of the Principal's residence, I may state that in a letter received here yesterday from the Rev. Principal Fisher, he states that the fire was caused through sparks from the chimney lighting on the roof, but despite the best efforts of himself, the staff, and the neighbours to extinguish it, the building was completely destroyed. Some personal effects and equipment were saved, but no lives were lost. The Principal states that he will find accommodation in the main school building for the balance of this year, or until such time as a new residence has been provided.

2. Immediately after receiving your telegram authorizing the building of a new chimney in the main school building, we telegraphed our freighting agent in Prince Albert to ascertain if he could deliver bricks, cement, etc., before the trail broke up, but have heard in reply that this is quite impossible. As it is also impossible to forward 2500 or 3000 bricks, cement, etc., during the summer months, our Commission will see that these are taken through at the beginning of next winter. In the meantime the Principal is being instructed to effect such repairs to the chimney as will enable it to be used without great risk until the new one can be built. Very little firing will be done during the summer months, and with the repairs it is hoped that the chimney may serve until the Spring of 1935, by which time the material can be sent in and the work of erecting a new one undertaken. I expect to visit this
school myself sometime this summer, and I will then give the matter my personal attention.

3. The concern of our Commission over the question of fire hazard through defective chimneys, will be explained to you by the enclosed copy of a letter addressed to the Principals of all our schools on Sept. 24th, 1927. At that time your predecessor, Dr. Duncan C. Scott, addressed a circular letter to the Principals of Indian Residential Schools on Oct. 6th, 1927, the first paragraph of which reads as follows:

"The recent tragic fire at the Beauville School, resulting in a serious loss of life, prompts me to write concerning the necessity of constant care, if the fire hazard to life and property is to be minimized. If you are not satisfied with the present fire escape facilities at your school, I should be grateful if you would let the Department have a report."

From that time onward our Commission has impressed upon the Principals of the schools under their control the vital necessity of providing every possible safeguard against an outbreak of fire, and the members feel strongly that they should not be held responsible for any accidents which may result from defective chimneys, or lack of adequate fire fighting equipment, especially after the Department had agreed with our Society to meet capital expenditure of this sort.

From what I have stated in section 2 above, I am of the opinion that the school may continue to operate until the Spring of 1935, and I beg to thank you on behalf of our Commission, for the authority you have given to spend $700.00 in providing the second new chimney required. If we can have it built at an earlier date, we shall certainly do so, but on account of the freighting difficulties mentioned, I have strong doubt as to the possibility of our being able to accomplish this.

Very truly yours,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

In my letter of April 7th last, addressed to you in reply to your telegram of March 29th, I stated that I expected to visit our Lac la Ronge School this summer, when I would give my personal attention to the condition of the second chimney in the main school building. I have recently returned from a visit which lasted from May 26th until June 1st, and am pleased to be able to report as follows:

1. That the new chimney which was built last year is of excellent workmanship, and will add greatly to the safety of the school.

2. That the chief defect in the second chimney is in the part which appears above the roof. There is a small crack in the basement which can be closed with cement so as to render it serviceable during the coming winter. I authorized, at our Commission's expense, repairs to the top part of the chimney, and feel confident that, with care and vigilance this chimney may be made to serve through another winter, when the building of the second chimney you have authorized will be undertaken. We are fortunate in being able to secure locally the services of an expert mason for this work.

3. As I did not consider the chimney in the laundry fully met the conditions of safety we desire, I authorized the building of another this summer. The cost of this improvement will also be met by our Commission.

-GENERAL SURVEY-

At the time of my visit the school had 98 pupils in residence, and a staff of 14 agents, exclusive of my daughter Miss D. Westgate, R.N., who is discharging the duties of school and
A strict nurse at that centre. All the pupils were in good health, with the exception of 3, who were suffering from tuberculosis, with varying prospects of recovery under treatment. As the school has no infirmary, and patients have to be kept in cots on the spacious verandahs of the main school building, it would be a great help to the Principal and his staff and the nurse if a small detached building could be erected for the accommodation of such cases. As the school could supply the lumber and put up the building if a grant of $200.00 were made for shingles, doors, windows, nails, stove, etc., our Commission will be obliged if you will kindly give this matter your own personal consideration.

I found that fire drill was regularly practised, and when the alarm was sounded during my visit the school was fully cleared in three minutes. As a bent iron bar is made to serve as a fire alarm, and cannot be distinctly heard in the remoter parts of the building, I feel strongly that an electric alarm system should be installed with gongs on each floor, and beg to recommend that this important matter also be given your own personal consideration.

Adequate farming and gardening land is a serious problem at all our schools in the northern parts, and Lac la Ronge is no exception. Since my last visit three years ago, the school management, by great manual labour, had cleared and fenced two acres. During my visit drills were made with hoes and mattocks and we "planted" this area with oats and brome grass seed mixed. It would be a great help if a grant could be made by your Department to help in the clearing of additional land, where oats and green feed could be grown, and we would be saved the heavy expense of having to supply the same from Prince Albert.

The furnaces, three in number, are, on the whole, in very good condition, requiring only some minor repairs such as door shields, bottom dampers, and stove pipe dampers, as mentioned in the list forwarded to your Department on October 11th last (page 46), but galvanized cold air, in-take furnace pipes are sorely needed, as the Principal stated that it was very difficult last winter to get any warmth into certain parts of the building. I asked the Principal to direct the attention of the representative of your Department who would accompany the Treaty party this year, to this special need, and also to the need of 16 additional batteries for the lighting system.

I have already addressed two letters to the Secretary of your Department referring to the urgent need of a new cylinder head and carburetter for the engine which operates the lighting and water systems, but so far have received no communication in reply to either letter. As the cost involved does not exceed $85.00 for these items of equipment, delivered at the school, and as their early provision may prevent a much heavier expenditure which may result through delay, it will be appreciated if you will give this matter your own personal attention.

A new residence should be supplied for the Principal not later than next year, to take the place of the one destroyed by fire.
last March. The school management will cut the lumber required for this building during the present summer, and our Commission instructed me to ascertain what help your Department would be able to give in providing doors, windows, shingles, nails, paint, etc., which will have to be purchased and sent in from outside. The school management will do the work, but our Commission feel that they could not meet all the expenditure involved.

Our Commission have authorized, at my recommendation very considerable improvements to the subsidiary buildings, also some furniture and furnishings, but the main school building stands sorely in need of paint, inside and outside, including the roof, and I would assure you that any help your Department may be able to give in meeting the needs I have specified will be very deeply appreciated.

The work being accomplished is, to my mind, altogether worthy of the fullest support which your Department and our Society are able to give it.

With very good wishes, Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Analysis of sample of water (our no. 511/34) sent to us on October 15th shows it to contain 0.02 percent total dissolved solids consisting mainly of calcium bicarbonate and a deposit of iron oxide. The trouble you mention is apparently due to the presence of iron in the form of the soluble salt, iron bicarbonate. When such water is allowed to stand or is heated in a boiler, the iron bicarbonate decomposes to give carbon dioxide and iron oxide, the latter appearing as a reddish sludge. The iron may therefore be removed by aeration (spraying the water and settling) or by long exposure to the air in tanks or finally by chemical treatment. Thus treatment with lime or soda ash would remove all the iron and soften the water considerably.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) V. A. Vigfusson.

Dear Sir:

When I visited our Lac la Ronge School in June of last year, my attention was directed to difficulties which had arisen in connection with the water supply for the main school building. The supply which is drawn from a well, and not from the lake, frequently comes out of the pipes a reddish colour. It was also found that the water was seriously affecting the whole piping system. Arrangements were made to have a sample of the water analyzed, and enclosed herewith you will find the result of the analysis as forwarded to the Rev. Principal Fisher by the Provincial Analyst in the Province of Saskatchewan.

He recommends the installation of a water softener, and so far as our Commission can see, the only way in which the situation can be remedied is to provide the school with a water softening process, or to arrange for the school's supply of water to be drawn from the lake instead of from the well. As the latter process would probably be much more expensive than the other, our Commission would recommend that a water softener be supplied.

Your careful and sympathetic consideration of this important matter will be greatly appreciated by our Commission.

Dear Sir:

Some time ago I received the copy of the letter received by you from the Indian Department with reference to the building the new residence at this school, and I note that plans and specifications will be prepared after it is known whether funds will be available for this purpose.

As this will probably be after March 31st, before this will be known, I would suggest that it will be too late then to begin to send to Lac la Ronge the materials necessary to build during the coming summer, therefore I am enclosing a list of the materials which I think will be needed. I have based my estimates on the plan submitted to you for consideration. Of course, you could have my figures checked over by an expert.

You will notice that I am asking for wallboard for the lining of the house throughout. I have done this after very careful consideration, and for the following reason. In the old house we were always having trouble with the plaster falling; and I would suggest that the best finish will be wallboard put on over a sheathing of half-inch lumber. While possibly it will cost more to ship in the wallboard than lime, the difference in the cost will be more than made up in the saving of time, and by the fact that Hastings and I can do the work, whereas if we plaster it will be necessary to employ an expert plasterer. The joints would be covered with wallboard tape, and the whole finally papered. I hope you will agree to this proposal.

I am also submitting a list of the materials required for building the residence chimney. Mr. VanderKraft's estimate for building the school chimney calls for 2600 bricks, and the residence main chimney 1950 bricks. In addition 300 bricks will be required for the kitchen chimney. Therefore 1300 more bricks will be needed over and above the 3600 already ordered.
With regard to the furnace I have merely indicated the items required, and I would ask that an expert be asked to check over these items, and say just what will be required. If you require a copy of the plan already submitted, and will let me know over CFQC, Saskatoon, I will forward one on Wednesday next.

An additional amount of lime and cement will be needed for building the basement wall, but before asking for any definite amount, I would like to consult Mr. Vanderkraft again on this matter, and as soon as I have done this I will write to you again.

I would also call attention to the item: 2300 ft. of fir flooring. I am asking for this because we cannot make really good flooring at the school mill, and I feel sure it will pay in the long run to put down good floors.

I would also like to call attention to the fact that if the materials are supplied, Mr. Hastings and I will be able to take care of the carpenter work, and it will be unnecessary to engage any outside labour save for the building of the basement wall and chimneys, and possibly to install the furnaces.

There are two books on page 294 of Eaton's Catalogue, which while they are not absolutely necessary, would be of great help to us in building. I shall be glad if you will send me by mail books #712-R188 and R189. I am sure these books will be of great help to us.

I am, Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) G. W. Fisher,
Principal.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

The sum of $2,500.00 is provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the coming fiscal year towards the cost of erecting a residence for the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge, (Reserve No. 186, Ile-a-la-Crosse Agency, Sask., Federal District of Melfort). This school is conducted under the auspices of the Missionary Society of the Church of England, and Reverend T. B. R. Westgate, Field Secretary, E. S. C. C., is strongly urging that the building materials be purchased and forwarded before the present winter trails close. He states that, if the materials are not delivered this winter, it will be impossible to build the residence during the coming summer.

Dr. Westgate has submitted a detailed list of doors, door frames, windows, shingles, cement, hardware and other building materials required. The source of supply for these materials would be Prince Albert, Saskatoon, or Winnipeg. Dr. Westgate suggests the best course to take in arranging for the purchase and obtaining the quantities and sizes of the various materials would be to authorize the Principal to come out to Prince Albert and Saskatoon to select them, himself, and arrange for their freighting to the school.

I would request your authority to incur the expenditure for the purchase of the building materials - it being understood, however, that payment of the accounts would not be made until the Appropriation for the coming fiscal year is available. I request, also, that you will advise if it will be satisfactory for the Principal or Dr. Westgate to arrange for the purchase. They would be instructed to obtain itemized accounts, covering the cost. They will be given the names of firms on the approved list from whom to make purchase. If the materials are to be forwarded this winter, by sleigh, from Prince Albert to the school - a distance of approximately 300 miles - it is necessary that early arrangements be made.

I may say that the greater part of the labour in the erection of the building will be carried out by the school authorities, without expense to the Department. The total cost of the building materials which the school authorities request be purchased and forwarded this winter will be approximately $1,100.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a report on my recent treaty payments to Montreal Lake, Lac la Ronge and Stanley.

Lac la Ronge School

This is built of lumber, three storeys high, very narrow halls and in my opinion a regular fire trap. The chimneys are of brick and in very good shape, furnaces were repaired and are in better shape than at my last inspection. Building is generally in poor condition having been built from green lumber and in such a shape if a fire did break out, I doubt if everyone would get out safely. The eaves are down three brass poles. Children have to make an exit from the roof or verandah on third floor, then down to second verandah and then to the main floor. Only piece of iron is hanging in the hall to raise alarm and a bolt there to hit it with which can very easily be misplaced and not there when wanted. I am doubtful if alarm could be heard by children sleeping or the staff and certainly could not be heard in rear of building. I would recommend that an electric system be installed and a weekly fire drill instituted.

Engine room adjoins main building which is at end of laundry, this is also a lumber building and certainly not fire proof, a certain amount of oil having soaked into floors.

Mr. Fisher drew my attention to the engine and lighting system. A new set of batteries will have to be supplied, sixteen large batteries are in use and a request was made that thirty-two be furnished in order to give better service. Type EOGO-13 8 hour capacity, 280 a.h. date H L. Engine is just about worn out needs a new cylinder and piston, this is a 10 horse power Z type engine No. 566204 Fairbanks Morse. I also noticed fire box in oven was burnt out and will take about $25.00 to replace, lining in bricks in cook stove are worn out. Window screens are also in bad shape and will take about $50.00 to replace. Building is in need of decorating inside and out.

The school is well managed by Mr. Fisher and he feels he is doing good work amongst Indians. However, in my opinion this school should be closed as it is very little use educating them when they have no way of making a living other than trapping which they are unable to do when they are discharged. There is no way of teaching farming as there is no suitable land and the whole thing appears to me to be a waste of good money.

R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 2, 1935.

Reverend Sir:

The Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year provides the sum of $800.00 towards the cost of supplying batteries for the lighting system and also a new engine to operate the lighting plant at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. Mr. R. S. Davis, Indian Agent, Leask, Sask., who visited the school during Treaty payments, states that the Principal drew his attention to the need of the above equipment. The Agent states the present equipment consists of 16 large batteries and that a request was made by the Principal that 32 be furnished, in order to give better service. He says the type required is EOGO-13 8 hour capacity, 280 a.h. The 10 h.p. Fairbanks "Z" type engine is worn out and needs a new cylinder and piston.

Owing to the difficulty in having the engine sent to Prince Albert or some other point for repairs, it is considered that it would be better to supply a new engine.

I shall be pleased if you will take up these matters with the Principal and advise the Department definitely as to the type and full particulars regarding the batteries. You should state, also, if you would recommend that a new engine be supplied or that the present one be repaired. If a new engine is recommended, the h.p. and type should be stated. Please state, also, when you would advise that this equipment be forwarded to the school.

Besides the above, there is an item of $800.00 in the Estimates, to carry out repairs and interior painting. I shall be pleased if you will ascertain from the Principal the repairs absolutely necessary at the present time and what interior decorating he requires. If possible, an estimate should be given of the cost of the materials and any outside labour it is necessary to employ.

When we have the information asked for above, consideration will be given to authorizing the purchase of the batteries and a new engine, if same is considered necessary, and also the minor repairs and painting. It should be understood, however, that the total amount available for all the above purposes is $1,600.

Dear Sir:

I have secured the information requested in your letter of August 2nd last No. 132-2-5, with regard to the new engine and batteries required at our Lac la Ronge School in connection with the lighting plant, and also the items required for painting and improving the interior of this institution, and you will find the same enclosed herewith as follows:

(1) Quotation on engines and batteries from the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., Limited, Winnipeg, dated Oct. 7th.

(2) Quotation submitted by the Rev. Principal Fisher on materials for painting and improving the interior of the school.

(3) Quotation submitted by the T. Eaton Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, on materials for painting the interior of the school.

As it is considered that the extras amounting to $75.00 given on page 1 of the quotation from the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., will not be required, the cost of a 10 H.P. 4 cycle, Diesel engine delivered at Lac la Ronge would be approximately $867.70. (See notes I have made in margin on page 2 of the quotation from the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co.)

The cost of 32 cells, Exide Storage Battery delivered at Lac la Ronge would be $760.00. (See note in margin on page 2 of the quotation from the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co.) The total cost of these two items delivered at Lac la Ronge would be approximately $1627.70.
The estimate of the Principal for the painting and material required for the interior of the main school building, is probably a little too high, but I think we may say that it would amount to somewhere around $650.00. As the total estimated cost for the engine, the batteries, and the paints and materials is $2,327.70, and as you have made it quite clear in your letter that the total amount available for these improvements is only $1600.00, I can only recommend that the paints and materials required for the interior of the main school building be allowed to stand over until next year, and that authority be given our Commission to purchase at once the engine and batteries from the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co. at the prices quoted, and arrange for their shipment to the school as soon as the winter trail is open.

Lac La Ronge Residential School:

I inspected the school and found the children in fair health. This school in my opinion is overcrowded. For instance classroom grades 1-3, is 20 x 30 with a ten foot wall, containing 74 desks, there is an average of 63 pupils in the room, and it is not possible to open windows as children are packed right up against them. Light is very poor, two windows to east and two to south. Absolutely no ventilation, and air in room is terrible - very unhealthy.

Grades 4-8, room is 24 x 33, walls 10'. Average 50 pupils. This room has five windows, and no ventilation as windows cannot be opened on account of children sitting so close to same.

I consider some system of ventilation should be installed, or another classroom built. Laundry and engine room could be converted into a classroom and laundry and engine room constructed away from the main building.

Blackboards are in very poor condition in room grades 1-3, this would require a new board 22' x 3'.

Infirmary

A year ago $200.00 was allowed to build an infirmary onto school building. This has been erected about 200 yards from the school. This building 28 x 16 - 9' walls, solid brick chimney from ground up, and would consider value of this building to be around $700.00, partly paid out of school funds. It will take $200.00 to complete this building as it will need wall-board inside, and siding outside.

Principal's Residence

Rev. G. W. Fisher is now residing in new building which was constructed last year. As not enough funds were available this house was not completed. Only one room is completed up-stairs, all downstairs is completed. It will take $500.00 to complete residence.

General

This school is very well managed. The building is old and nothing more than a fire trap. Some system of fire alarm should be installed, as one in use is no good, and if fire should break out during night I am sure some lives would be lost.
