Sir,

I beg to report on my trip to Montreal Lake, Lac-la-Ronge and Stanley in connection with 1936 Annuity Payments:

School Boarding.

This building is an old frame building, which was built of green lumber, is very poorly planned, and is nothing less of a fire trap. Three fires have occurred since my last visit January 1936, which were gotten under control.

One occurred in January in the kitchen, which did no damage.

The second started on the roof and attic floor, and if this had not been discovered in time no doubt the building would have been completely destroyed.

The third started in the wall between the play room on the girls side of the building burning a portion of the wall between the play and class rooms. This was caused from the new chimney that was built last year. This work was done by the Commission with instructions direct from the Department. In my opinion this chimney should not be used, as it will in all probability start another fire, and if it occurred during the night I feel sure lives would be lost.

The fire-alarm system consists of an iron bar and bolt and cannot be heard in all parts of the building. I had the fire-hose tested and found in good condition. If a fire should start in the basement it would not be long before water supply would be cut off as engine is located there.

Fire-drill was held and it took the children seven minutes to vacate, but if a fire started with everyone excited they would not get the children out in anything like this time. If the Department had some form of instructions to be followed in fire-drill, such as a check on children when they got out and what should be done by different members, would be of great help. If an experienced Fire Chief could visit some of these Boarding Schools and make recommendations to be followed, it would bear some weight and help officials when checking these schools. Most of the staffs are not level headed, if they were would not be holding down the positions they do.

The children's food consist of fish, bread and lard, three times a day; once or twice a week they get peanut butter for supper, also some oatmeal is added for breakfast.

School draws its pupils from Stanley, Lac-la-Ronge and Montreal Lake. In my opinion they should not be allowed to take pupils from Montreal Lake, as we have a good day school there, and only makes the cost of education out of all reason.

Yours truly,
R. S. Davis

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of the 23rd ultimo, Number 132-2-5, advising me that Mr. Indian Agent Davis considers the new chimney erected last year at our Lac la Ronge School was not properly constructed and constitutes a fire hazard. In this connexion, I beg to state that the Principal of this School, the Rev. G.W. Fisher, is being asked to give this matter his immediate attention, and to remedy any defects he can discover. It is my present understanding that the chimney itself was well built, but that some of the beams in the framework of the School were in too close contact with it. I am of the opinion that this matter has already been attended to, but I am calling the attention of the Principal to it in case it has not.

Recently the roof of the building caught fire from a spark from one of the chimneys, but this was extinguished before any extensive damage was done. To prevent a recurrence of this sort of thing our Commission are considering the possibility of having the School covered with metal shingles. After they have secured comparative prices on the different kinds of non-inflammable roofing, I may write to you again in the matter. In the meantime I wish to assure you that our Commission and the School management will continue to do everything possible to eliminate fire hazards at this institution.
While writing on this subject, I desire to lay before you the urgent need of an adequate fire alarm system for this School. This need is set forth in the following extract from a letter from the Principal, dated June 2, 1936:

"In connection with our fire alarm system, I would like to say it is an understood thing in the community at large, that the continuous ringing of the school bell is a call for assistance. On Monday our alarm failed to call anyone, and for the following reasons. First, the bell began to ring at the usual "first bell" hour of 8.45. Secondly, in the anxiety to ring the bell as loudly as possible, the bell was turned over, and so could not be rung properly. I would like to suggest that the Commission urge upon the Indian Department the necessity of providing us with an adequate fire alarm system both inside and outside of the building. For outside use, I would suggest a siren whistle. I believe these can be obtained to be operated by a hand crank.

Two years ago I called the attention of the Indian Agent to the need for a better alarm system within the building, and he promised to take up the matter with the Department, but so far, the Department has done nothing. It is my intention to speak to the Indian Agent again, when he visits the school on June 19th.

In conclusion: I would like to say that the fire was not caused by anyone's neglect. The chimneys have been regularly swept. Mr. Courtney has been very careful in this matter, and we have had no chimney fires."

It will be appreciated if your Department will give this very important matter immediate attention, and instruct your representative, Mr. Indian Agent Davis, to supply this School with suitable fire alarm systems for both inside and outside use.

Your obedient servant,

As a means of further eliminating the fire hazard at this school our Commission are keenly desirous of having the wooden shingles replaced by metal ones. In my letter of the 6th inst. I stated that we were securing comparative prices, and those received from the T. Eaton Company, Winnipeg, are as follows:

# 1-B c Cedar XXX Shingles - $4.75 per M
# 2 " " " - $3.65 " M

Metal Shingles for 44 sheets - $10.70

1-M Cedar Shingles will cover 100 square feet 4½ inches to the weather.
44 Sheets Metal ditto will cover the same surface.

The quotation for Cedar Shingles is for IMMEDIATE ACCEPTANCE - they vary almost from day to day.

August 6th - 1936

I cannot give you the exact area of the roof to be covered, but estimate that it would be about 8,400 feet. The cost of metal shingles to cover such an area would be approximately $900.00 apart from transportation charges. As it is not possible for our Commission or for the school management to meet this expenditure out of the amount sanctioned in your official letter of May 1st, I cannot see any prospect of having a metal roof provided until funds are made available for this purpose by your Department.

As the metal shingles could not be sent through before the winter trail opens, I would earnestly request that authority be given to our Commission to purchase the shingles and send them through before the winter trail closes, the cost to be met out of your appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38. Such an arrangement would enable us to remove, so far as is possible, one of the greatest fire hazards at a school where wood fuel is used.

Your sympathetic consideration of this important matter will be highly appreciated.

The Principal has recommended that galvanized iron be used, and we are now awaiting a list of quantities and exact measurements before placing an order for the same.

To our Commission it is a matter of first rate importance that this School which burns wood fuel should be provided with a roof of non-inflammable material, but I am convinced in my own mind that it cannot be provided out of the
grant of $1,325.00 which you have sanctioned.

As soon as we have secured the information requested, with regard to quantities and measurements, and are able to get an estimate of the cost plus transportation charges, I will write to you again in the matter.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of the 8th inst., number 132-2-5, addressed to the Rev. G. W. Fisher, Principal of our Lac la Ronge School, re freight rates.

In 1935 it is understood that Revillon Freres and the Hudson's Bay Company were both paying $2.50 per 100 lbs. for their freighting. The Commission had been paying $3.00 per 100 lbs. for theirs, and they therefore took up the matter with their freighter. The result was that a rate of $2.50 per 100 lbs. was arranged for 1936 with our Indian freighter. It was pointed out that a lower price would be quoted for a contract for 150 tons than for one of 50 tons, which is the School's estimate.

It is true that the Hudson's Bay Company, having eliminated Revillon Freres were able to make a contract for $1.75 per 100 lbs. for 1936, but evidently the contractor lost money on the deal, as the rate for 1937 has been advanced to $2.25 per 100 lbs.

For many years, the Commission have given their freight contract to W. A. Bear, in order to help him out. He is an Indian and has always taken a keen interest in the School. In a letter written by him to the Commission in August, 1935, he asks: "So do you think $2.60 per hundred be O.K.? One can come out O.K. at this rate in good years. In hard winters I know will keep me scratching to come out right. I am game to try my luck for this winter at this rate, $2.60 per hundred."

The question with Mr. Bear will be re-opened in view of Mr. Davis' report as the Commission cannot afford to pay more than ordinary freight rates.

Dear Mr. Davis:

Our Commission will be obliged if, on the occasion of your next visit to our Lac la Ronge School, you will give special attention to the possibility of having this School's water supply secured from the lake instead of from a well as at present.

You are aware, I understand, of the existing shortage of water at present, and of the consequent increase in fire hazard. While the deepening of the well may help to reduce the hazard, it will not eliminate the process of corroding which is said to be gradually destroying the water pipes. Our Commission, at very considerable expense, provides this School with a water-softening plant, and while it softens the water, the corroding process is still reported to continue. It is therefore the well considered opinion of the Commission that the source of this School's water supply should be changed from the well now used to the lake, on the shore of which the School is located. As the water supply at our Onion Lake and Sioux Lookout Schools is taken from adjacent lakes, we have good reason to believe that the change suggested at our Lac la Ronge School would be fully justified.

Your sympathetic consideration of this suggestion will be duly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir,

With further reference to our conversation while in Ottawa last month regarding the possibility of your Department making a grant for the building of an Engineer's residence at this school, and your desire that I write you further concerning this matter, I would like to submit the following information for your consideration.

Mr. Bulteel, our engineer, was married to a member of the school staff during the summer holidays, and with the consent of our Commission, for the present Mrs. Bulteel retains her position in the school. For this winter they occupy rooms in the school building, but they would like to have a house of their own next year. We would like to build a cottage for them as close to the school as possible.

I am enclosing for your perusal a suggested plan for the proposed cottage. It is estimated that it will cost about $2,500 to build. I shall be glad if you will lay this matter before your Department with the request that the Department make a grant to cover the entire cost, or at least assume a substantial amount of the cost of the same.

As it is desired to build as early next summer as possible, it will be necessary to get out logs during the coming winter with which to make lumber locally, and also to have the necessary doors, windows, shingles, building paper, etc., shipped in over the winter trails. I shall be glad if you will let me know the Department's decision as soon as possible, so that I may make more specific estimates of the materials required. Supplies would have to leave Prince Albert not later than March 1st.

Trusting the Department will be able help us in this matter,

I am,
Yours faithfully,

2. On taking this matter up with Rev. G. Fisher, Principal of the All Saints' Mission, Lac la Ronge, Sask., he stated that he quite agreed with Mr. Vander-Kraft regarding the stench of the sewer.

3. On checking the sewerage disposal system at the Mission I find that there are two underground tanks about fifty yards to the east of the school. One of these tanks draws all the waste materials from the toilets, basins and tubs. The second tank draws all the waters from the laundry. An overflow leads out of the second tank and goes to an approximate distance of forty yards from the lake shore. Tank number one overflows into tank number two - the liquids only leaving tank number one. Chemical treatment in this tank number one precipitates the solids. At the time of installation (sixteen years ago) there was a filter at the end of the overflow from the second tank but Rev. Fisher believes that this filter is now stopped and the liquids instead of filtering are coming through the top and on the surface of the ground. However, Rev. Fisher says it is impossible for any solids or paper to get into this overflow. No tank is bailed out twice.

4. With further regard to this sewerage system, I am informed by Rev. Fisher that he is at present negotiating with the Indian Department with regard to having a new filter put in and possibly to have the overflow drain north into the muskeg instead of south towards the lake. Any expense incurred in this matter would be chargeable to the Indian Department and would not be a matter for relief work.

5. With reference to the samples taken by Miss H. Resident Nurse, there were four samples taken, one from the Mission well, one from the natural reservoir dock (approx. 600 yds. from the Mission), one from the creek draining from the muskeg into the lake (approx. 1000 yds. from the Mission) and the fourth taken from the M.O.M. Police dock, (approx. 1100 yds. from the Mission). These samples all showed water unfit for human consumption unless boiled or chlorinated. A comment was made by the Department of Public Health, Regina, that these returns, that the samples should have been placed in sterilized containers obtainable from the Regina Laboratory. Sample number two from the creek (into which the sewerage would seep were it changed to other than muskeg) showed more unfit for human consumption than the other samples.

6. On checking the place where this sewage flows on the surface of the ground, I have not been able to find any trace of solids or paper which might cause the stench.

7. It is my belief that the waters are being polluted mostly by the various fish freights, live stock, dead fish, etc., and not in any other way. However, something must be done to stop the stench from the overflow as it is extremely nauseating at times.

8. I have taken this matter up personally since receiving his letter and will come down and examine the sewerage system.

Re. Your letter 132-2-5.

Dear Sir,

With further reference to your letter of March 29th, and my reply of April 9th, I would say that I have thoroughly gone into the matter with our Engineer, of the improvements which might be effected in our sewage disposal system. We have come to the conclusion that since the septic tank is in good working order, and there is no blockage between it and the settling pool, the cause of the offensive odour complained of, must be due to the settling itself being clogged. We would suggest, therefore, that during the coming summer, the settling pool be dug out, cleaned, and reconstructed. If, as we anticipate, this pool is full of stones, it will entail considerable labour to carry out this work, and I would ask the Department to make a grant of $300.00 for labour, and for any necessary materials which may be required. It will be impossible to determine just what may be required until the digging is commenced.

However, the suggestion made above would not do away with the overflow being discharged into the lake, and to avoid this it would be necessary to construct an entirely new system, and the direction of the discharge changed to run into the muskeg at the back of the school. This would necessitate the digging of a trench from eight to twenty feet deep, and about 600 ft long, in order to lay a new pipe system, and since the land through which this line would have to pass is full of boulders, it would entail a considerable amount of blasting and labour.

Since it will be impossible to carry through such a project during the coming summer, owing to the excessive cost of freighting the materials that would be necessary, I would suggest that the Indian Agent be made to make a thorough survey when he visits the school about June 20th. My own impression is that such a change in the entire system could not be made for less than $2000.00.
For your information I would say that in the early part of 1935, because of a similar complaint to the one recently made, at the request of Indian Agent Davis, I submitted sketches of our sewage disposal system, which were sent to Department of Public Health, Regina. Some time after I received a letter from Mr. Davis outlining what should be done to keep the system running smoothly. These instructions have been faithfully carried out. At that time, the Department of Public Health apparently made no objections to the overflow being discharged into the Lake. I can assure you that it is my desire to do everything in my power to remove permanently any cause for further complaint.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of May 2nd, file 132-2-5, in regard to the sewage system at the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School; I have inspected this system a number of times and have found that, owing to the formation of the ground in the locality of the school, I feel that it will be very difficult to ever make a sewage system work satisfactorily unless the first tank is sealed so that the overflow would not run into the second disposal tank which is about 100 yards away.

The formation of the land around the buildings is of rock and all the earth, or most of it, has been hauled for the garden.

Mr. Fisher suggested that another septic tank be built back in the muskeg, with an approximate cost of $2000.00, but I am of the opinion that the muskeg will also become polluted and the same condition will occur within a year or so and consequently the money would be wasted.

I am enclosing herewith a rough sketch of the locations of the buildings and the tanks. I have marked thereon, in red ink, the ground that I believe has become over soaked. Perhaps this circle is a little large but it will give you some idea of the conditions. I have also marked, in red ink, the outlet on the first tank that, in my opinion, should be sealed.

I have discussed the matter with Mr. Dempster, the Engineer at the P.A. National Park, and he could see no other solution and advised me to take the matter up with you and have you refer it to the Engineering Branch in Ottawa. If this proposal is adopted, it would be necessary to supply them with a tank in order to haul this refuse away from the school to a distance of about two miles from the buildings. A pump would also be required to pump out the first tank. The school have an engine that would be suitable for use on the pump.
Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant with further reference to the sewage system at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

The suggestion contained in the fourth and fifth paragraphs of your letter appear to be practical and no doubt you will study the situation carefully when you reach the school.

If, after discussing the matter again with the Principal, you decide that your plan should be tried you should report fully to the Department following your return and at the same time give full particulars regarding the tank and pump that you would recommend be supplied. Purchase of same will have to be made through our Purchasing Branch.

No doubt you can make satisfactory arrangements with the Principal to have the farm instructor at the school give more attention to the sewage plant in future.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a report on the northern proportion of this agency.

Indian Residential School Lac La Ronge.

The school building is nothing more or less than a fire trap. The whole heating system is in bad condition and the plan of the building is such that if a fire broke out at night it would be impossible to get the children out. I had a fire drill, but it is hard to tell just what would happen in the case of a fire, as when I have fire drill it is more or less expected and everyone is ready so that things run smoothly. The fire hose was inspected and tested. I found 50 feet of 1½" fire hose in bad shape which should be replaced at once and I am forwarding form 37 for this.

Sewage System

I thoroughly discussed the sewage system with Rev. Fisher and I am at a loss to know what to do as I cannot see where a system could be built that will look after the requirements of an institution of this size owing to the location of the school. The school is built on land that is of heavy rock formation and is about 15 feet above the level of the lake. As near as I can see the outlet previously ran into the lake but the lake level is now low and this overflow runs on top of the ground and is causing a very bad smell with a tendency to cause fever. The people of the village object to this and also object very strongly to us running it into the lake as this is the water supply for the whole settlement. Nothing was said about the disposal going into the lake in years gone by as no one knew anything about it at that time. I am enclosing a blue print of the system so that you will be able to have the engineering branch look it over and see just what can be done.

I previously recommended that this sewage be hauled away in a tank but on seeing the large amount of water that goes through this system, I believe that it would be impossible to do this unless a couple of men with tanks did nothing else.

I would recommend that the Department send an engineer to this school to go into the whole thing as a large amount of money could be spent with no results being obtained. I am holding up any work until I am further advised by the department as the amount of $300.00 the department has allowed would not improve conditions.

R. S. Davis.
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Indian Residential school, Lac La Ronge.

The school was inspected and conditions have improved a little in regards to the food for the children.

The children's dormitories should have screen windows, and as they have a handy man at the school, this work should have been done; it is impossible for the children to sleep at night with the mosquitos.

The lack of games for the children is a handicap to them; this phase of their education is very badly neglected. These children have no playground equipment with the exception of a baseball and a football and have not been taught how to get the best from these games.

Re: Sewage Disposal System, Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

Although as we advised in our memorandum of the 5th instant, it was understood that Mr. Dempster probably would not be able to make an inspection at the above school until later this fall we are now in receipt of a letter from him advising that he made a hurried trip by plane to Lac la Ronge on Thursday, the 3rd instant. Owing, however, to freezing conditions and the fact that the lakes might freeze overnight, he was only able to spend a portion of one day on making an inspection. For your information the following is quoted from Mr. Dempster's letter:

"I found that at present water was being pumped from a well, which, as near as I could make out, was being fed partially from the lake and partially from a small spring. Whereas there used to be from twelve to fourteen feet of water in this well, there is now only 4½ feet; hence on wash days they cannot pump sufficient water for their needs.

"As I see it, the only solution is to sink a new well closer to the lake and install a pipe line out into the lake. I do not believe water will filter through the soil. It is necessary for me to go back and spend from three to four days going over and sounding the shore area for the water system and also going into the matter of sewage disposal. I will do this as soon as the in-between season is over. In the meantime I arranged with the mechanic in charge of their water system that, in the event of the well going dry, he could hook up a typhoon pump of capacity 2500 gallons per hour to a gasoline driven unit and pump from the lake into the well as the occasion demands. They were fortunate in having two pumps, one for the water system from the well and a spare pump. This spare pump could be enclosed in a small shelter right on the ice and, providing the suction and discharge lines, as well as the pump itself, were drained after using, no difficulty should be encountered in pumping even in the cold weather.

"In the short time I was there I gathered that the installation of a well with a pipe line would be an extremely costly proposition as it will be necessary to go out approximately 500 feet in the lake to obtain any depth of water. In the meantime, however, I do not believe in the meantime any difficulty will be experienced."

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Memorandum for file:

Rev. C. F. Hives, Principal of Shingwauk Home, and who was Principal of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School until 1929, visited the Department today and I discussed with him the difficulties that we are experiencing at Lac la Ronge. He gave me the following information:

1. Mr. Hives states that there are very good pole fire escapes on the front of the Lac la Ronge school. He claims that the dormitory doors open directly on the upper verandah at either end of which brass poles lead to the ground. He further stated that when he was Principal it was found possible to empty the building within two minutes.

2. While he was Principal he installed a septic tank which he states worked perfectly. There was only a very small discharge from this tank. It should, of course, be cleaned out at regular intervals. Possibly this has not been done.

3. With regard to the water Mr. Hives felt that it would be inadvisable to attempt to run 500 feet of pipe into the lake. It would probably be a constant source of trouble. He believed that if more water was required it could be more easily obtained by drilling a well.

Dear Sir:

The Commission are in receipt of a letter from the Rev. G.W. Fisher, Principal of their Lac la Ronge School, in which he submits the following report:

"As far as the water supply is concerned matters are steadily getting worse, and it may be necessary before very long, to take the School team from hauling fuel wood, to bring water from the Lake for the laundry work, as it is now well-nigh impossible to obtain sufficient water from the usual source for this purpose. At the present time one may say without fear of contradiction, that save for the few chemical extinguishers in various parts of the building, this school is entirely without fire protection, for the well can be pumped dry in fifteen minutes, whereas it takes several hours for it to regain what can be pumped in that time. While our chimneys and roof are now reasonably safe, one would feel far happier if one could be assured an adequate supply of water for all purposes, including fire protection."

The Commission understand that a report has been forwarded, to your Department, through Mr. Indian Agent Davis and will be obliged if you can advise them if early action can be taken.

Yours faithfully,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Sewage Disposal and Water Supply Lac La Ronge Residential School

With reference to the above project, we are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Dempster in which he suggests that if it is at all possible to have a fire-pump and approximately 300 feet of canvas hose loaned to the School, water could be pumped from the Lake into the well on wash days or in case of fire. This in Mr. Dempster's opinion would alleviate the situation for the time being until a new water system could be put into effect.

Mr. Dempster further suggests that the Principal of the School should be advised to send in water samples for analyses as often as possible and it may be even necessary to treat the water to ensure safe drinking. In connection with this latter point, however, Mr. Dempster states that the treating of the water will be difficult with the present system, but that in the proposed new system provision would have to be made for chlorination.

We, of course, have no fire pumps or hose in this vicinity, but possibly the Indian Affairs Department could make some arrangement in this connection.

It is suggested that instructions to the Principal of the School with reference to taking samples of the water, as well as possible chlorination, could be issued by the medical service of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director, Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Sewage Disposal and Water Supply, Lac la Ronge Residential School.

I am in receipt of your memorandum of March 22 and I have noted Mr. Dempster's suggestion.

As you are no doubt aware this school is located approximately 300 miles from Prince Albert and I am not aware of any place where we could obtain the loan of a fire pump and approximately 300 feet of canvas hose as suggested by Mr. Dempster.

Dr. W. E. Burton
Commissioner
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir,

Sometime ago I made a complaint to the local RCMP officer here about the sewage, which is being disposed off daily right into La Lo Ronge, from your Departmental School here.

We had an inspector out here last fall but no further action, I believe, is being taken to remove this evil.

For your consideration I wish to tell you that we had one typhoid epidemic here 2 years or so ago.

As you probably know all sewage, at least a very big part of this, from your School here runs into the lake.

In the springtime, the stench is enough to knock a person over.

There are many ladies on the staff and their bath water together with the bath water of some 40 grown up girls running into the lake, does not make the water very nice.
to drink and it is absolutely against the law to provide water.

How much longer is the village of Lac la Ronge, together with the travelers who come here for a visit, being subjected to this very great danger?

We have no doctor here and if an epidemic breaks out, no money to get out.

Will you please consider this:

There is no room for all Indian children in your school here and about 60 children (non-treaty) are not getting an education for lack of a school.

I believe that in these hard times, the Dominion and Provincial governments may well cooperate with each other and make a public school of your Indian School. Then all our children could get an education and no sewer disposal would run into the lake any longer.

I shall be pleased to give you more detail if you desire this.

Yours truly,

Albert Vander-Kraft

P.S. The water here was condemned by Regina several times.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

With reference to the water supply and sewage disposal systems at the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential Schools, attached hereto are copies of a report, in duplicate, and plans submitted by Mr. Lazorka.

The suggested alterations to the water supply appear to be adequate and comprise a 4 inch connection from the lake to the present well, construction of a pump house and removal of the present pumping unit from the school to the new pump house and the installation of a chlorination unit. The estimated cost of these improvements is about $5,700.00. However, these alterations will have to stand over until next season as equipment to excavate the trench in the lake bottom will not be available until then and it is not clear that funds have been provided in this year's vote. No water shortage should occur next winter as the school has been authorized to retain the fire pump and hose loaned by the National Parks Bureau until next spring.

The sewage disposal scheme has been discussed with the engineers of the Health Department who made certain suggestions including the elimination to the screen chamber as being unnecessary, substitution of one 4 inch syphon for the two 3 inch syphons shown on the plan and a reduction in the size of the septic tank, together with the use of reinforced instead of plain concrete. These suggestions will be taken up with Mr. Lazorka and if adopted will result in some reduction in the cost which was estimated to be about $3,800.00.

Kitchen and laundry waste will be disposed of through a drain to a swamp lying north of the school at an estimated cost of about $1,600.00.

These projects will also have to stand over until funds have been provided for their construction.

REPORT ON:
WATER SUPPLY AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS,
LAG LA RONGE, INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The above school was visited on July 7th-10th and an inspection carried out together with the necessary surveys. I have prepared plans, compiled from information obtained, and am enclosing blueprints of these in conjunction with this report. The condition of the water supply and sewage disposal systems, at the time of my visit are summarized below:

PRESENT WATER SUPPLY.

General:

Water is pumped from a well located 186 feet away from the school by a Fairbanks Morse, 2,500 g.p.h. self-piling typhoon pump, driven by a 3 H.P. Fairbanks Morse gasoline engine. The pumping unit is located in the basement of the school. Water is pumped into two pressure tanks, each of approximately 660 gallons capacity, to a maximum pressure of 60 pounds per square inch, from where it is distributed throughout the school.

Source of Supply:

The supply well is 18 feet deep, dug to solid rock. At the time of inspection there was 10 feet of water in the well. From levels obtained, the water level in the well was 3 feet above the Lake level, the latter being 83 feet away. In view of this fact it is evident that the source of supply is from springs and underground flow and not by infiltration from the Lake.

I was informed that the supply was adequate this year, during the summer months, but that there was a shortage during winter months, as experienced in the past, due to the drop of water level in the well. The demand is far more important during the winter months, as the water consumption is greatest then, being 2,500 gallons daily on wash days; and the fire-hazard being at the maximum. The school, when occupied during fall, winter and spring has 125 occupants.

From the above observations it is imperative that the lake be considered as a source of water supply, and proper water works constructed to bring water from the lake into the well, to assure an adequate supply at all times. A proposed scheme will be dealt with, in detail, later.

Quality---
Quality of Water Supply.

I was informed by the principal of the school, Reverend G. W. Fisher that several samples of water were sent in for analysis, in 1936; but copies of these reports could not be located at the time. I asked him to have samples again taken this year, and supply me with copies. I have received these and am attaching copies, hereto. The sample from the well shows no B. Coli contamination, whereas the two samples of lake water show contamination.

Even though, the sample from the well shows no B. Coli contamination, as per attached report, I was advised by Reverend Fisher that last year contamination had been reported.

Probable Source of Contamination.

In view of the fact that the sewage flowing out of the Septic Tank follows a rock filled ditch, as shall be dealt with in more detail later, on the sewer system no doubt some of it seeps down and may be carried by underground flow into the well. Due to this fact, therefore, that there is a possibility of the water supply becoming contaminated by underground flow, or when the lake water is used for an additional supply, which shows contamination along the shore, even some distance away from the present sewer outfall, I would recommend installing a chlorinator for the purpose of treating the water supply.

PRESENT SEWER SYSTEM.

The sewage from the school and the principals residence is discharged into a septic tank, 12 feet x 9 feet x 11 feet deep. This tank is divided into two compartments 6 feet long, each; one being a syphon chamber. The sewage is discharged from the syphon chamber into a pipe line, towards the lake. It was informed that only four lengths of soil pipe were laid leading out of the septic tank and the remainder of the discharge line into the lake was a 4 inch wooden box laid in a rock filled ditch. The wood box pipe has now rotted and the rock filled ditch serves the purpose of carrying away the effluent into the lake.

A separate 4 inch discharge line from the laundry and kitchen was originally constructed, joining the rock filled ditch carrying the sewage, some distance down towards the lake. However this line became blocked in October, 1937, and the laundry and kitchen wastes were diverted into the sewer pipes, in the school basement, and passed through the septic tank, together with the sewage. This is still being done, at present.

This-----
This however, is a poor arrangement, as the laundry wastes should not be admitted into the septic tank. Furthermore this tank is located too high, and also due to its inadequate size, does not permit a long enough retention period for the sewage. The sewage is therefore discharged out of the septic tank, shortly after entering it.

In order to improve the sewage system, the present septic tank will have to be abandoned, and a new one together with a disposal field constructed.

PROPOSED WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM.

At present the pumping unit is located in the basement of the school. This arrangement is very poor, as in case of a fire there would be no access to the pump. Furthermore this pumping unit being gasoline driven, and gasoline kept in a drum in the basement of this school increases the fire hazard. I would therefore recommend building a pump house over the present well, and moving the pumping unit to this location. In case of a fire, the pump could be operated as necessary to keep the pressure up in the pipelines for fire protection.

Since the water supply is not adequate at certain times of the year as was pointed out, a pipeline will have to be laid into the lake, as shown on the enclosed plan, to ensure sufficient water at all times.

I wish to point out at this stage, that the laying of the pipeline into the lake may present a problem. Since the lake bottom and the shoreline is underlain with huge rocks, driving a cofferdam, in order to excavate deep enough for the pipeline, is out of the question. I believe excavation between the well to reasonably close to the shoreline may be done by ordinary methods. However from there to stn. 4 plus 00 as shown on the plan would have to be excavated by a dragline.

A dragline, owned by the Brooks Construction Company, Prince Albert, is now being used on the new road construction from Montreal Lake to Lac La Ronge. This dragline however, would not be available much earlier than the fall of 1946. By the present progress made on this road, it does not appear that the Lac La Ronge end would be reached till then. To bring in equipment other than this would be prohibitive as winter trails are passable. Then again no firm would bring their equipment in over the winter trails (when such freighting is possible) just for such a small job. It would therefore appear that the most economical method to do this excavation will be with this dragline, used on road construction, at such a time when it will be available.

In-----
In view of the fact that water samples have shown contamination, it will be necessary to install a chlorinator to ensure a safe water supply.

PROPOSED SEWER SYSTEM

The present sewer system is in poor condition, being unsanitary as well as inadequate. The septic tank does not permit a long enough retention period, as pointed out before and the sewage passing into the ditch and eventually into the lake is practically raw. A new system will therefore be constructed.

The present discharge lines from the school and principal's residence will be diverted around the existing septic tank into the manhole. A new septic tank, located below the present one will receive sewage from a manhole as shown on the plan. The sewage after being discharged by the syphons, which are designed for 90 gallons per minute, will be distributed throughout the disposal field.

PROPOSED LAUNDRY AND KITCHEN DRAIN

In order to dispose of the laundry and kitchen wastes, it will be possible to discharge these by a pipeline into a swamp along line "B" as indicated on the general plan.

The following is an estimated cost of the proposed laundry and kitchen drain:

Conclusion:

In conclusion I would say that any freighting in connection with this project, as bringing in materials, would have to be done during the winter, as no roads are passable in summer, and the new highway under construction would not be opened to public use for a few years. In view of the fact that the Lac La Ronge area has been set aside as a provincial Park by Saskatchewan, makes it all the more necessary to have the sewer system, in particular, sanitary, as objections to the present system would, no doubt, be stronger in the future.

Dear Sir:

As you are aware, several times during the past three years the matter of providing a constant and adequate supply of water for this school has been taken up with the Indian Department, and so far, nothing definite has been done in the matter.

While for most of the year our well has given us enough for our daily needs, for several months each winter since March 1937, we have had difficulty in obtaining sufficient water, particularly on wash-days. It also means we have no reserve for fire protection. For the past month we have been working under such conditions. To-day I had to have the boys carry water from the lake in order to wash the dishes after the noon-day meal.

It is true that the Department made arrangements with the Dominion Parks Branch to loan an engine and pump, (of the fire-fighting type) so that we might pump water from the lake into the well, but we cannot use it in sub-zero weather.

Mr. Indian Agent Davis was here several weeks ago, and I reported the matter to him, and he promised to ask the Department to supply sufficient 2" pipe to carry a suggestion by which we could use our spare pump for pumping water from the lake into the well. So far, I have had no further word from him.

Last July, Mr. Lazorka, an engineer sent in by the Department, made a complete survey of our sewage and water systems, and of course, reported to the Department. I am wondering whether it is the intention of the Department to do anything to remedy the situation during the coming summer?
Without financial backing from the Department, I feel it is impossible for us to do very much. In 1937, the sum of $150.00 was given us for deepening the well. We did the best we could, and were able to go down several feet deeper, but further digging was impossible when we reached bed rock. We tried dynamiting but without any success. Do you think it would be possible to persuade the Department to send in a well-boring outfit, and either deepen our present well, or give us an entirely new one?

I shall be glad if you will write to the Department regarding this matter, so that we may know whether we may expect anything to be done during the coming summer.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) G.W. Fisher,
Principal.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re - Fire pump and hose loaned to Lac La Ronge Indian School.

You will recall that, last summer, we arranged for the loan of fire pump and hose from Prince Albert National Park to the above school in connection with an emergency water supply. By arrangement with the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch the loan of this equipment was extended over the winter months. Towards the end of April last, in view of the serious forest fire hazard in Prince Albert National Park, this equipment was recalled.

On the receipt of the equipment by the Park Superintendent, he reported that it was in very poor condition and that considerable repairs were necessary before it could be operated. When the pump was loaned early the summer of 1939, it was on the understanding that it would be returned in first class condition.

The National Parks Bureau have now had the pump repaired and have submitted two accounts covering repairs in the amounts of $49.08 and $20.25. The Director of the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch has asked if we could arrange payment of these accounts by the Indian Affairs Branch, in accordance with the understanding when the pump was loaned. The accounts are enclosed herewith and I would be glad if you would give consideration to paying them.

Director.
Ottawa, June 25, 1940.

Dear Sir:

The Department has been requested to pay an amount of $69.33 for repairs to the fire pump and hose loaned to the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School by the authorities of the Prince Albert National Park.

We are advised that when the equipment was returned to the Park Superintendent it was in very poor condition and that these repairs were necessary before it could be operated. It was stated further that when the pump was loaned to the school, early in the summer of 1938, it was on the understanding that it would be returned in first class condition.

In a letter dated February 26, 1940, addressed to the Secretary of the M. S. C. C., the Principal of the Lac la Ronge Residential School wrote in part as follows:

"It is true that the Department made arrangements with the Dominion Parks Branch to loan an engine and pump, of the fire-fighting type, so that we might pump water from the lake into the well, but we cannot use it in sub-zero weather".

It would appear from the above that the pump was not used to any great extent, and if it was properly stored, it is difficult to understand why its condition should have deteriorated to the extent of requiring repairs -

Mr. R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent,
L e a s k, Sask.

Dear Sir,

I have received the copy of your letter of June 25th, addressed to Mr. R. S. Davis, Leask, Sask., with reference to the pump and hose loaned to this school by the authorities of the Prince Albert National Park.

After its arrival at the school the care of this pump was turned over to the care of the School Engineer, and I personally had nothing to do with the handling of it. As far as I remember, until last winter when we tried to pump water into the school well from the lake, the pump was used but twice, when I gave permission for its use to extinguish two bush fires, which started up within a quarter of a mile from the school, and which at the time appeared to be a menace to the school property.

At the beginning of November after running for a short time, the pump broke down, and on November 20th, I wrote to the Superintendent of the Prince Albert National Parks, sending him the parts which were broken. He at once replied, sending at the same time the necessary repairs, which our Engineer installed. After this, so far as I know, the engine and pump worked all right, save as indicated in the brief report attached. The only thing I can suggest is that more damage was done when the pump broke down in November than was thought at the time.

I am sorry that this pump needed so many repairs; for I thought when it left here it was in good condition.

I am,

Rev. G. W. Fisher, Principal, Indian Residential School, Lac la Ronge, Sask., visited the Department on July 29 and we discussed the water situation at the school.

Mr. Fisher pointed out that at the present time the water level in the lake is at the lowest point that it has ever reached. As a consequence it was necessary to extend the pipe line. The necessary pipe for this purpose was supplied by this Branch early in the spring and has been installed.

Mr. Fisher understood that owing to present conditions it was impossible for the Department to consider the expenditure that would be necessary to carry out the proposal outlined in the report submitted by the engineer some months ago. However, Mr. Fisher stated that a coffer-dam to protect the pipe line would be of material assistance and he stated that if he could be allowed an amount of $250.00 for labour he felt that he could make a suitable installation. As this amount of money was still available in our appropriation from the amount provided in the current year's estimates for the Lac la Ronge School official letter of July 30 was forwarded to him.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of July 30th, 1940, I have the honour to submit Return of Labour in connection with Water Supply System at the Lac la Ronge School, for which a grant not exceeding $250.00 was made.

On my return home after my visit to Ottawa last summer, I at once went over the whole situation and found that as the Lake level had fallen considerably during the time I had been away, and was still falling, it would not be possible to erect a coffer dam within the limits of the money allowed, and with the materials available. So I decided to dig a new well near the lake shore. I trust the Department will approve my action in this matter.

I am glad to say, that while we could dig the well as deep as I would have liked to do, owing the fact that we struck bed rock at a depth of about ten feet, we have a well which at present is yielding an adequate supply of water. I am hoping the question of supplying water for the school has been solved.

The total cost of labour amounted to $156.00. I personally advanced this sum, and I shall be glad to have the Department's cheque for this amount at the earliest convenience.

I am enclosing a rough sketch of the work done. I believe the well and pipe line is adequately protected against frost and there should be no difficulty on this score. But it will be necessary, in order to make the work permanent, to build a concrete wall on the outside of the mill-slab wall filled with shavings and earth, in order that it may not be washed away when the Lake returns to its former level. I am wondering whether
the Department will allow me to use the balance of the grant already made, amounting to $96.00 for this purpose. My understanding is that the grant was made for labour only, and since to carry out the additional work will involve expenditure for cement, I would ask for authority to buy the necessary cement, which can be shipped in during the coming winter for use in the Spring.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:-

Re: Lac la Ronge C. of E.
Indian Residential School

I have just received a Departmental letter dated August 14, 1941, No. 131-2-5, embodying part of a special report on our Lac la Ronge School which had been forwarded by Mr. Indian Agent Davis, and in which he makes special reference to (a) the lack of proper fire escapes, and (b) the need of more organized sport and vocational training.

Re the fire escapes, I note the following item in the list of requirements submitted to your Department on Oct. 3, 1936:-

"(E) Fire Escapes. Only sliding poles are in use at present, and the Principal fears that in sub-zero weather these might not serve the purpose for which they were intended. He suggests that chutes or some better system be provided."

With regard to the Indian Agent's statement that the main school building, in his opinion, "is nothing more or less than a fire trap", I would point out that a new chimney from the furnaces was built in 1933, and when I visited this School in June, 1934, I was able to report that I considered "the workmanship expert".

At that time I thought that the chimney from the Laundry was unsafe, and gave instructions for a new one to be built at once. In this way we endeavoured to eliminate danger from fire from these sources.

I found that only a gong was being used as a fire alarm, and since then an electric fire alarm system has been installed. This School, as you may know, has sliding poles for fire escapes, and when I sounded the fire alarm the School was cleared in 3 minutes.
This School was again visited by the Commission's Assistant Secretary-Treasurer, Colonel Mermagen, in 1935, and when he sounded the fire alarm early one morning, without giving any previous notice except to the Principal, he found that the School was cleared in approximately one minute. He refers in his report on this visit to suggestions he had made re the catch on the door leading to the verandah, where the poles are installed; re wiping the poles from time to time with rags soaked in coal oil so as to prevent rust, and re the arrangement of the clothing which each child should pick up when the alarm sounded, etc.

In the list of requirements submitted on Oct. 2, 1940, I find the following items included for this School:

(a) 2 - 50 ft. lengths of 1½" Underwriter's Fire Hose (canvas) complete with couplings 1½" thread ...... $14.00

(b) 2 only Pump type Pyrene Fire Extinguishers, 1 quart size ...................... 65.00

(c) 2 only "Guardane" Fire Extinguishers, 2½ gals..... 80.00 (?)

$ 159.00

From this it is quite clear that our Commission has taken all the steps within their power to secure the safety of this building from fire, and I was surprised to find, in Departmental letter, Aug. 12, 1941, No. 150-53, that no provision is being made for a Night Watchman's services in this and six of our other Schools this year. I have already directed Dr. McGill's attention to this omission.

With regard to the other items, namely organized sport and vocational training, anyone who has ever visited at Lac la Ronge and noted the rocky nature of the spot on which the School stands, and of the surrounding area, will realize how difficult it is to secure suitable playing fields.

For some years our Commission has recommended to your Department that buildings or space be set aside for vocational training, but so far no such facilities have been supplied. There is a saw and planing mill at Lac la Ronge, and this has been used to some extent I know, but cannot say whether full use has been made of it or not. I can assure you that our Commission and our Society keenly desire to cooperate with your Department in the matter of vocational training, but the heavy cuts made in our grants from 1932 and continued for several years, with a resultant loss to us in per capita grants of approximately $142,000.00, and your Department's decision last year to reduce the pupilage to 92.24%, have made it absolutely impossible for us to undertake many of the repairs and improvements we heartily desire.

I note that a letter has been sent direct to the Principal advising him that the sum of $700. will be available during the current fiscal year for repairs and improvements and I am asking him to furnish me with a copy of his reply.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

With further reference to your letter of August 14th., #132-2-5, and my reply to same of August 28th., with reference to providing additional fire escapes at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, in this connection I would make the following recommendations:

(1) That the sliding poles at present in use be allowed to remain in their present positions.

(2) That metal fire escapes of the stair type be provided for the lower Boys' and Girls' Dormitories. I am enclosing a rough sketch of the positions of the windows. Both ends of the building are identical, and in providing the necessary escapes, the difference would be that one would require a right hand, and the other a left hand railing.

(3) Re. the upper (attic) dormitory occupied by the senior girls, I would recommend that an escape of wooden construction be renewed, on a rather different plan. I am not submitting a plan for this, as I have found it difficult to draw a plan which will show exactly what I think is required. But I feel sure that I could have constructed an efficient and safe escape (as far as wooden construction can be made safe) for the sum of $60.00. If the Department will authorise the expenditure of this amount for the purpose mentioned, construction could be begun at once.

As I do not know the cost of the metal fire escapes, it will not be possible for me to make suggestions as to the use that can be made of the balance of the $700.00 allotted to this school, until the cost of escapes is determined.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In your letter of June 30th last #160-2, you informed me that the sum of $700.00 was available during the current fiscal year for repairs and equipment at our Lac la Ronge School. In a letter received this morning from the Reverend Principal Fisher, and written on the 17th inst., he states that you have already forwarded to him an accountable cheque for $200.00 for the building of fire escapes. It would appear from his letter that shipment of the material required for those fire escapes could not be secured last Fall, and consequently they are not completed. He intimates that he may not be able to complete them properly until the warmer weather comes, and as the work will be done without further labor costs he will be able to make an accounting to you of that $200.00 before the end of March.

With the balance of the $700.00 grant, namely $500.00, he desires to purchase the items given on the enclosed list.

As it is expected that your Purchasing Branch will place the order for the various items, I beg to suggest that an exception be made in the case of the fir flooring, and that the Reverend Principal Fisher be allowed to place an order for this with the North Star Lumber Company of Prince Albert. It appears that this Company when filling an order for Stanley, which is further north than Lac la Ronge, sent a thousand feet of lumber flooring more than was required, and they have offered to deliver this flooring to Lac la Ronge at Prince Albert price.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

I have received your letter of April 4th, and am surprised to learn that the cheque for $60.15 sent to you on March 27th, has not been received.

I have looked up the stub of my cheque book, and find that I issued a cheque made out to the "Receiver General Ottawa," on the above mentioned date. I am writing to my bank about the matter, to find out if per chance it has been received by them. Should neither the Department nor the Bank be able to trace it within a reasonable time, I shall be only too glad to issue a duplicate cheque.

Dear Sir,

I regret that I have been unable to send you an accounting for the cheque received for the erection of additional fire-escapes at this school, until this late date.

The delay was caused chiefly by the failure of certain materials, ordered last fall, and for which arrangements had been made for immediate delivery, not arriving until a few weeks ago. Then, when delivery was made, it was found that a mistake had been made in the number of door-casings shipped, making it necessary to order an additional one.

I have also had difficulty in obtaining bills for freighting of materials from the Brook's Transportation Co., I had to write twice asking for it. The bill finally came on March 19th, whereupon I immediately mailed a cheque for the amount due, but owing to faulty mail service my cheque is still lying in the local post office.

The earliest I can expect to receive the receipted bills is April 2nd. This being the case I am forwarding a statement minus this receipt - shown under date of March 20th. It will be sent immediately I receive it.

I trust this will be satisfactory to the Department.

Enclosed find cheque for balance due to the Department amounting to $60.03

I am,
Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

I have before me your letter of June 19th, advising me that a grant of $650.00 has been made to this school for repairs during the current fiscal year.

While there are quite a number of things for which this amount could be expended, the most urgent need would appear to be a new set of batteries for our lighting plant.

I have obtained from the Exide Batteries of Canada Ltd., Montreal, the following price quotation for a set of batteries of the same type as those at present in use at this school:

"32 - type EOS-13 plate Exide Cells, in glass jars with glass covers, assembled sealed and charged, ready for use, complete, including W-2-F hydrometer syringe........................................$698.58
8% Dominion Sales Tax..................$55.89

Net to the Department of Indian Affairs, f.o.b. our Toronto factory.............................$754.47

Shipping weight approximately 3070 lbs.

Capacity 240 Amp. hrs. at the 8 hr. rate to 1.75 w. per cell.

Shipment approximately four months after receipt of order.

As we are so far from a railway centre, it would not appear possible there could any saving in shipping out the old batteries for credit.

The batteries now in use were installed during the Spring
of 1936, and while they are now hard to keep charged, will no doubt give service until the middle of the coming winter; by which time we trust the new ones will have been received.

It will be noted that the cost of the batteries asked for more than takes up the grant made for total repairs and replacements during the present year. It is hoped that the Department will make an additional grant for the purpose of providing the equipment so much needed.

In addition to the cost of the batteries, the freight charges from Toronto to Lac la Ronge are estimated at $139.50.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

Principal.

I hereby submit a report covering Annuity Payment on the Northern Reserves of the Carlton Agency.

The Lac La Ronge Residential School was thoroughly inspected. The building is not the least modern. Fire escapes are placed at what I consider the most strategic points but fire alarms and equipment are neither new nor modern. However, when tested were found to work satisfactorily. Fire drill is well carried out. During the past year the school was understaffed, but I consider the results obtained in spite of the handicaps are as good as elsewhere. Dear Sir,

I have received a letter from Dr. Alderwood telling me that in a letter dated September 25th, 1944 #150-53 from the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, provision has been made for the payment of a grant for the Night-watchman at this school for five months at the rate of $35.00 per month.

At the present time wages for labour of any kind is quite high at Lac La Ronge, chiefly because of the higher prices paid for fur and fish. Unskilled labourers ask for at least $3.50 per day. Last year our Night Watchman received $40.00 per month with board and lodging. This year he is asking to be paid at the rate of $2.00 per night. He is on duty from 6.00 p.m. to 6.00 a.m. He is thoroughly reliable, and I know of no one else who will fill the position as well.

Last year, through your recommendation, the Department increased the monthly grant to $40.00 per month, and I am wondering whether you could arrange for a similar or larger increase for the coming winter. If you are able to do this, it will be very much appreciated.

With kind regards,
Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Jones,

With kind regards,

Mr. E. S. Jones, Indian Agent, Leask, Sask.

I am returning, unpaid, your voucher No. 524.

However, provision was made in the current year's appropriation for an amount of $40.00 a month only for the winter of 1944-45, and this is the average amount allowed to other Indian residential schools. It is considered a fair allowance towards the cost of employing a night watchman. Any amount required above this will have to be provided by the school concerned. Philip Phelan,

Dear Mr. Bryce:

You will remember that when you were here at Treaty time, I pointed out to you that I found it very hard to use the grants given each year by the Department for equipment and repairs to the best advantage, due to the fact that such grants have to be used before March 31st, of the fiscal in which they are granted; whereas, in the matter of actual repair work, such as the laying of floors, painting, etc., it is best to do the work during the summer vacation, when most of the children are away for their holidays. At that time of the year it is not known just what grant will be available.

With the grant made last year, I endeavoured to buy things I thought were necessary for the improvement of the school, but much to my regret, some of the things were evidently unobtainable, or in some cases things costing much less than those asked for were substituted, with the result that during the year 1944-45, this school did not get the benefit of the full grant made.

Since the First of June, mostly, since school closed for the holidays, we have been doing a considerable amount of work on the school, laying new floors and painting. I have had several men engaged, and have or will be paying out the following sums of money for wages:

To - A. VanderKracht .................. $41.30
" - H. Hegland ......................... 96.60
" - H. Charles ......................... 60.00
" - N. Irving ......................... 20.00

$217.90

On April 19th, I paid to A. VanderKracht the sum of $91.12
on account wages for labour - repairs on school, making a total $309.02 during the present year.

If it had been permissible to have retained some of last year's grant after March 31st, part of these labours costs could have been met out of the 1944-45 grant. These costs are at present being borne our regular per capita grants, which we can ill afford to do, and for this reason I write to ask whether you will recommend that a special grant for labour of at least $250.00, and if possible of $300.00 be made by the Department for immediate use in covering some of the costs already incurred, and of those necessary to put the school in a better state of repair.

In addition to the amounts already expended, it will be necessary to spend at least $50.00 in order to put our heating system in a good state of repair before the coming winter.

If the Department could send me an accountable cheque for $250.00 to $300.00, I shall be pleased to send vouchers showing the manner in which the money is expended.

In the course of a few days I shall be sending you the usual list of requirements from the Department for this school for the fiscal year 1945-46.

Trusting you may be able to persuade the Department of the necessity of providing additional help in putting our building a better state of repair,

I am,
Yours faithfully,
[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have your letter of the 21st instant in connection with the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. Bell sounds knell as school burned

By MARY GARDINER
PRINCE ALBERT, Feb. 5 (Special).—As the All Saints' Indian residential school at Lac La Ronge went up in flames Sunday afternoon the toppling belfry sounded its last peal. The fire broke into clear peals before crashing into the inferno below.

Outpost residents stood huddled in helpless groups unable to take any steps against the fire swiftly eating its way through the building which had been a landmark since 1920 in this 167-year-old community.

Within an hour and a half the school had crashed to the ground and the only remnant of the huge three-storey frame structure was a pile of rubble smouldering in the frosty northern twilight.

The fire is reported to have started in the basement under the boys' playroom near one of the furnaces. When it was discovered alarms were quickly sounded throughout the building and all the children, 61 girls and 38 boys, were moved to safety in the Anglican church nearby.

None of the children's belongings were saved although a few personal effects of Miss E. Graham, senior room teacher, were removed before the fire had gained much headway.

Supplies
Provincial government and M. and C. Aviation company planes left Prince Albert Monday carrying provisions and clothing.

Aboard one of the aircraft was Dr. J. M. Morrow, medical superintendent of the federal department of Indian affairs for northern Saskatchewan. Lac La Ronge is 170 miles north of Prince Albert.

Rev. W. C. Wickenden, principal of the school, and Amy Hastings, the school engineer, attempted to use fire extinguishers and one of the pumps against the blaze. However, the flames speedily gained headway and were soon beyond all control.

Staff members who lost all their possessions were Miss B. Williams, matron for the past 10 years; Miss MacKenzie, junior room teacher; Miss Hailstead, sewing room supervisor; Miss C. Foulds, kitchen supervisor; Miss L. McKenzie, assistant kitchen supervisor; W. Finlayson, night watchman, and A. Hastings, engineer.

Relatives and friends speedily took the children into their homes where they will remain until parents come to claim them.

Already local officials in charge of the drive to collect money and clothing for the victims of Saturday's disastrous St. Patrick's orphanage fire in Prince Albert, have offered clothing for use by the La Ronge children.
February 18th, 1947.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.
Director-Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Ontario.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Thank you for your letter of February 14th. I have been anxiously awaiting some definite word concerning the rebuilding of our School which was destroyed by fire at Lac la Ronge. I have not yet recovered from the shock or heartbreak of losing this school, for I know what a definite loss it is to our Indians in the North. I think I know these Indian bands of the North very well as I have spent considerable time amongst them. They are among the finest Indians to be found anywhere in Canada. For the most part they are living the life which they love and which was the life of their forefathers. They are hunters and trappers, travelling by dogs in winter and by canoes in summer. They never have been farmers and they never can be farmers because of the country in which they live; they live amid the lakes and rivers and trees and rocks.

I do hope therefore, that it is the intention of the Government to rebuild this Northern school this year. I only wish I could talk this matter over with you and the other officials concerned because I think I have information that would be of use to you. I am very much afraid that if something is not done immediately by the Federal Government that we shall lose precious ground in the educating of these Indian children and in preparing them for the days that lie ahead.

I was at Montreal Lake yesterday. I only wish you could have been with me. Our teacher there, Mr. Waite, with his efficient wife, is doing a magnificent job, and that under conditions, that in my estimation, are deplorable; but I am sure that both Inspector Ostrander and Indian Agent Jones have told you of the condition of his house and also of the school.

Again assuring you of my keen desire to see some immediate action for the replacement of this school; and with kindest personal regards,

I am,

Sincerely yours

Four boxes of supplies were shipped by the Red Cross today to relieve the situation at La Ronge where children and staff of an Indian residential school lost all their possessions when the school burned to the ground last Friday.

The boxes were shipped by transport truck and are expected to arrive at La Ronge sometime over the weekend. Included in the shipment are blankets, quilted socks, mitts, sweaters, jackets, underclothing, pajamas and miscellaneous items.

Mrs. C. S. Nance, secretary of the Prince Albert branch, Canadian Red Cross, said the supplies sent to La Ronge were shipped in from Regina for orphanage survivors. My dear Mr. Hoey:

I arrived back in my office this morning after being away for the last six days visiting Red Earth and Shoal Lake Reserves in this Province. As you can imagine, the going was pretty strenuous owing to our very severe winter this year.

I was sadly disappointed and almost discouraged when I read your letter in which you regret to inform me that there is little possibility of replacing the Lac la Ronge School within the next two years.

I do hope this is not a final decision. I wish it were possible for me to talk with you face to face, and also the minister, because I think I could put facts before you that would assist you in coming to a decision that would call for an immediate rebuilding of this school. I am greatly concerned about this whole matter and it is most discouraging when, upon occasion after occasion, one is faced with nothing but frustration and inability to carry forward work that is so necessary; owing to lack of equipment.

Every person I have met here in the North since the destruction of the Lac la Ronge School takes it for granted that the Government will immediately rebuild. I shall hesitate to inform them that there is no likelihood of any such rebuilding within the next two years, because of their surprise and disappointment.

Again expressing my regret, and also the fact that I cannot talk the matter over with you personally,

I am,

Faithfully yours,
