Dear Mr. Jones:

I have just received your letter of the 25th ult., and in response to your request for a written report to amplify the verbal one I made to Dr. J. M. Morrow on Feb. 3rd, the day following the fire at All Saints Indian Residential School, Lac La Ronge, now submit the following statement.

The fire broke out at 1.00 p.m. Sunday, February 2nd when I was at the foot of the steps leading from the boys' playroom to the basement. A boy, who was in the vicinity for the furnace nearby, gave the alarm and I noticed that a hot air pipe emerging from the furnace was glowing red, and that the wooden boxing of cold air rent overhead was aflame. This air flue ran across the floor joists and led to the cold air register box in the centre of the boys' playroom. I may say incidentally that Mr. Hastings, our engineer, said subsequently that he had not yet fired up at that particular furnace, but had found it shortly before reduced to a bed of glowing embers and had gone in search of his ash raker to the far end of the basement. He was, therefore, suspicious that some boy or boys through carelessness or foolishness had had something to do with the origin of the fire in the hot air pipe.

Boys got large pans which were handy in the basement and tried to dampen the flames with water. Mr. Hastings was sitting by the pump engine at the time, waiting, presumably until his usual time for starting the pump. A water hose was kept hanging near that particular furnace, and I told Mr. Hastings to get it into action. Meantime I ran upstairs for the big fire extinguisher and by the time I got down he had opened the adjacent workshop and had the hose ready. One of the boys assisted Mr. Hastings operated the fire extinguisher and I assisted Mr. Hastings with the hose. Since there was hardly any force behind the water I told Mr. Hastings to get the pump working while I managed the hose. I may say that the previous night had been our coldest, 35 degrees below zero, and that our water pipes in the basement had been frozen. It was 10.00 A.M. before there was running water in the school, and at the time of the fire water pressure was abnormally low. The day was windy and bitterly cold, and, of course there was a strong draught along the cold air flue. This was lined with paper and the fire spread rapidly along it. We dampened the flames from below, creating stifling smoke in the process, but were unable to affect the fire within the ventilator and underneath the floor of the boys' playroom. Our engineer lost no time in getting the pump to work and there was an immediate increase in the volume and pressure of the water, but our efforts were unavailing against the flames once they had taken hold upon the old, dry timber of the school. In a few minutes after the alarm was first given, the basement was so thick with smoke that it was impossible to work there and I had to abandon all hope of checking the fire.

The fire alarms had been sounded immediately the fire was detected, and I found later that the building had been rapidly vacated. Mr. Finlayson, the nightwatchman, was the only person in bed and asleep at the time, but I noticed him outside when I myself left the basement by the stairs remote from the fire.
The matron had got a boy to go up the top floor after little Walter McKenzie, who was by himself in the comfort of the boys' supervisor's room undergoing a rest treatment for a burnt leg. All the children were warmly dressed in their Sunday overcoats, and some of them had their weekday ones also. After ordering the children into the Church in order that they might be counted I went back to the school to assure myself that everyone was out. By the time I was free to go back to the office to see if anything could be salvaged, the smoke was so dense and the flames threatening that it was not possible to rescue correspondence files and records except a few at hand by the veranda window. Helpers were not long in running to help, but with the exception of the lighting plant and portable things in the laundry very little was saved. Most of the furniture from the staff sitting-room was removed, and that from Miss Graham's room next door. That was all. Staff losses alone amounted to not less than two thousand dollars.

Fortunately none of the outbuildings was harmed, although the farm instructor's house was threatened. After reimbursing local traders who had supplied our children while they were being cared for by Lac La Ronge people I sold the bulk of our food stores. I should have said that within three hours of the outbreak of fire all our pupils were accommodated by local people, and that I had made arrangements with the storekeepers to provide them with staples. As you know Dr. Morrow and Bishop Martin flew in the next day to give assistance in the matter of food and clothing, and in making arrangements for the pupils to be returned to their homes.

It will not be possible for me to give you a complete list of the children who returned to their homes until my records arrive from Lac La Ronge, which ought to be soon. On the day of the fire there were 98 children enrolled. All were in residence with the exception of three boys who had been truant for some days: Thomas Roberts of Montreal Lake, who had gone to his mother, Mrs. Nancy LaFavor, on the 5th of January and had been missing ever since; Alex. Mirasty and Charles Roberts, both of Sucker River, who had gone home together on January 20, and had not been returned to school by their parents during the spell of severe weather.

By Tuesday, Feb. 4, pupils from Sucker River, Stanley and Pelican Narrows had been flown home, and to days later Dr. Morrow flew south with the Montreal Lake children. All these children had blankets or quilts and were given rations for several days. Provisions was also made for them to be supplied at their local stores until they were in the care of their own people. I may say that large supplies of clothing for emergency needs had come in from the Red Cross Prince Albert and from various church organizations by the time I left Lac La Ronge en route for Gordon's School, Punnichy on the 20th of February and more is on the way. The labour of distribution I left to our missionary, the Rev. S. Cuthand, who willingly offered his services. Bishop Martin is also giving his assistance in this matter.

As you know I was called away from the business of property disposal and our Administration appointed Mr. Spooner as agent. Before I left I made contracts to rent the Principal's residence and the fisherman's cottage on a monthly basis. I have already mentioned my disposal of food stores. Mr. Spooner was directed not to dispose of the paint sent in by the Department or any other stores which might be considered as the Department's property. I understand that the Superintendent of our Administration is looking into the question of ownership. There were considerable stocks of clothing, footwear, sealers, soap and school supplies, which I ordered to be transferred to Gordon's School.
In our conversation by telephone I gave you the names of pupils transferred to this school in care of Dr. Morrow.

Myles Charles of Stanley, son of Catherine Charles, deceased.
Minnie Mirasty
Demar Mirasty
Lydia Mirasty all of Lac La Ronge, children of Mrs. Percy (Betsy) Charles and Paul Mirasty deceased.
Willink Charles
Moses Charles
Ida Charles, all of Lac La Ronge, children of Mrs. Wm. (Norah) Irving and H. Stanley Charles deceased.
Kitchener Allan Bird, of Lac La Ronge, son of Peter Bird and Olive Bird, deceased.

David Charles, half brother of Myles Charles, aged 6 years was taken to Stanley, but since he is an orphan perhaps he should be brought to the school, like Myles, to be taken care of properly.

Peter Custer of Pelican Narrows was left at Lac La Ronge in care of Joseph Wilfred Ross. The latter inadvisedly took the boy on a trip to Little Hills so that he missed the plane which returned the Pelican Narrows children.

I trust the foregoing report will prove adequate, but shall be pleased to supply additional information if needed, subject to the limitations of records now at my disposal.

The tragic ending of our work at Lac La Ronge was mitigated by the fact that no lives were lost and that the building, admittedly, was overdue for replacement. Despite the present unfavourable trade conditions I hope, with our church in general and our Indian School administration in particular, that the day will not be long delayed for the resumption of our work with the Indian children of Northern Saskatchewan under more favourable conditions.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) D. C. Wickenden.
Carlton Agency.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Enclosed herewith is a copy of the report submitted to this office by Rev. Wickenden, now principal of the Gordon Indian Residential School, in connection with the fire that destroyed the Indian Residential School at Lac La Ronge.

On arriving at Lac La Ronge, Saturday, March 15th, last, I learned that the Officer in Charge of the R.C.M.P. Police at that point had carried out an investigation re: the cause of the fire. To date the Police report covering same has not been received at this office, but in view of the discoveries made by myself, I am satisfied the Police will have found that the responsibility of the fire rests on four boys who were pupils at the school. This matter will be the subject of another report when the Police report has been received.

The following equipment which I believe is the property of the Department was saved:
- The lighting plant complete including 10H.P. Diesel engine, generator, switch board and 32 batteries.
- A saw mill, complete with engine and planer.
- A large quantity of paint.
- 23 storm windows, 6 complete windows, less frames.

The lighting plant with the exception of the batteries has been placed in the warehouse. The batteries are in heated storage at the Saskatchewan Fish Filleting Plant at Lac La Ronge, arrangements have been made to have the batteries placed on their line for the occasional charge.

There were large quantities of food supplies and clothing in the warehouse which is intact, these supplies no doubt, will be the property of the Church Authorities.
The following buildings remain undamaged:

Principal's Residence; A two story frame house with basement 5 rooms and bathroom. The building is wired and sewage system is installed. This building is at present leased to Mr. McCabe an employee of the Provincial Government, by the Church Authorities.

The Warehouse; A two story building 18'x40', Lumber, 14' stud cement foundation, building is in good repair and half has been rented to the Saskatchewan Fish Filleting Plant by the Church Authorities.

The Ice House; 14'x16', 12' stud, galvanized roof, Lumber, building is built on rocks and is a good building.

The Oil House; 12'x14', Lumber, building is in good repair and is not built on a foundation.

Barn; 24'x28', Lumber, this building is in good repair and is built on a rock footing.

Cottage; 12'x14', Lumber, good repair, built on stone foundation.

Farming Instructor's Residence; 18'x20', Lumber, this building definitely does belong to Church Authorities.

The above is a complete list of buildings remaining on the site. I would point out, irrespective of ownership, all buildings would be or can be made suitable for the establishment of a Nursing Station at this point. The Department warehouse at this point is too small for our requirements and it will definitely be necessary that we have one of the buildings for an office so that I may have a roof over my head when at Lac La Ronge.

E. S. Jones,
Indian Agent.

In this connection also interviewed Cora (Mrs. R Sanderson who had boarded one of the children for a time after the fire. Mrs. Sanderson advised that she had boarded one John Roberts for about a week after the fire and that during the time this boy was with her he appeared very nervous and would not leave the place. After he had been sent to his home at Stanley this woman was told by her son that Roberts had stated that he had helped to set the fire and asked the boy not to say anything till after he had gone home. Apparently the boy told his mother of this but she did not see fit to report the matter. Following is statement taken from David Sanderson, son of Cora Sanderson noted above.

"I am David Sanderson, I state as follows: I attend the La Ronge Day School, don't go to the Mission. On the Sunday of the fire at the Mission my mother brought John Roberts home to stay with us till his folks came from Stanley for him. While he was at our place he told me that he had helped to set the fire along with Kitchener Bird and some other boys. He said that they poured some kerosene on the basement floor then set a match to it, after which they went down in the Settlement till the building was ablaze. He would not say what other boys were in on it too other than Kitchener Bird. He made me promise that I would not say anything till after he had gone home. As soon as he left I told my mother about it and I think she told the Minister." ends.

Enquiries reveal that John ROBERTS is now with his family who are trapping on Deception Lake, some distance north of Jonas HALKETT, noted in this report is at present with his family at Foster River and Burdock McKenzie is at Stanley. It is thought these boys will be interviewed in this connection as soon as possible.

Kitchener BIRD, was transferred to Gordon's School at or near Melfort, Sask. It is also understood that Mr. WICKENDEN, the former Principal of this school is now Principal at the Gordon...
I am Wilson Charles, I state as follows:- I was attending the Anglican Mission School at Lac La Ronge at the time of the fire; I have been attending the school for several years now. When the fire started on Sunday, Feb. 2, I was in the Principal's office being punished for not attending church. I was there for some time before the alarm was given.

On the previous Monday, January 27th, a fire was started in the basement by Kitchener Bird. This boy told me he took hot ashes out of the furnace and placed them under a pile of wood in the basement. This fire was discovered by the principal, I think, and was put out. Kitchener Bird told me that night that he had started that fire. Nothing was ever said around the school about that fire.

On Sunday night, Feb. 2nd, the night after the fire that destroyed the school, I was walking on the road with Kitchener Bird and we were talking about the big fire and he told me that he had set it. I didn't ask him much about it as I was too scared. I think he got some gasoline and started it behind one of the furnaces. I was alone with Kitchener at this time but I think that Jack Mirasty and Noah Bird knew that he set it. The time before when he was telling me that he started the fire under the wood pile I was with Burdock McKenzie. I do not know if there was any one else with Kitchener when he set the school on fire. This is all I know about this."

ENDS.

Noah Bird also interviewed but denied having any knowledge of this matter other than he had heard boys say the fire had been started by some of the boys. This boy was attending the Mission.

Jack Mirasty interviewed and closely questioned it this connection and following is his statement.

"I am Jack Mirasty of Lac La Ronge, I also attended the Anglican Mission here.

I was in the boys play room at the time of the fire. I saw Kitchener Bird, Jonas Halkett and some other boys run up from the basement on that Sunday (Feb. 2) and they said that the place was on fire, I do not know who the other boys were; I got scared when I saw the smoke coming up and beat it outside. I hear some of the boys talking that Kitchener set the fire. I think that Jonas was with him at the time." ENDS.

VERY POOR COPY
In the above connection I beg to report that on the 2-2-47, the Anglican Mission at this point was destroyed by fire. Since that time rumours have been circulated in the settlement to the effect that the fire had been set by some of the children. As the Principal, Mr. Nickenden, left this point a few days after the fire, writer interviewed Mr. D.E. Spooner, farm instructor at the Mission and advised him of the above. Spooner advised that he had also heard rumours to the effect that the fire had been started by the children, but that as he did not know what his position was now in regards to the school, whether he was in charge of the property etc., and also that he had been given to understand that the suspicions as to the origin of the fire had been reported to the Principal prior to his departure and in view of this he had not felt it his responsibility to make any complaint to the detachment. Mr. Spooner was unable to offer any information of value regarding the origin of the fire as he had been at home at the time and did not get back to the school till the blaze was well started and it was too late to attempt to put same out.

In view of the fact that the Principal and teachers have left this point and apparently there being no one here who cares to take any responsibility with regards to the Mission property it has been deemed to be expedient to invest light the cause of this blaze. Accordingly, Andrew Hastings, engineer, formerly employed by the above Mission was interviewed and he advised the writer to the effect that at the time of the fire he had been working in the basement and that a few minutes prior to the blaze he had seen several children run up the stairs from the basement, he was unable to give any idea as to who the children were but stated that as the blaze started shortly after, or was discovered shortly afterwards he was certain in his own mind that they had started same and was of the opinion that the fire could not have started near the furnace or from a faulty furnace as was stated. Hastings advised he had reported his suspicions to the Principal and had thus felt it not his responsibility to report the matter further.

As a result of enquiries made by writer in the settlement in this regard, writer interviewed Wilson Charles, who had been attending the Mission at the time of the fire. Following is a statement taken from this boy.

Lac La Ronge School Fire

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

We have received a Royal Canadian Mounted Police report dated March 7, 1947, which would indicate the possibility of arson in connection with the above fire. This report is a preliminary one and indicates that two juveniles, namely Kitchener Bird and John Roberts, may be responsible for this fire. As Kitchener Bird is now attending the Gordons School, we are writing to Mr. Ostrander concerning this report. I would appreciate an opportunity of discussing this situation with you and showing you the report, at your convenience.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Reverend Canon H.A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Superintendent,
Indian School Administration, M.S.C.C.,
102 Bank Street, Ottawa, Ontario.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

It has been disclosed that Kitchener Bird, one of the boys transferred from the Lac la Ronge School to the Gordon's School and referred to in this office letter of the 14th ultimo, File No. 214-303-11 ACE, is one of the boys implicated in the burning of the school.

I have not received the report of the R.C.M. Police since this boy was questioned on the 25th instant but I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend D.C. Wickenden, the Acting Principal of the Gordon's School, to the effect that he has admitted striking the match which started the fire on February 2nd.

Mr. Wickenden informs me in his letter that Kitchener Bird has settled down and appears contented at the Gordon's School, and he is very well behaved. Notwithstanding this fact it would be a mistake, I believe, to allow him to remain at the Gordon's School because he will no doubt be telling other boys of his escapade and be quite a hero amongst them. I would therefore recommend that he be returned to his home.

I understand that Mr. Wickenden has to return to Lac la Ronge shortly to complete some unfinished business in connection with the school and I think it would be advisable for the boy to be returned to Lac la Ronge at the same time and that he be discharged from the school.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

1. Adverting to the above, and to Lt. Col. Ronge Detachment report under date of the 7th instant, with forwarding minutes of the C.C., "F" Division C.I.R., Regina Sect., and Officer Commanding Yorkton Sub/Division appended thereto, on the P.M. of this date the writer patrolled via hired team Livery to the Gordon Indian Reserve and investigated in the above regard.

2. The Rev. D.G. PICKERDEN, former Principal of All Saints Indian Residential School, Lee Le Ronge, Sask., was interviewed and the following statement obtained:

"I, Rev. D.G. PICKERDEN, state as follows:
Just before 1:00 P.M. on February 2nd, 1947 I went to the boy's playroom, seeking a certain boy, one of four who had been troublesome to staff members during the morning. Not finding him there I went downstairs to the basement where I noticed two or three boys. This part of the basement was partitioned off and served as a washroom. I passed through the doorway on the north side and turned into the main part of the basement. Not seeing the boy I sought, I returned and was about to climb the stairs when a boy in the vicinity of the furnace nearby (in the north-west corner of the basement) yelled out to me: 'There's a fire!' I looked in his direction and noticed that a section of hot air pipe emerging from the furnace was red hot, and that a patch of the wooden boxing of the cold air vent fairly close overhead was aflame. This air flue ran between the floor joists and led to the cold air register box in the boy's senior classroom. The said hot air pipe led to the register box in the boys' playroom. Three or four big boys gathered and we ran to the centre of the basement where there were some large cans to the water taps. Mr. Andrew HASTINGS, the school engineer, was sitting there by the pump engine, and I told him to get water hose into action (this hose was kept hanging close to the furnace at the west end) while I ran off to get the large fire extinguisher upstairs. I had ordered the fire-alarms to be sounded, and when I came down with the fire extinguisher I gave it to Isaac BALLINTINE, one of big boys, to operate for a time while I helped Mr. HASTINGS with the hose. Subsequently, when I was discussing the origin of the fire with our engineer, Mr. HASTINGS declared positively that he had not yet fired up at that particular furnace. He had found it not long before the fire alarm was given reduced to a bed of glowing embers, and had gone to the far end of the basement in search of his ash rake. At the time of the outbreak of fire he had tended the other furnaces only. He was, therefore, suspicious."

3. Kitchener A. BIRD, mentioned in Lee La Ronge Detachment report was also interviewed and the following statement obtained:

"I, Kitchener Alan BIRD, Treaty Indian aged 12 years, state as follows, I am the son of Peter BIRD of the James ROBERTS band of Lee La Ronge, Saskatchewen.

I have been attending the Lee La Ronge Indian school since 1944. I'm in the 2nd grade. I slept in the main dormitory with all the other boys. During the winter months there has been quite a lot of talk about burning the school down by the boys in the dormitory, Isaac BALLINTYNE, Wilson CHARLES, and Jack MIRASTY and I have talked about burning the school down.

On Monday January 27th, 1947, I was in class at the school and I asked my teacher for permission to go to the toilet. And I went down to the basement and while there I took a coal shovel and took some hot ashes from under the firebox of the furnace and put them on the cordwood which was stacked in the basement. The wood caught fire after while and it was discovered by the Principal and put out.

On Sunday February 2nd, 1947 at about 1:00 p.m., I was in the boys playroom with Jack MIRASTY, Norh BIRD, and Isaac BALLINTYNE and we started to talk about setting fire to the school. We all went down the basement steps and when we arrived at the basement Jack MIRASTY asked me if I had a match and I did not have any. Jack MIRASTY gave me two or three matches and I went to the back of the furnace on the west side of the building where there was some cardboard cartons which had been torn up. I struck the matches on the shelf of the cold air flue and placed them on the torn pieces of cardboard. They immediately caught fire and flared up. I then got scared and ran up the stairs and outside, the other boys had already gone out.

After this I stood around and watched the school burn down. I have only told one boy about setting this fire and that was Sampson SANDERSON of Lee La Ronge, Sask."

Witness,

Signed Kitchener A. BIRD.

Rev. L. G. Wickenden.

(P. T. O.)
4. The above statement was obtained from this juvenile after he had made several attempts to put forth various stories regarding the origin of the fire, he is quite ready with an explanation for any question put to him and will lie rather than attempt to tell the truth. KITCHENER will be 13 years of age on the 31st of March 1947, he is small of stature and has not the slightest conception as to the value of the damage he has caused by setting fire to the school.

5. The Rev. D. G. WICKENDEN, former principal of the School was present during the interrogation of this boy and the location of where KITCHENER states he started the fire was checked with the knowledge of the building by Mr. WICKENDEN, the point stated by KITCHENER where he set the cardboard on fire was directly underneath the cold air vent, it was ascertained that this particular cold air vent was of wooden construction to within three or four feet of the furnace and was lined with paper, it being alleged that when same was constructed there was a shortage of tin piping and this was a makeshift affair.

6. The hot air pipe observed by Mr. WICKENDEN as being red hot runs directly underneath this cold air vent which are all located at the back of the furnace at the west end of the school. For record purposes it is pointed out that this school was heated by three hot air furnaces fired with cord lengths of wood.

7. No explanation was obtained from KITCHENER as to why he committed this offence, and it was also ascertained that KITCHENER together with several other boys were to be the subject of prosecution in the near future for petty thefts from the local stores at Lee La Ronge. Mr. WICKENDEN advises that he is of the opinion that the boys involved in this action may have planned the destruction of the school in order that they could return to their various homes and thus avoid any further action for the thefts.

8. Mr. WICKENDEN advises that he was kept busy the week following the fire disposing of stores etc., and was then transferred to the Gordon Indian School at Punnichy, Sask., in view of which he was not in a position to take this matter up with the local Detachment and, further, he made a full report to his immediate superiors.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 23rd instant, File No. 132-2-5 (WT 1), in connection with the burning of the Lac la Ronge School, and proposed prosecution of Kitchener Bird and John Roberts, I have today discussed the matter with the Deputy Attorney General and his attitude in the matter seems to be that he should not recommend what action should be taken with a view to punishment of the boys concerned but he states that, if our Department decides to prosecute, his Department will then see that the necessary action is taken.

I certainly would be in favour of punishing these boys if suitable punishment could be found but the only punishment that can be meted out to them is a term in the Industrial School here in Regina where their associates will be incorrigible white boys, many of whom know far more about law-breaking than these backward Indian boys from the north woods will ever know. Kitchener Bird has now been returned to his home and John Roberts has been at his home for some time.

To proceed with prosecutions it will probably be necessary for a worker from the Social Aid Branch and a Magistrate to be flown into the North and the boys, if convicted, flown out again. These boys will probably view a flying trip out to Prince Albert and a train trip to Regina as fun. After a term in the Industrial School it would still not be safe to put them in an Indian residential school and the only thing which then could be done with them would be to return them to their homes as little heroes who had received considerable notoriety as a result of their "brave" act in burning the school.

I may say that I gave this matter considerable thought before making the recommendation which I made to Superintendent Mortimer. I decided then that no good would come through any action of this kind being taken, and, while I do not wish to appear stubborn in the matter, I still am unable to see the matter in any other light. However, if the Department decides that it would be better to prosecute I am quite prepared to abide by the Department's decision.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

On the 15th instant I received from Inspector Ostrander authority to return one of our pupils, Kitchener Allen Bird, to his home in Lac la Ronge. This boy, not yet thirteen years of age, had confessed to striking the match and starting the fire which destroyed our residential school at Lac la Ronge on Feb. 2. However, as I explained in a lengthy report to Mr. Ostrander on March 26, the chief instigator and the boy who supplied the matches was Jack Mirasty, aged fifteen and the oldest boy in school in respect of residence. I also pointed out that most of the boys who were named as having spoken at different times of burning the school down had been implicated in the serious thefts from Olsen's store and cafe during November last, concerning which you wrote me early in January. In getting rid of the school perhaps they thought that they would escape possible trouble in connection with the thefts.

When I was at Lac la Ronge last week Cpl. Kirkby, R.C.M.P., told me that he had received instructions from headquarters to close his file concerning the fire. Presumably that means that no action is to be taken against these juvenile offenders, and hence, this letter of enquiry. They know that they have committed punishable crimes and have confessed their guilt. Failure to bring them to trial in a court of law will only be interpreted as a sign of weak indulgence and indifference. There will be for these young delinquents and their associates no such thing as the "majesty of the law", but rather a growing disregard for all law and order and a corresponding contempt for officers of the law. I cannot conceive that offences of a similar nature would be overlooked in civilized society, and it is our task to Christianize our Indian wards and to instill into them a healthy respect for the white man's justice.

Yours faithfully,

Acting Principal
Lac La Ronge, Sask. May 1st 1947

J.W. Corman
Attorney General
Regina, Sask.

Dear Mr. Corman,

On Feb. 2nd of this year the Indian residential school here was completely destroyed by fire.

Investigations regarding this fire reveal that this was arson committed by 5 boys attending the school.

I understand that upon advice from the Indian Dept. at Ottawa, no charge whatever will be laid against those boys, they are not going to be prosecuted.

Is it within your jurisdiction to lay a charge?

If not, would you confirm the current report, which is apparently true, that no proceedings will be instituted against those little firebugs? I would then take up this matter with Ottawa.

I own a dwelling house here, together with a warehouse, both buildings carry fire insurance with our own provincial insurance office, but somehow, with these firebugs still at large, I feel that, as a resident of Saskatchewan, I am not getting the protection to which I am entitled.

Yours very truly

(Sgd.) Albert Vander-Kracht

DEPUTY MINISTER

I have received several reports from the R.C.M.P. who investigated the destruction of the above mentioned building and from these reports it is evident that the fire was set. At least, two boys, Kitchener Bird aged twelve years and John Roberts, aged twelve years, were particularly implicated.

When the reports of the police indicated that the fire had been set I communicated with Mr. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies for the Province of Saskatchewan and a copy of his reply is enclosed.

The officers of this Branch have given the matter very careful thought and it is felt that after weighing all the circumstances in the case, it would be desirable to prosecute the two boys mentioned above and I would appreciate it if you would approve of such action being taken.

1. A copy of your letter dated May 12, 1947, as well as the enclosures mentioned was forwarded to the Inspector of Indian Agencies, and the following is a reply received from Mr. Ostrander:

"With reference to your File No. 47R 692-7, and your letter of the 15th instant enclosing copy of a letter received by the D.A.G. from Mr. Albert Vander-Kracht, of Lac la Ronge, I do not think that these boys should be referred to as "little fire bugs". They are both little children from the bush country who were dissatisfied at the school and managed to burn it because they did not realize the seriousness of their action.

Perhaps I have taken the wrong view of this matter, and I must admit my original view has not changed, but no good will be done anyone to bring these two Indian boys out of the bush and place them in the Industrial Home here in Regina for a period of months or years. Perhaps such action would give Mr. Vander-Kracht the feeling of safety for a time but I presume he would not suggest that they should be confined indefinitely in order that his buildings may be safe indefinitely. I believe in punishment where good will be done, or might be done, but I do not believe in punishment in a case of this kind where I firmly believe more harm will be done the two boys. They will learn more about crime and misdemeanor in an industrial school than they have learned, or will learn, in their home environment."

Dear Sir:

Re: Kitchener BIRD et al - Arson (511) CCC
Lac la Ronge, Saskatchewan.

1. Through our headquarters Ottawa information has been received from
the Director of Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, that prosecution is desirable.
The matter was referred to the Deputy Attorney-General Regina and he replied
under date of July 7 as follows:

"Referring to your letter of the 28th ultimo and to the recent
telephonic conversation which Superintendent Mortimer had with
me I hereby confirm the said conversation wherein it was decided
that the prosecution herein should proceed in view of the directions
received by the Commissioner from the Director of Indian Affairs
Branch, Ottawa, under date the 10thday of June last.

This fire was on the 2nd day of February and as a result of no action
being taken we are still carrying on correspondence as to whether
or not a prosecution should be instituted and if no action is taken
the question arises as to when this correspondence is going to end, and
as the case may finally end with a prosecution, such as in the case
under section 265(6), of the Criminal Code in the Judicial District
of Moosomin in which we had to institute a prosecution in order to
end an endless chain of correspondence extending over about a year
trying to stave off a prosecution, it would seem advisable to start the
prosecution now in order to dispose of the case."

It would be appreciated if you would have an Information and Complaint
laid against each of the accused and properly waived and forwarded to this
office so that prosecution may proceed.

Yours truly,

Sgd. W. Mortimer, Supt. In Charge,

Regina, July 12th, 1947.

R.A. Hoey, Esq., Director, Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Ontario.

With reference to Department letter of the 10th ultimo, File No. 132-2-5 (WT), regarding the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School Fire, and proposed prosecution of Kitchener Bird and John Roberts, I am now in receipt of a letter from Superintendent W. Mortimer, in charge C.I.B., R.C.M. Police, Regina, asking me to have Information and Complaint laid against the two boys concerned. I shall do so only upon receiving your instructions to that effect as I certainly do not approve of proceeding with the prosecution of these two boys simply because some people wish revenge against them, when we know full well that any attempt at correction in an institution will do them more harm than good. The matter of prosecution then looks like revenge upon children, as they are no more than children.

I saw Kitchener Bird a few days ago at Lac la Ronge and was again impressed with the fact that he is but a simple little child who, I am sure, did not know the seriousness of his act. I did not see the other boy at this time but his case is very similar.

Copy of Superintendent Mortimer's letter is enclosed herewith.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

With reference to this office letter of July 29th, 1947, File No. 1153-309-11 AGE., Department telegram of August 9th, and telegram from this office in reply dated August 9th, regarding buildings of No. 122 Ex-Basic Training Centre, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter from the District Resident Architect, Department of Public Works, addressed to Mr. G. Gustave Brault, Acting Chief Architect, Department of Public Works, Ottawa.

On the 15th instant Mr. J. Ramage, of the office of the District Resident Architect, Saskatoon; Mr. R.S. Jones, Indian Agent, Carlton agency; and the writer went through the buildings which are available, or soon to be available, and which would prove suitable for a residential school. It will be noted that buildings No. 2, 3, 9, 23, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 32, 33, 35, 36, and 38 are all vacant and have been handed over to the Department of Public Works by the Department of Labour (Canadian Vocational Training). These buildings are somewhat scattered about the grounds of the training centre. No. 33 is a mess hall now available but it is in very bad shape and much of the equipment has been removed or destroyed, and it is very desirable to obtain building No. 34, which is a similar mess hall but in good condition and immediately adjacent to No. 33. No. 34 is held by the Provincial Department of Reconstruction but is not being used. Every effort should be made to obtain the use of No. 34 at once. The buildings which should immediately be put in use for the school are No. 2, to be made into two residential suites; No. 3 to be made into two residential suites; No. 34, combined kitchen and dining rooms; No. 23 and No. 29 "Huts," in good condition, suitable for dormitories; and No. 27, the drill hall, which has ample space for recreational purposes in bad weather, also ample space in a lean-to part thereof suitable for arrangement into classrooms.

By the use of the buildings mentioned a pupilage of 200 of both sexes and all ages could be accommodated providing sufficient staff, including 4 teachers, can be found.

I have not discussed the proposed school with any of the officials of the Anglican Church and I am not certain whether it is the intention of the Department that the proposed school is to be operated under the auspices of the Anglican Church or not. I believe it would be a good opportunity for us to open a non-denominational residential school in order to carry out what seems to be the intent of the Parliamentary Committee and the wish of many of the Indians.

I would recommend that the Department of Public Works be asked to immediately prepare for school purposes the buildings mentioned, and that steps be taken to secure, probably from the War Assets Corporation, the necessary beds, bedding, kitchen utensils and dishes, and that our Department should order 200 desks, 4 teachers' desks, and chairs, as well as the necessary furniture to furnish buildings Nos. 2 and 3 for living quarters. Two members of the school staff should be provided with sleeping quarters and necessary bedroom furniture that one male and one female member of the staff shall be able to sleep in the boys' and girls' dormitories respectively.

It would appear to me that the staff of this school for the present should consist of a Principal, a Matron, a Nurse, an Engineer, an Assistant Engineer, 4 teachers, a Kitchen Matron, a Girls' Supervisor, a Boys' Supervisor, a Sewing Matron, and a Gardener.

The grounds which will be made....
The grounds which will be made available for our purpose consist of a good playground space of 4 acres, and about 3½ acres of orchard, garden, and nursery. The orchard and nursery would prove of great value to the school and is well worthy of the attention of a full-time man who would act as caretaker of the buildings in addition to the duties of a gardener.

Ample accommodation can be found for housing the school staff mentioned by the use of Buildings No. 2 and 3, and one half of one of the dormitory buildings, either No. 23 or 29. Furniture and bedding should be secured for this purpose also.

Immediately north of the orchard and nursery is an unused area of 40 acres. It could be secured in the future to enlarge the garden. It is good soil and suitable for gardening purposes by using water. The water for all purposes at the school will be supplied by the City of Prince Albert and is already connected. Power also is supplied by the City of Prince Albert.

I believe that the Department of Public Works will have no great difficulty in having the necessary buildings prepared for our use at a not far distant date. More difficult will be the matter of securing staff.

I should be glad to be advised of the Department's decision in the matter and to receive further instructions with regard thereto.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Your letter of August 29th, file 132-2-5(WT), was forwarded to me in Saskatoon and I had the opportunity of placing your offer before the Executive Committee of our Missionary Society. I also took the opportunity of visiting Prince Albert and went over this place thoroughly in company with Principal Fisher of St. Alban's School.

May I say at once that I personally appreciate very much the consideration given to us in this matter and am clear that the buildings in the camp can be used satisfactorily for a school of at least one hundred children. I feel, however, that some amendment to the suggestions made by the Inspector and District Resident Architect would be required. The buildings which it is proposed should be used appear to us to be badly scattered and not at all suitable for the purpose. The drill hall, #27, might make a play place in the summer but the cost of heating such a huge building would be quite prohibitive with the income which we are likely to receive. Also, the use of buildings 2 and 3 as staff residences does not appear to us to be feasible as they are too far away from the children's quarters. It is to be hoped that building #34 may be obtained from the Provincial government as it is certainly in very much better condition than 33. We wonder why #30 is not proposed as it is included in the list of units handed over. It is a splendid building with classrooms already provided and an excellent gymnasium superior to anything which we have in the majority of our present schools. Our suggestion would be that buildings 29, 30, 33 and 34 should be made available and these four, which are close together, would form a workable combination. Our experience points to the necessity of concentrating both staff and children to make effective supervision possible. It would be very difficult for our workers to control the boys if they were passing between unused buildings and there is everything to be gained by having the buildings in close proximity.

I shall be grateful if consideration may be given to our suggested amendments to the plan proposed by your officials.

I may say frankly that our Executive met in a very disturbed state of mind by reason of the distressing financial state of our Administration. Re: Basic Training Centre - Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

With reference to Department letter of the 26th ultimo, File No. 132-2-5 (W T), in connection with the above, I have to say that the matter of the location and distribution of the buildings at Ex-Basic Training Centre No. 122 was given careful consideration before my original recommendation as those buildings best suitable for early use as an Indian residential school.

Building No. 34 was recommended because it was a mess hall in good condition. Building No. 33 was not recommended because it was originally built for a mess hall but much of the interior furnishings had been removed. Since my original recommendation these furnishings have been replaced and both are now well equipped mess halls.

I should point out that many of the buildings were in use when the matter was first considered, and I mentioned those not in use which could be used to advantage. I understand that all of the buildings have now been turned over to the Department of Public Works and some time in the not far distant future will all be available.

I recommended Building No. 27, the drill hall, as a building which would provide classroom space and plenty of room for manual training, as well as a large floor space for recreation purposes during the winter, and in wet weather during the summer. I recommended Buildings Nos. 1 and 2, as they are both residences which could be made into staff quarters without much difficulty. However, any vacant building could be made into staff quarters, and any vacant building could be used for recreation purposes and manual training. In recommending the buildings in the first instance, I had in mind only those buildings which could be made available and useful in a short time at no great expense. However, I am not prepared to enter into a controversy with the Church Authorities as to which buildings should be used. I would say, however, that Buildings Nos. 33 and 34, which are now both fully equipped mess halls, with kitchen and washing facilities, should not be taken for school purposes. Either would furnish much more dining and kitchen space than we have in any of our present Indian residential schools and to destroy the usefulness of one of these buildings as a kitchen and mess hall, instead of taking one of the other buildings, either No. 20, 21, 22, or 23, would seem foolish.

With regard to Dr. Alderwood's remark about the cost of heating such a huge building as the drill hall No. 27, I made enquiries about this and as it has an excellent heating plant which provides a temperature of 50 to 55, which is sufficiently high for recreation purposes, I believe it would be just as economical to heat the one building, thus providing classroom space for manual training and space for recreation all under one roof, than to heat three other smaller buildings to supply the same accommodation.

Although we are now considering opening this as a 100-pupil school its possibilities for the future are great, and there would be ample accommodation for several hundred pupils amongst the buildings which will shortly all be available. If the pupilage was increased to 300 or 400 some time in the future the drill hall would be a very necessary part of the school.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Basic Training Centre - Prince Albert, Sask.

In February 1946 the Lac la Ronge Residential School in northern Saskatchewan was destroyed by fire. This school had a pupilage of 100. As a result we today have all these children entirely without school facilities.

After careful consideration we have decided to recommend that the former Army Training Centre at Prince Albert be taken over and used as a residential school in place of the Lac la Ronge School. We are already operating a residential school in Prince Albert at the former Anglican college there. It is recommended that the school to be operated in the army camp be called the Lac la Ronge Residential School and that it be operated as an entirely separate unit from the Prince Albert Residential School.

These buildings are entirely suitable for this purpose. Inspector Ostrander, Mr. Indian Agent Jones and our Educational Survey Officer are in complete agreement that it is feasible to use certain of these buildings as a residential school. Dr. Alderswood of the Missionary Society of the Church of England has also inspected these buildings and feels that they would be suitable. It may be further added that the Roman Catholics, who lost by fire their orphanage in Prince Albert last year, are using some of these buildings as a temporary orphanage.

The Dominion Department of Public Works is willing...
to let us have the use of these buildings.

However, before the Missionary Society of the Church of England will agree to the operation of this school it will be necessary to make them the following guarantees:

(a) That there will be a pupilage at this school of at least 120;

(b) That the per capita grant would be a basic rate of $200.00 (the rate formerly paid at the Lac la Ronge School) plus any additional special grants allowed by the Government;

(c) That this School would be turned over to them as a complete functioning unit with full equipment.

Items (a) and (b) above present no great difficulties, as we have the funds in our Vote which would have been used for per capita payments at the Lac la Ronge School. However, item (c) would mean an expenditure of approximately $10,000.00 for the purchase of beds, tables, chairs, desks, complete kitchen equipment, blankets, sheets, etc. We are unable to finance such an expenditure from our present Vote and it would be necessary to have your approval for the inclusion of this item in our Supplementary Estimates.

Director.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT.
Lac La Ronge Residential School.

It is our intention to include in our 1948-49 estimates, a sum for the erection of a Residential School at Lac La Ronge, Saskatchewan. The site for this school will be that previously used by the Church of England for the operation of the former school which was burned by fire two years ago. You are requested to prepare the plans and specifications for these buildings.

The pupilage to be provided for at this school will be one hundred and fifty (75 boys and 75 girls). Due to the isolation of this school, it is felt that frame construction should be used but that the dormitories should be in separate buildings, in order to minimize the danger of fire.

It is recommended that this school consist of the following buildings:

(1) Boys' Dormitory Block:
   (a) Sleeping Quarters for 60 boys
   (b) Two staff rooms
   (c) Wash rooms
   (d) Recreation Room
   (e) Manual Training Shop

It is suggested that this be a one storey building with a full basement. The sleeping quarters, staff rooms and wash rooms could be on the main floor with the recreation room and manual training shop in the basement.
(2) Girls' Dormitory Block:

The general planning for this building would be the same as for the boys' dormitory block. The exception would, of course, be the manual training room which, in this building, would be replaced by a domestic science room. This room should have extra electrical outlets provided for a power sewing machine and electric rangettes.

(3) Administration Building:

This would be a two storey building and would have a full basement. We would require the following rooms in this building:

(a) Staff Quarters for eight.
(b) Assembly Hall.
(c) Kitchen and dining-rooms.
(d) Wash rooms for use of school pupils and staff.
(e) Power House (We are prepared to accept your recommendation that the power house should be located in a small building. It is felt that the whole unit should be steam heated from this power house).

(4) Classroom Block:

This would be a standard four-room school previously designed by you for use at Eskasoni and Shubenacadie.

It is recommended that a meeting be held between your architects and our school officials to finalize the exact details of the buildings required.

It is my idea that the children so housed would have their breakfast at the annex, after which they would be transported to St. Alban's by truck, remaining all day for classroom work, etc. and then after supper be returned by truck to the annex.

I strongly feel it would not be in the best interests of the children involved to be sent back to their homes at this time of the year, after having been admitted to a Residential school with the intention of remaining the entire year at the school.

It will be very much appreciated if you will bring this proposal to the Indian Affairs Branch as early as possible. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to our administration for their information.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) G.W. Fisher
Principal
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copies of letters dated November 22nd and November 25th from Rev. G. W. Fisher, Principal of the Anglican Indian Residential School, Prince Albert, together with a copy of my letter to Mr. Fisher, dated November 24th, 1947.

When visiting the Indian Residential school at Prince Albert (known as St. Alban's school) I found that the dormitories in the building are again over-crowded notwithstanding the fact that the, then, principal, Rev. Henry Ellis had been instructed to reduce the pupilage to 100 because of the crowded dormitories. In the discussion Mr. Fisher proposed having all the pupils in excess of 100 live in one of the buildings recently taken over at Ex 122, Basic Training Centre, Prince Albert, I concurred with the suggestion and asked him to make the proposal in writing through this office. When his proposal came in his letter of the 22nd instant he introduced another matter with which I could not agree, namely: serving meals at Ex 122 Basis Training centre. His letter of the 25th instant is in reply to my letter of the 24th.

I realize that there will be some delay in establishing the new school at Prince Albert, and in the meantime the dormitories at the old school will be over-crowded to the detriment of the children sleeping in them, also increasing the fire hazard. Please advise me whether or not I should insist that sufficient of the children be returned to their homes to reduce the number in residence to 100, pending the opening of the new school. These extra children should not have been admitted to the school, but they are there now and there will be some difficulty in contacting their parents with a view to returning them to their homes.

With regard to that part of Mr. Fisher's letter where he refers in the third paragraph to the purchase of cooking utensils, etc., I have to say that I located a quantity of these utensils which could be purchased from a surplus in the hands of the Provincial Government, Department of Rehabilitation, taken over by them from War Assets Corporation. A list of these utensils was prepared and is held in this office as I am awaiting unit prices from the official in charge here in Regina. Mr. Fisher misunderstood me when he says that he understood that arrangements were made for their purchase. I proposed submitting the list to the Department and recommending their purchase as soon as prices have been received. I expected to receive these prices today but they have not yet arrived. The list is not the complete requirements for opening a school of 120 pupils. Some of the articles were in sufficient quantity for our requirements, others were not. As soon as authority has been received to take over the utensils in question I intend to check over the list with Mr. Fisher, ascertain what further quantities are required, and submit the necessary requisition to the Department.

I have not yet been officially informed that the proposed school will be operated in the near future. I note that Mr. Fisher's letter indicates that a definite arrangement has been made.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 5th instant,
File No. 132-2-4 (W T), and Department telegram of the 6th instant regarding
preparations for opening the new school at Prince Albert, I visited Prince
Albert recently to discuss with Reverend G.W. Fisher and Mr. Jones the matter
of further equipment necessary before the school can be opened.

Enclosed is a list of further equipment asked for by Mr. Fisher,
also some catalogue sheets showing laundry machinery which can be purchased
from J. H. Connor & Son, Limited, Ottawa, and which could be seen by an
official of our Department to decide whether or not it is suitable.

The only prices shown by me on this list are the quotations on
the laundry machinery and labour for manufacturing lockers for the children's
clothing.

I would ask that this list be carefully examined and that any
unapproved items be deleted. Also that I be instructed as to the manner by
which it is intended to make the purchases. If it is by means of Requisition
Form 37 I would like to be informed whether or not there should be some sub-
division of the requisitions.

We discussed the question of partitions, flooring, etc. in the
buildings which it has been decided we would use. There will be some expense
in connection with building partitions, repairing floors, and re-arrangement
of plumbing. I have asked Mr. Norman Thompson, District Resident Architect,
Department of Public Works, Saskatoon, to assist us in securing the plan,
preparing an estimate and getting a quotation on this necessary work. As soon
as this part of the preparation has been completed I shall communicate further
with the Department.

J.P.B. Ostrender,
Inspector of Indian Agencies, Saskatchewan.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY.

Possibilities of Prince Albert.

It might be worthwhile to invite the attention of the new Superintendent of Anglican Indian Residential Schools to the possibilities which exist at Prince Albert barracks.

As you know this installation was originally a Mounted Police station. The stables could be converted to house cattle, a few of which could be pastured nearby.

There are buildings which could be used as heated poultry houses.

In addition to the pasture land there is some ground which looks good enough to grow a worthwhile stock of vegetables for which there is no problem of water supply.

There are some fruit trees which might be responsive to proper care.

As Prince Albert is a point of departure for tourists to and from the Northern park lands, a handicraft shop in the city could be organized to dispose of articles made by the pupils at the school.

In addition to the laundry chores necessary for the institution itself, the school might branch out into a laundry, mending and dry cleaning business for the town. I did not myself find that these services were superior at Prince Albert.

The curriculum need not anticipate anything beyond High School Entrance. If they go beyond this it would be
to the pupils' and the Department's advantage to have them attend the High School, the course of study for which is being modernized and enlarged. The province, moreover, makes a grant towards the cost of attendance of high school pupils from out of town. As the parents of these children would be non-residents of Prince Albert, the children would qualify even though they continue to reside at the residential school.

As, however, most of the boys will be in the intermediate grades it should be possible by arrangement with the Prince Albert School Board to obtain the services of a part time Instructor in technical subjects. Similar arrangements, no doubt, could be made in subjects proper for the girls.

C.A.F. Clark,

Please refer to my letter of November 7th, 1947, File No. 1713-303-11 AG2./300-4A, in connection with the lumber stored at 6x-122 Basic Training Centre, Prince Albert, and the property of the Department of Labour, Canadian Vocational Training School, also Department letter of November 14th, 1947, File No. 132-2-5 W.T.

An inventory of the lumber referred to was prepared and forwarded to Mr. W.A. Ross, Regional Director, C.V.T.S., Regina, with a view to having it turned over to our Branch. Mr. Ross has now received a letter from the Director of Training, Mr. R.W. Thompson, Department of Labour, Ottawa, which reads in part as follows:

"....the following procedure would have to be adopted:

(1) The Province would have to purchase this lumber from the Dominion Department of Labour, and send a cheque for the same to this office, payable to the Receiver General of Canada.

(2) The Province would then bill the Dominion Department of Mines and Resources for this same amount, which would be paid by the Department of Mines and Resources to the Province of Saskatchewan."

I do not understand the reason for such a procedure. No doubt the province would be glad to purchase this well seasoned lumber at considerably below the market price at which it is now available for sale. I have grave doubt that they would then agree to resell it to our Branch for the same money, if at all. I am very anxious to secure this lumber as it has been well seasoned under cover for a year, and is in excellent condition. The price which we would be paying for it, if taken over direct from the Department of Labour, is about 80% of the current retail price of lumber, and it is all useful for building purposes in our building program for the coming fiscal year.

I would be glad if enquiry could be made from Mr. Thompson as to the reason why this lumber cannot be transferred direct from the Department of Labour to our Department, and I have no hope that we will get it by the means he suggests. The matter is urgent because Mr. Ross has to make immediate disposal of the lumber, and I would ask that I be advised at the earliest possible date as to the action which it is proposed to take. The quantity of lumber is approximately 66,000 ft. and consists of dimension lumber, common boards, shiplats, etc.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, File No. 132-2-5 (E.I.), in connection with prosecutions of Kitchener Bird and John Roberts regarding the fire at the Lac la Ronge School.

Information was laid by the writer on the 23rd of August, 1947, against both of these boys in accordance with instructions from the Department. On the 29th of October, 1947, Kitchener Bird was sentenced as indicated in police report and Department letter. On December 3rd, 1947, he was transferred to the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle where he remained until February 23rd, 1948, when he was returned to his home on the reserve. Apparently the use of the term "indefinite period" is common in this province when sentencing boys to the Industrial School, and simply means that it is left to the discretion of the School Superintendent and Provincial Welfare officers to decide termination, in the best interest of the boy.

The R.C.M. Police file is still incomplete with regard to John Roberts. My last information in this connection was to the effect that the N.C.O., in Charge, R.C.M. Police, at Lac la Ronge, is to make arrangements for the hearing when the boy is located. He could not be found at the time that the Magistrate dealt with the case of Kitchener Bird and it was not considered advisable to incur a great expense searching for him in the north country. I am today writing the Officer Commanding, R.C.M. Police, Regina, reminding him that the case is still in abeyance in case it may have been overlooked.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

MINISTER OF EDUCATION

Regina, Sask., March 29, 1948

Dear Mr. Glen:

You will recall our previous correspondence and conversations with regard to Dominion-Provincial co-operation in providing educational facilities and services in the northern part of the province. I think there is no need for me at this time to repeat our opinions with regard to the situation. Perhaps I might mentioned that we had previously sent a list of communities in which in our opinion we might well work together to provide the necessary services.

I am raising the matter again as a result of the recent announcement that your Department is going to build certain new schools for the use of our Indian population. We have particularly noted the proposal with regard to a new six-room school at Lac la Ronge. Might I suggest that as a result of this development we would be more than interested in renewing conversations with regard to co-operation in this field. Using Lac la Ronge as an example we would like to suggest that some plan be worked out whereby the Dominion Government would make arrangements to construct and operate a dormitory and provide the facilities in a separate building for carrying on the educational classes. We have no wish to participate in the dormitory operation. We do feel that it would be an advantage if arrangements could be made whereby the school could be operated in conjunction with our new school at that point. I may say that we have almost completed the construction of a new school at Lac la Ronge and this school is constructed in such a way that almost any number of additional classrooms might be added. With an eight-room school at such a point I am sure you will agree that excellent educational services could be provided.

I know from our previous correspondence and in conversations that you are in agreement with the plan of treating all our citizens in the north on a similar basis.
It would seem to us that we have at this time an excellent opportunity to further coordinate our activities and consequently make them more effective. I may say that the officials of the Saskatchewan Government who work in this area feel that such a plan would put into effect the wishes of the people who live in that area.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) W.S. Lloyd,
Minister of Education.

The Honourable J.A. Glen,
Minister of Mines and Resources,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

With reference to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of April 2nd, the attached letter from the Minister of Education for the province of Saskatchewan to our Minister is returned herewith.

It has not yet been decided where to rebuild the former Lac la Ronge Residential School.

There are two proposals now before us:

(a) That we rebuild the school in the area of Lac la Ronge. This viewpoint is supported by the Right Reverend Henry D. Martin, Anglican Bishop of Saskatchewan, and by the former Principal of the School, the Reverend D.C. Wickenden.

(b) That we rebuild the school closer to Prince Albert, possibly in the area of the Little Red River Reserve. On the Reserve just mentioned a suitable site can be obtained. The cultivation of this land would produce the vegetables required for use at the school and also the raising of cattle, hogs, etc., for food purposes. This could not be done in the Lac la Ronge area. This viewpoint is supported by our Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan, Mr. Ostrander, and Mr. Indian Agent Jones.
In view of the above divergent recommendations, the whole situation is still under consideration.

It is our intention to have our Educational Survey Officer go to Saskatchewan in the third week of April to interview Bishop Martin and ascertain whether he is still as determined as previously to press for the rebuilding of the school at Lac la Ronge.

I also understand that Mr. Matte, of the Prime Minister's Office, has phoned our Superintendent of Education and advised that the people of Prince Albert are anxious to have the school built near that city. In view of these considerations, we have not attempted to answer the Honourable Mr. Lloyd's letter but are presenting the facts to you, as stated above.

Director.

Dear Dr. Keenleyside:

The Session of our Legislature prorogued on Thursday last
and I am now endeavouring to catch up on some of my correspondence.

A short time ago I noticed an announcement in the Saskatoon
Star-Phoenix by your Minister, the Honourable J. A. Glen. This
was to the effect that some 80 new schools would be constructed
in the near future for Indians and that one of these would be
located at Lac la Ronge.

I can hardly believe this report is correct and I am, there-
fore, taking the liberty of writing you a personal letter in
this regard. As you know the Provincial Government has had a
public school in the process of construction for over a year at
Lac la Ronge and I understand it will be completed this summer.
As you are possibly aware last summer we appointed a Northern
Administrator and at the end of this Session assent was given to
a Bill to provide a special administrative set-up for the
Northern half of the Province, the areas of which have been
especially designated for this purpose. The Northern Administrator
is also much concerned regarding this situation.

It is our hope and desire to treat the Indians the same as
any other citizens of our Province. While education is not the
responsibility of our Department, nevertheless under this new
Act the general administration of the North is and since reading
this announcement I have been wondering if it is not possible to
work out some plan of a joint approach to this problem of education
in the North. We have worked out a very satisfactory joint fur
development programme and I cannot see why a similar approach
could not be extended into the field of education. It would not
only be much more economical, but it is believed it would be more
efficient and even more important is the fact that by having two
schools in the same area false divisions are created immediately
in the minds of the children. This applies both to white and
native children and it is felt establishes the wrong relationship
from the very beginning. In other words I personally feel the
Best method of fitting people to live together in later life is to have them attend the same schools - together they can learn much from each other; otherwise we set up by our own actions the very divisions we are all seeking to eliminate.

The writer can fully appreciate that there are groups who would have a special interest in seeing the system of separate educations continue. However, even under the best of planning, educational services in the Northern areas are bound to require the expenditure of substantial public funds and it is thought we will all be rightfully subject to severe criticism if we encourage unnecessary duplication.

I have already been asked to make a press statement, but intend to refrain from so doing until I have learned the facts. A copy of the press announcement in question is being attached hereto for your information.

If for some reason, known or unknown, complete co-operation between the two Departments concerned cannot be obtained, which I would be reluctant to accept as being the case, then as an alternative I would strongly urge an immediate conference with a view to eliminating duplication and properly allocating the different areas, in order that each settlement will be adequately served and thus correct the present situation where in some areas a large number of school children are without facilities of this nature.

Receipt of your reply would be greatly appreciated and I shall continue to refuse making any public comment until same arrives.

With kindest personal regards, I am,

Yours sincerely,

(signed) J. L. Phelps,

Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development.

MINERAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN OFFERS AID TO PROSPECTORS

REGINA.—Up to 40 men will be assisted by the provincial government in carrying out prospecting activities in Saskatchewan's Precambrian Shield under support of the government's new mineral development policy, Resources Minister J. L. Phelps announced recently.

Applications from individuals or partnerships may be submitted by March 31, said the minister, who added that interested parties must submit at least one letter of recommendation from a former employer. "Prospectors with mining experience and anxious men with bush or service experience" are required.

Prospectors may make any deal they wish with individuals without obtaining permission from the government, Mr. Phelps said.

Cash awards will be made for discoveries on the basis of 2½ per cent of the value of the property located and underground development during the three-year period starting from January 1, 1948, until December 31, 1950. Samples for assay will be picked up twice during the season, at Friday Lake and a government geologist will spend a few days with each party.

Prospectors will be flown into the bush country from La Loche Range or Pilot Flats. They will gather at these two points where they will then all have an opportunity to choose partners for the season. Equipment will be obtained by depositors so that each prospector will be completely outfitted within five days, including tents, fuel, food supplies, Mr. Phelps said.

A $100 bond must be deposited with the department of natural resources at each location.

REGINA—Mossebank resident Dr. D. Mott has expressed his appreciation in a letter to Dr. J. L. Mott, chairman of the Health Services Planning Commission, in which he said he was grateful to help defray the costs of the plan.

Natural Resources Posts For Churchman, Roney

REGINA—Appointment of J. W. Churchman as assistant deputy minister of natural resources for Saskatchewan was announced recently by Hon. J. L. Phelps. Mr. Churchman, formerly executive assistant in the Natural Resources Department, was appointed by a special order-in-council.

Mr. Churchman's successor as executive assistant will be W. A. Roney. The appointment to the new post was made at the same time by the Saskatchewan public service commission. Mr. Churchman was appointed technician with the commission.

Mr. Phelps said the post of assistant deputy minister was a newly-created position but was one which had been vacant since former assistant deputy minister G. C. MacKinnon was appointed deputy minister in the fall of 1947. The vacancy in the assistant deputy minister's post had been delayed since that time because a suitable replacement could not be found when one was not available, he said.

A native of Saskatchewan, Mr. Churchman received his school and university training at Saskatoon. After graduation he taught school for part of that time as school principal at Cutknife.

Enlisting in the R.C.A.F. during the Second World War, he served three years as an instrument mechanics instructor, and following his discharge joined the staff of the natural resources Department in June, 1946, as chief clerk.

Correspondence School's Enrolment For Studies Up

REGINA.—Number of pupils receiving tuition on grades one to eight from the Saskatchewan government correspondence school has increased by 376 since June and will continue rising as the closing of rural schools in the province, Education Minister W. S. Lloyd said recently.

Of the increase, 291 pupils receive full instruction from the correspondence school under direct direction of a teacher or other qualified person.

Figures were not available on increased high school course enrolments due to the school closing down because such students apply individually for the courses, Mr. Lloyd said.

New enrolment in the junior grades is approximately 1,000, but this figure has jumped to 2,245 this year, Mr. Lloyd said. The latter figure 784 pupils receive full tuition and 461 study part-time.

Courses follow the curriculum outlined by the department of education. Irrigation, Conservation Said Vital For Land Use

Increased agricultural production in Saskatchewan is directly related to the problem of rehabilitating soil through conservation and irrigation, Agriculture Minister I. C. Nollet told the legislature.

Speaking in the budget debate, Mr. Nollet said that of the 60,000,000 cultivated acres in the province only 8,000,000 acres are classed as very good to excellent productive land. Rehabilitation of the remaining 52,000,000 acres, he said, is necessary if the province is to maintain its present production.

Period of settlement and subsequent production is gone and the province's farms must be operated on a different basis. Of the 140,000 operating farm units in Saskatchewan in 1939 only 125,000 remain, he said.

The future of farm production lies with the small farmer who must come to the congress to rehabilitate his farm machinery and land resources.

Mr. Nollet referred to suggestions by Jacob Benson (C.C.F.-Last Mountain) that ministers ought to work and meet with the various departments before M.L.A.'s are asked to debate on budget expenditures.

The minister of Agriculture stressed the need for an increased agricultural production to meet the nation's food needs. Such an increase had been proven possible through the efforts of farmers in the last few years.

Cattle production had gone from 1,147,000 pounds in 1939 to a peak of 2,400,000 pounds. Hog production rose from 500,000 in 1939 to 1,754,000 in 1940 and then dropped to 1,300,000, 3,500,000 pounds in 1939 to 20,702,000 pounds in 1940. The minister also declared plans for the coming year stressed soil conservation and the rehabilitation of forage crop production, Mr. Nollet said, adding that the latter point was particularly important because of low grain prices had reduced forage crop acreage. Because of this Saskatchewan farmers each year had to import 1,000,000 tons of hay.

The 1947 crop failure had resulted in P.F.A.A. payments of $1,000,000 to 50,000 farmers for damaged crops, Mr. Nollet said.

The new Grade 12 general science course will be optional although it is compulsory in the lower high school grades. Reason for this variation, Mr. Jansen explained, is that the general science course deals with science in general terms, and is not suitable for students who plan to go into science studies at a university following completion of high school.

Mr. Jansen emphasized that the general science course for Grade 12 was designed primarily for the use of students who did not plan to continue their studies at a university following high school graduation.
