Reference is made to the Indian Residential School which is getting under way at Ex. 122 Prince Albert, referred to as the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School.

Rev. G. W. Fisher, Principal, has been in ill health for some six weeks, having spent the last three weeks in hospital. The date of his return to duty is uncertain. 56 Boys who sleep in Building No. 30 are taken by truck each morning to St. Alban's School and remain there until 7.00 pm. Nothing further has been done to establish the school at Ex. 122 while Rev. Fisher has been ill. Things were bogging down.

I interviewed Rev. Fisher yesterday, he now agrees that I go ahead with further developments. Work on making the kitchen ready is under way also the laundry, (lighting, heating and refrigeration).

Rev. Fisher is not able to concentrate or make decisions. He has an idea the Department has requested him to forward an account for a purchase made in December. No trace of this letter can be found in his office. Was such a request made?

I find a shipment of battleship linoleum was received in March. Rev. Fisher's files indicate the account covering this purchase was forwarded by him to the Department. Is there an outstanding account covering a December shipment of any kind. Accounts have been received from Marshall Wells covering a recent shipment of kitchen and table cutlery etc., this shipment is to be checked today and the accounts will be forwarded forthwith if found in order.
I am aware, why, this school is referred to as the Lac La Ronge Residential School, but this is frightfully confusing, for instance, mail addressed to Rev. Fisher in this manner quite often goes up to Lac La Ronge and has been known to remain there for two weeks. Please address all mail to Rev. G. W. Fisher, St. Alban's Indian Residential School, Prince Albert, Sask.; in future.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

Dear Mr. Neary:

There are two matters I must write to you about. (1) With regard to the seasonal schools at Stanley and Pelican Narrows. I very much regret to inform you that to date I have not been able to secure teachers for either one of these schools. Young University students who are not studying for theology seem to be able to demand very high wages for their summer's work, and they do not seem to be attracted by what we are able to offer them, especially when they are required to pay their own travelling expenses and added cost of board in the North. But I will continue in my endeavour to secure teachers because I am most anxious that these poor Indians in the North be given at least some education.

(2) The second matter I wish to discuss with you is the replacement of our school at Lac la Ronge. I understand that the sum of $200,000.00 was passed by Parliament for the building of a school in Northern Saskatchewan, at least I read something to this effect in the newspapers. Moreover, various rumors have reached me as to what the Government intends to do regarding rebuilding our schools at Onion Lake and Lac la Ronge. I wonder if I may trouble you to please let me know the mind of the Department in this matter. I know there were different ideas as to the location of the new school to replace the one at Lac la Ronge, but I have no definite word as to the mind of the Department on this question.

St. Alban's School here is doing an excellent job of work and from my visits to the school I am pleased to see the happy condition of the children. Also it is a matter of great satisfaction to me that the children who are attending the local High School are enjoying their work. If there is anything I can do I shall be most happy to offer my services in any possible way. I think you can understand my desire that our Indian boys and girls of this North country should be adequately provided for along the most important line of education.

With kind regards,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Bishop Martin:

I have for answer your letter of April 30th.

Major Clark our Educational Survey Officer is at present inspecting schools in Alberta and Saskatchewan. I have today written him an air mail letter asking that he visit you in Prince Albert with regard to our plans for Lac la Ronge. At the present time we have several proposals before us but no decision has as yet been reached.

With regard to seasonal schools, while we can not pay travelling expenses of students into these places, we can offer seasonal salaries that are high enough to help defray at least part of the travelling expenses. We could offer $150.00 a month for University students at Stanley and Pelican Narrows.

We have been getting students to go in to Northern Ontario from the University of Toronto and the University of Eastern Ontario.

I am leaving tonight for an inspection trip in Eastern Ontario but will expect to hear further from you with regard to these schools shortly after my return on May 15.

PERSONAL:

Major C.A.F. Clark, Educational Survey Officer,
c/o Mr. H.N. Woodsworth, Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alberta.

Lac la Ronge Residential School.

Your letter of May 10th arrived when I was away on an inspection trip at Manitoulin Island. However, I had an opportunity of discussing the Lac la Ronge situation and your letter with Dr. Keenleyside, Mr. Jackson and Mr. Hoey this morning.

The consensus of opinion is that we should be prepared to go ahead with the erection of a hostel at Lac la Ronge. This hostel could be conducted by the Missionary Society of the Church of England and the children would attend the Lac la Ronge Provincial School. As this is, undoubtedly, one of the trends in Indian Education which will be forthcoming from the deliberations of the Parliamentary Committee, it is felt that Lac la Ronge would be a good place in which to introduce such a program. Therefore, you can discuss the situation with Bishop Martin and the Reverend Principal of the present Prince Albert/Lac la Ronge School to find out the number of children for whom we should provide accommodation at Lac la Ronge. This is closely tied up with the future of the Prince Albert situation. A decision must be reached as to whether we will continue to operate a school in the old Theological College or to concentrate our attentions on the Army Camp. From here it is somewhat difficult to make a firm decision but it would seem that a good Residential School in Prince Albert (at the Army Camp) and a hostel at Lac la Ronge would amply care for all the Anglican children in Northern Saskatchewan whom we are unable to reach with our day schools.
I know that Mr. Ostrander will have some objection to this proposal as he feels that the Educational system in Saskatchewan "not to be above reproach". However, I feel certain that the Parliamentary Committee is going to favour more and more, closer co-operation between our Education Division and the various Provincial Departments of Education.

With regard to the second point raised concerning the opening of new day schools in Northern Saskatchewan, we cannot at the present time enter into any written contract with the Provincial Department of Education. However, when the new Act is finally passed by Parliament, it is anticipated that provision will be made for such agreement and that we will then be able to come to the various Western Provinces with proposals for Education. Therefore, the more thoroughly you can acquaint yourself with conditions in the Northern parts of these Provinces, the better we will be able to approach the situation when the time arises. It will be quite alright for you to remain away from Ottawa until on in June as you propose.

I realize that the above is a rather rambling letter but I hope it will brief you sufficiently to meet the Minister of Education in Regina on or about Tuesday, May 25th. Please find attached a draft letter which I am today sending over to Dr. Keenleyside for forwarding to the Honourable Mr. Lloyd.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

BFN/HM.

Dear Col. Neary:

Re: Lac la Ronge Residential School

I have your letter of May 6th with which you intended to enclose a copy of a letter from the Honorable Mr. Lloyd and an extract from a letter from Bishop Martin. Instead, the whole of Bishop Martin's letter is attached and there is nothing of Mr. Lloyd's communication.

For this week and next, Mr. Gooderham has suggested the following itinerary -

May 10 - by car with Supt. Pugh to Morley
" 11 - Survey of Morley
" 12 - Survey of Pekisko where new reserve is planned.
" 13 - Further work at Morley
" 14 - Survey of Sarcee
" 15 - Office work in Calgary
" 17 - Proceed to Rocky Mountain House
" 18 - Business at Nordegg
Remainder of week in the Hobbema area

This would allow me to be in Regina on Tuesday, May 25th. I could visit schools in the vicinity of Regina until such time as the Saskatchewan Department of Education is prepared to conduct discussions. As you say, however, "discussion" is hardly the word, as I shall be doing the listening.

If you can spare me until well on into June, I should be able to reach several points in the northern portions of these provinces which have so far defied anyone's approach. That would cut down the expense of time and fare from Ottawa to the Saskatchewan border. It will mean, of course, voluminous reports.

I have several books of notes but am awaiting photographs to illustrate certain situations.

Yours sincerely,

C. A. F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Dear Mr. Lloyd:

Since receiving your letter of April 16th, we have been able to communicate with our Educational Survey officer who is at present inspecting schools in Alberta. He advises that he should arrive in Regina about May 25th. He has been told to contact your office on arrival.

In the meantime, we have asked Major Clark to obtain from you all possible detail with regard to your new school at Lac la Bonge and also your plans for educational advancement in Northern Saskatchewan.

AIR MAIL

July 14, 1948.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School
Prince Albert Army Camp

A meeting of officials of the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C. and our Education Division was recently held here to discuss the future policy with regard to the Elkhorn Residential School, the Prince Albert Residential School and the Lac la Ronge Residential School (at present being conducted in the Army Camp at Prince Albert).

After considerable discussion, it was decided to set the pupilage at the temporary school in the Prince Albert Army Camp at 200.

The officials of the Indian School Administration seemed to prefer not to place too many children in these temporary quarters until they have had an opportunity of operating it for at least a period of a year.

We have already provided considerable equipment for this school on the basis of 120 pupils. We are closing the Indian Residential School at Chapleau, Ontario and arrangements are being made to ship all beds, bedding, desks, tables, etc., to the new school in the Prince Albert Camp in order to provide for the extra 80 children.

We are sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Indian Superintendent Jones at Prince Albert and an accountable advance for $2,000.00. We would like to have the necessary partitions erected, cupboards built and other emergency construction work carried out in
order to have the school ready for occupancy by September 7. It is felt that the best and fastest way to have this carpentry work carried out is by day labour. It is understood that a certain amount of the lumber required is already on hand. Authority is given for the local purchase of nails and other materials in an amount not to exceed $100.00. If additional materials are required, either submit a requisition by air mail or wire details as to requirements.

We are ordering the following supplies of interior paint from the Departmental Purchasing Agent today in order to expedite delivery:

- 5 gallons interior enamel, pale green
- 5 gallons interior enamel, white
- 10 gallons Kem-tone or similar spreader paint, pale green.

You can advise by Army Message as to further quantities required.

With regard to plumbing repairs, would you please advise as to what is required in order to provide adequate facilities for 200 children and staff. Would you also submit tenders from local plumbing firms if possible.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Attention of Mr. Neary

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 14th instant,
File 132-2-5 (E.1), in connection with Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School,
Prince Albert Army Camp.

The matters referred to were discussed with Superintendent E.S.
Jones, of the Carlton Agency, and Reverend C.W. Fisher, Principal of St. Alban's
School, Prince Albert, on the 17th instant, and a decision made as to the additional
buildings which will be immediately required for a proposed 200-pupil school.

If you will refer to my letter of June 5th, 1948, File No. 1021-303-
11 AGE., you will note that I asked that steps be taken to secure certain buildings
referred to as Nos. 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 27, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, and 34. Some of
these have already been secured, namely Nos. 23, 27, 29, 33, and 34. Nos. 21 and 31
are now vacant and they, in addition to those already secured, should be immediately
secured for the new school. All those mentioned in my letter of June 5th, File 1021-
303-11 AGE., will eventually be needed.

Assuming that Nos. 21 and 31 can be turned over to our Department for
school use, I instructed Mr. Jones to have a plumber examine the buildings and give
a quotation on preparation of the plumbing and heating for immediate occupancy, which
he will do, and submit requisitions to the Department at once.

Plans were also made for removing some partitions and installing
others in the different buildings which we propose using. Some consideration was
given to using materials on hand for the erection of the partitions, but we found
that no suitable material was on hand for this purpose, therefore Mr. Jones is
preparing a requisition to be forwarded immediately to the Department for partition
material and any other materials needed over and above the materials now on hand.
A requisition in this connection will be submitted by Mr. Jones at once after he
has secured local prices. It was too late on Saturday to secure prices when we
had finished our plans. As I had no information as to the quantity of beds, bedding,
etc. to be shipped from Chapleau, it was impossible to prepare a requisition for
these. That requisition will have to wait until Mr. Fisher secures the information
from the former Principal at the Chapleau School as to the shipment from there.

It has been my plan to use the main part of Building No. 27, the
drill hall, for a recreation building, the lean-to part thereof to be used for the
laundry, sewing-room, storage space and for manual training. This lean-to part
has its own heating plant and will be very easy to heat. The main part of the
building is heated by two large circulating heaters which Mr. Fisher has been inform-
ed will use two tons of coal a day to heat the occupiers. This will appear to be
rather expensive heating for a school with a pupilage of 200. Certainly it is not
too expensive if the school eventually has a population of 400, which, I believe,
should be planned on from the beginning, notwithstanding the doubt of the Church
officials in that regard. Some work is needed on the lean-to of Building No. 27,
and Mr. Jones will prepare a requisition in that connection. Very little work is
needed to prepare the main part of the building.

The interiors of all of the buildings which we will use require paint
and I am sure that the quantity of paint referred to in your letter will not be
sufficient, therefore another requisition will be submitted for the paint. The
floor of that part of Building No. 3 which will be used for the dining-room certainly needs improvement. It is badly chewed with Army boots and it is useless to paint it in its present condition. Surfacing with veneer and battleship linolium is recommended for this floor, and a requisition will be submitted by Mr. Jones in connection therewith.

Preparations are being made to place six classrooms all in Building No. 23. Partitions, plumbing, redecoration and blackboards are required for these classrooms.

It is proposed to use Buildings Nos. 29, 30, and 31 (when secured) for children's dormitories, playrooms, and cloakrooms. Approximately 65 pupils will sleep in each of these buildings, and each building will have a playroom and accommodation for two staff members. Mr. Fisher's request for playroom space in each of these buildings resulted from his fear that the main part of the drill hall will be too expensive to heat during all of the cold weather.

Building No. 21 is to be prepared for staff quarters by partitions and re-arrangement of plumbing, heating, etc., and redecoration.

Building No. 3, the centre part of which is the kitchen, refrigerator, etc., and an "H" hut, one side of which will be the dining-room, is to be prepared on the one side for a suite for the Principal, and a Chapel. The whole of this building needs redecoration in addition to the improvement of the floor, as previously referred to, for that part which is to be used for the dining-room.

I may say with regard to the whole, the cost of preparing these buildings will far exceed $2,000.00, and I would appreciate being advised of the total amount available in the event that it is all needed.

J.P.B Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Philan,

I have just one significant picture of Holy Angels School so far, as the post office people "mislaid" the other roll where I really got the low-down and the close-up. The school—finished in tile but mostly plywood inside—appears at the left. Between the church and the domed-roof building at the right (new mission) is the old mission which they are going to demolish. There is much more to be said re this school.

Locally, the Chaplain freight is being stored in the gymnasium. Some of it is good; other items are a bit seedy. Work on the classroom block is going ahead. They will be good rooms, but we must see that nobody whose ideas are clouded with long habituation to magic blackboards and over-many desks to a room sets the standard. I have asked Mr. Supt. Jones to ensure that a window here and there is crossed over in the Colonel Randle manner.

I made a cheap evening station to station call to Mr. Ostrander. He is staying in Regina until Monday noon when he is leaving.
for sure and Battleford. His assistant is already in Battleford where he must remain for a while because of staff shortages. His clerk Scott is here with the exhibition stuff. The Indian Brotherhood has held a three-day session in the barracks.

I'll work my way south and confer with Mr. Ostrander on Monday before proceeding to Elkhorn.

Au revoir — soon!

Yours sincerely,

Charles Fordyce Clark

Prince Albert Indian Residential School

The accompanying memoranda and diagrams may help you to appreciate the efforts of our colleagues here. Mr. Jones and I spent considerable time this past week on the spot with the Rev. Mr. Fisher. This morning Mr. Ostrander and I had a long conference with Mr. Fisher here.

August 8, 1948

Mr. Ostrander:

Prince Albert Indian Residential School:

I know you are as anxious as I am that the citizens of Prince Albert shall have no reason to say that our Department is setting up in their city a second-rate institution for "second-class citizens." I have spent several days in a survey of potentialities, of the progress being made, and in acquainting myself with the ideals toward which Mr. Asst. Jones and Rev. Mr. Fisher are working.

It seems to me that where the expenditure required is reasonable we should not ask the staff or pupils to put up with any make-do or haphazard substitute for what is fitting and proper to the inculcation or maintenance of self-esteem. I may seem to labour this point, but I have seen too many schools where other considerations are allowed to outweigh basic physical needs, resulting in undesirable emotional reactions and in mental (and probably spiritual!) attitudes that hamstring those who are trying to pull their weight.

1. The classrooms appear to be commodious, but we must check any tendency to crowd in more than forty pupils to a teacher. Natural light is likely to be good, but I'm not certain that sufficient windows can be kept open. Temperature may also become a problem. Thermometers should be placed in each room and temperatures regularly recorded.

P.T.O.
Classrooms (cont.)

As there are not enough desks, one room for small primary grade children might well be equipped with the small tables and chairs that are popular in up-to-date schools.

Blackboards are provided in our new one-room forty-pupil schools to the extent of 48 feet. The amount of blackboard in St. Allan's is pitifully small and should not be permitted to be a standard of comparison.

The lavatories in the classroom block ought to be completely adjusted before classes begin. The urinal in the room appointed for girls should be removed and four washbasins installed with a mirror above each. In the boys' room the urinal should be screened off and two wash basins installed.

Soap is going to be more expensive. Liquid soap dispensers would be more economical and hygienic.

Each toilet compartment to be equipped on the right-hand side with a toilet-tissue fixture. This may evoke protests. I have heard them all in both languages. Some of our schools make a success of this training; others don't seem to be even trying.

Dormitories:

With ten-foot ceilings, the Department normally permits one single bed to each fifty square feet of floor space (500 cu ft). The army scaled it down to 400 cu ft per adult.

The only room which I saw under construction intended as a dormitory supervisor's bedroom was on the small side and was planned without regard for a clothes closet. Both the room and the closet should be bigger unless only small-seated supervisors are to be retained.

A private bath-room for the supervisors in each dormitory is essential if worthwhile personnel are going to remain in the service. Certain surplus units can be re-medicated to give a decent-sized room with lights, mirror, wash-basin, toilet-seat, bath-tub, radiator, and an electricity outlet for curling-iron, razor, etc. Let us reduce the excuses for frivolousness.
Dining Room: We should not permit partitions separating boys from girls. Flooring? The staff dining room should be partitioned off at one end and will thus have an exit for teachers, etc., only and a door into the pupils' mess-hall.

Kitchen: The established kitchen to be used as such.

Dish washing room: There was an idea put forward that a bake-oven should be installed here. The set-up is needed for washing and storing dishes. Just because people get in each other's way in the St. Allan's kitchen when various activities are going on simultaneously, there is no reason why inconvenience should be imported into the new set-up. Besides, where would the flour be stored?

Baking: A good baking and storage room for bread and flour could be set up in the gym lean-to.

Laundry: This should be set up in the gymnasium lean-to, and could serve both present schools. A suggested layout is given in the attached diagram for pooling certain activities of the two city establishments which are only fifteen minutes' slow walking apart.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 13th instant, File 115-1-9 (Enl.), in connection with the Lac la Ronge School (Prince Albert), and the report of Mr. G.A.F. Clark on his visit there recently. I am quite in agreement with the proposal to clear and break as much as possible of the areas numbered 1, 2, and 3, on Mr. Clark's rough plan, which is returned herewith. I am instructing Superintendent E.S. Jones to proceed with an expenditure up to $350.00 to clear and break this land, if possible, this year. I notice the acreages shown by Mr. Clark, approximately 6 acres in Plot No. 1; 2 acres in Plot No. 2; and 3 acres in Plot No. 3. I believe the acreage shown is about correct for Plots Nos. 2 and 3, but I went over the other area referred to as Plot No. 1, and I am reasonably certain that it is considerably less than 6 acres. The whole of the area might contain close to 6 acres, but a considerable part of it is useless clay subsoil, which has been removed from the area shown as the play area, and it is unsuitable for growing any garden produce. I believe the total area, which can be usefully broken and cultivated in Plot No. 1 is about 3½ to 4 acres. However, we need as much of it as we can get, and will break up all that is useful.

I am endeavouring to ascertain the possibility of acquiring the land shown in Mr. Clark's plan as "available on lease from city", which I believe contains about 40 acres. Mr. Jones was instructed to interview the officials concerned, and advise me as soon as possible, as to the possibility of acquiring this on lease. There is, in addition to this, an area of approximately 18 acres immediately to the south of the area shown in Mr. Clark's plan as "orchard, garden, poultry, stable". This can be purchased, I understand, for $2500.00.

I instructed Mr. Jones to ascertain the possibility of buying this land, and if it can be bought for $2500.00 I would recommend that we buy. I do not think it can be leased.

With regard to the poultry house and the keeping of hens, no poultry has been kept at this school, but Reverend Mr. Fisher wishes to keep a flock of chickens, and intends to buy 200 chicks next spring if he has suitable facilities in which to keep them. The building referred to as a poultry house, and the yard immediately adjacent thereto, can be made suitable for keeping chickens, but the expenditure in this connection might well be delayed until next spring.

Work is progressing favourably, by day labour, in preparing the necessary buildings for the school, is being done very economically, and will prove quite satisfactory to all concerned.

J.P.B. Ostreander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

I make this comment while quite aware of the fact that it is the wish of the Church Authorities to continue with the name, and also, I presume, continuance of the name has something to do with the current year's appropriation for the Lac la Ronge School.

Superintendent E.S. Jones has communicated with the Department on more than one occasion, I believe, in connection with shipments going astray when consigned to the Lac la Ronge School. Some of them have actually been hauled by truck from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge, and back to Prince Albert, a distance of about 330 miles of road. Is there any reason why this school cannot be called the Prince Albert Indian Residential School to distinguish it from the St. Alban's Indian Residential School at Prince Albert? It is my hope that eventually the two schools will be amalgamated under one of these names.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Regina, Saskatchewan.

We have your letter of the 26th ultimo suggesting that the title "Lac la Ronge School" be changed.

Reference night letter of August 27th requesting authority to purchase Calsomine locally. My intentions are to have the classrooms and dormitories painted immediately. The recreation room and staff quarters can be decorated when school is in progress.

Due to the fact that I have to spend so much of my time away from the office, I have been unable to carry out Departmental instructions regarding obtaining authority before making purchases of materials. Full use has been made of all available material, however, it has been necessary to purchase a number of doors and casings for the classrooms and staff quarters, and such finishing materials as quarter-round and door facings. I realize the instructions re: purchases were clear and definite, but due to the shortage of time and available help, I considered it would not be advisable to hold up the work.

Reference 132-2-5 (E.l) of August 31, 1948, re:
Lac La Ronge Residential School.

Alterations and repairs to the buildings at the
Prince Albert Camp to be used for the purpose of the Lac La
Ronge Residential School are sufficiently far advanced to
permit the opening of the school. Two hundred children are
in residence. It is understood the staff will be complete
and that classes will commence on Monday September 13th.

The clearing and breaking of the garden area,
authorized, has been completed and is in first class shape.

Re: the $4000.00 advance received, expenditures to
date are as follows:

Wages; carpenters, plumbers & Helpers; total hours worked up
To week ending September 4th. 1390½ hours; Total Cost $1440.88

Mikes Transfer; for moving 66,000 ft. Lumber previously
purchased; from Building No. 30 to Drill Hall. $99.00

M & K. Plumbing Co.: plumbing fittings $1.84

Northern Hardware; nail pullers. $6.90

Prince Albert Lumber Co.: Ten Test, Doors etc. $587.73

Total $2136.35

Accounts Owing:

Prince Albert Lumber Co. $593.52

P. A. General Electric $236.05

M & K. Plumbing $21.84

Total $848.81

Accounts not yet Received:

Calsomine & Sizing. (Approximately) $50.00

Nails, Lock-sets, etc. $150.00
Decorating has been started. The kitchen and Dining Room are practically finished. It is my intention to size and calomine the ceiling in all classrooms. I consider the walls can be painted at a later date. Staff quarters have to be decorated, several members of the staff have stated they will decorate their own quarters if materials are supplied. I intend to take advantage of this.

Work yet to be done:
- Principal's living quarters and office.
- Living quarters for two married staff members half completed.
- Laundry equipment space to be cleared and equipment set up.
- Garage to house one car and one truck, Estimated cost of Labour and Materials $1600.00

Additional kitchen utensils and table ware are required also additional beds, mattresses and bedding; also floor covering to serve the present enrollment. Rev. Fisher is preparing a requisition covering the above.

Consideration must be given immediately to accommodate an additional 100 pupils. These can be housed and fed in buildings already prepared, additional classroom space will be required.

I regret the fact that the Department has not been kept informed regarding the progress of the work undertaken.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

A SOURCE of NEVER-ENDING SATISFACTION

Behind the component parts of the GILSON "WEATHER-MAKER" lies an interesting story of years of patient experiment and test—the application of scientific engineering skill in designing—and the same traditionally high standard of workmanship and attention to detail so characteristic of all GILSON products. Note these excellent features...

What it is:—

The sectional illustrations below show how the Gibson "Weather-Maker" is constructed. First a heating unit of very heavy copper-bearing steel plate, sealed by electric arc welding into a single, solid, dust-proof unit. Hot gases pass through a specially designed radiator which extracts every possible unit of heat before these gases enter the flue. Underneath the radiator are the air filters for removing dust and dirt from drawn air, and below these again is housed the silent, slow-moving fan. The automatic humidifier, with porous evaporating plates, located above the heating unit, feeds to the thirsty air the moisture it lacks, thus keeping the atmosphere always properly humidified.

What it does:—

Combustion, of course, takes place in the heating unit—which may be hand-fired with any fuel, or by means of a stoker, oil burner, coal blower or gas burner. When the air surrounding the unit becomes heated to a pre-determined temperature the fan starts automatically. This draws the air down through the filters, forcing it against the heated surfaces and over the automatic humidifier, whence it is sent back into every nook and corner of the house—a continual gentle flow of healthful warmed (not hot) air containing the right degree of moisture and free from dust. This clean, humidified, circulating air is yours to enjoy at will—automatic and controlled to suit your needs.

Heating Unit

Two decades of experience in building welded steel furnaces (longer than any other Canadian factory) are behind this massively constructed heating unit, which is made to burn any kind of fuel. Copper-bearing steel as heavy as eight gauge—is used. The firepot is built in removable sections, of sturdy cast iron. Being straight—with grate diameter equal to maximum firepot diameter—ideal combustion is achieved, with no sloping sides to accumulate ash or retard heat radiation. The fire door is large. The entire heating unit is built to salvage the most heat from the fuel consumed and to last indefinitely.

Automatic HEAT CONTROL

For hand-fired installations the operation of the fan is controlled by a Faunsditch, which stops the air whenever the fan is not actually needed. The fan stops automatically when the air temperature exceeds the desired minimum. It is designed to use mechanical firing equipment such as stoker, oil burner, etc.

The Humidifier

This is located above the heating unit — where the air is warmest and thus able to absorb the most moisture. The porous ceramic plates raise the water like a wick, whence it is readily absorbed by the air. The water level in the pan is automatically maintained by the float valve.

Long-life Radiator

Before the hot gases from combustion can enter the chimney they must pass through this oval-shaped radiator—cleverly designed to present a large surface area to the incoming gases, contacting the radiator both through the centre and outside and thus abstracting heat from the gases and preventing it from being wasted up the chimney. Sealed by electric welding this radiator cannot leak, and its design ensures unusual economy and long life.

Cleanable Filters

There are two filters—easily removed for cleaning. The filter medium is rust-proofed metal wool, sufficiently open for air to pass through while retaining dirt, dust, lint, etc. Filters should be cleaned about every three months in residential installations.

I am enclosing Voucher No. 1106 (107)
amounting to $1225.00 in favour of Hugh Struther's Construction Co. Prince Albert, Sask.

A contract was entered into with Struther's Construction to clear and bring under cultivation 3½ acres of land at a cost of $175.00 per acre. Mr. Ostrander's letter No. 1670-313-11 dated August 25th, 1948.

It will be noted this firm cleared and brought under cultivation seven acres not 3½ as authorized.

The area was gone over by Mr. Struther's and myself subsequent to commencement of clearing, and I did not estimate there were seven acres in the plot or that the whole plot could be cleared.

The work was carried out during my absence, and I accept part of the responsibility. However, the error has this redeeming feature, the plot will provide sufficient garden acreage for the school for all times and the expenditure would have to be made sooner or later.

Regina, October 23rd, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 21st instant, File 656-5 (E.l), in connection with the clearing of land for the Lac la Ronge School at Prince Albert.

In this connection I have to say that when it was decided to ask for authority to clear the land for the garden, it was thought that only 3½ acres could be cleared and broken. Consequently, authority was asked on the basis of 3½ acres at a cost of $175.00 an acre. Mr. Jones instructed the Hugh Struther's Construction Company to clear, break, and prepare for garden all the land in the block. In his absence they cleared and broke the whole of it before they took any measurements. When they measured it they found that it was 7 acres instead of 3½, and have naturally asked for payment for the whole 7 acres at $175.00 an acre.

This was discussed with Mr. Jones on my last visit to Prince Albert, and I examined the work which had been done. There is no doubt that the area is 7 acres, and it provides an excellent garden plot for use of the school, therefore I would strongly recommend that Carlton Agency Voucher No. 1106 for $1,225.00, be paid as the products from the garden in future years should well justify the expenditure.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School: 27037

Efforts are being made by all concerned to compensate for factors that have marred the opening weeks. A tidal wave of pupils came into an inadequately prepared, equipped and staffed institution, compelling various make-shifts and improvisations that must not be permitted to continue any longer than it takes to correct them, having regard, of course, to the money available.

The increasing incidence of mumps is an added strain and indicates the necessity of setting up one wing of Bldg. 21 as a thoroughly adaptable infirmary. A suggested plan for this is being finalized.

The dormitory situation was examined by day and by night and attention drawn to matters which must be righted.

Air-space per pupil; ventilation; necessary heating and lighting and use. "Lock THEM OUT DURING THE DAY."

Shortage of beds and mattresses.

Elkhorn can supply 45 single beds only. Will you please advise re mattresses? 50?

Bldgs. 27, 30, 31 will suffice, if used solely as dormitories, for the authorized pupils, plus supervisors, plus necessary storage space.

Married staff quarters and the principal's residence, Bldg. 32, are not ready for occupancy, but the carpenter is expected to return tomorrow. The furnace may be ready to operate tomorrow. Mr. Waterhouse will then proceed to adjusting the plumbing to serve the infirmary—the pipes separate.
and amenities for the staff, separated from the pupils. The "scale of issue" to pupils of towels, basins, etc., in the infirmary has to be reduced, but the movement of sick pupils to washrooms can be distributed over longer periods than possible in dormitories. A stove is to be added in this building so that food may be brought in bulk from the main kitchen. There seem to be plenty of stoves in the camp.

Incidentally I have consulted against uncaring the new stores (range) designated for the La Ronde school. They are stored in Mr. Sept. Jones' warehouse.

Similarly I have requested that the huge bake oven recently received be not uncared until we have had a chance to study the economics of bread making here, and have made a well-considered choice of a site—any. This oven is too ponderous a thing with which to guess wrong.

The drill hall and its lean-to's have been my biggest disappointment. If you will refer to my diagram submitted long before work commenced you will appreciate my surprise on seeing:

1. A young mountain of coal on the main floor of the gym. This, along with some neatly stacked lumber and a conglomeration of useful and useless things and materials effectively shuts off use by the children and makes it necessary to provide covered play space elsewhere—but not in the dormitories!

2. One cartload of coal was dropped in the door of the "coal" lean-to which is thus crippled. A lot of stuff is supposed to come out.
of there—masonry materials, etc., said to be wanted by the C.V.T.S.

3. A garage with an imposing wide door where the laundry was indicated.

4. The laundry sited and outlets cut in the concrete so far over that the toilets intended for the girls were obliterated. There is only one toilet, basin and shower left and these are part of a self-contained apartment ("stage dressing rooms") which has been assigned to Mr. Waterhouse, the engineer, on whom we depend for the plumbing and mechanical work. It is a valuable man.

5. Mrs. W's workshop occupies the space where the bake-oven might have been.

6. The principal has an office-cum-bedroom in one of the rooms intended for sewing and repairing—actually the one called "storage." This, of course, is only temporary. The "sewing" room is operating, but the distance from it to where the laundry will likely be now may require a complete change in the set-up of vocational instruction for girls. These linoleum covered floors, the good heating and lighting, must not be abused. So far I have heard no mention of library, reading or hobby rooms. These might be thus exploited.

An alternative for the "laundry" has to be found and the answer seems to be that it should go in the kitchen building (33) to which we hope to get title—perhaps we already have been granted this. The Kitchen buildings are #33 and #34.
The factors in favour of installing the laundry in the second kitchen are:

1. Concrete floor space 40 ft by 22' 11" former site reduced to 22' 8" by 26' 6"
2. Four-flue opposed chimney convenient. Chimney would have to be built at gym.
3. Water tank (L = 10' D = 3' 6") already set up in Kitchen. Too big to move through eddy. The smaller tank has been removed.
4. Ceiling is higher in the kitchen.
5. Clear hanging space; drill hall dirty.

Only a washer and a drier have come from the factory. N.B. The washer has one broken part; must be welded or replaced.

I advise that the new machinery be set up and the steam and water lines laid on so that the machines from St. Albans can be brought in later and added in an efficient assembly line so that all the machine laundering can be done at the barracks. This would involve no interruption of the laundry processes and should when completed supply a dependable plant capable of operating at varying degrees of full potential according to need.

St. Albans should soon abandon machine laundering as their lay-out is cramped and inconvenient; they will not have upper-grade girls to work; and the withdrawal of machinery will permit advantageous staff adjustments.

The belt-driven Chapleau machinery would entail too much expense or hazard to install here.
Dishes and dishwashing are at present a 
driving business. Washing is being done in 
little dish pans on the dining table. A high 
priority job is to connect the hot water pipes to 
the triple basin sink and handle the 
dishes and cutlery (when the supply becomes adequate) 
in the manner prescribed for institutions. 
The matron (Mrs. Wood) and the chef de cuisine 
Miss Sheppard know what is required. Moose 
Fort school has the equipment (trays, racks, etc.) 
Perhaps more is available from War Assets.

The same ladies are considering a plan to 
use cafeteria service. In any case more kitchen 
equipment is necessary to remove the Rube 
Goldberg cartoon features. Needed are:
1. Work tables of suitable height and top surface 
   - there may be some local stuff which we 
     can convert. We shall try.
2. Large cooking kettle with drain cock.
   Five gallons of water and vegetable weigh 50 lb.
3. Mobile wagons of stone height 2'10" to 
   transport loaded pots.
4. The usual kitchen tools - their carrying set 
   is a menace.
5. Vegetable peeler
6. Bread slicer - but I don't want to 
   encourage the use of bread.
7. Other articles endorsed by inspectors.

The local school superintendent (Mr. Percy) 
told me that the children were being badly fed. 
I was able to assure him that unhesitating inspection 
of meals at all times has satisfied me that the 
children get plenty of good food.
Playroom and assembly space are fast-approaching necessities. We shall try to supply these in the court-house buildings (33 + 34) — a wing of 33 for boys, of 34 for girls.

The chapel space used in Bldg. 30 must be restored to serve as part of a dormitory to meet air-space requirements. I have suggested using the other wing of 33 as a chapel, but the question of how to heat it (and the "play-assembly-rumpus" rooms) arises. Formerly, like the dining-room, they were heated (maybe not) by two small stoves with long hot chimneys of tin pipe — an unsuitable installation where horseplay is inevitable. (The supervisors will have to be alert to prevent the children from swinging from the pipes of the hot-water heating system in the dormitories. Another damaging activity is the pulling of wire from bed-springs to make catapults. Many other schools where children kill time in dormitories are similarly afflicted. Vigorous physical activities must be supplied and the dormitories used only at such times and temperatures that will induce no dawdling in getting into bed or getting up.)

Accordingly, damage-proof play space, adequately warmed when only necessary so, like the chapel, a priority. Hot air heating by readily controllable apparatus is indicated. Heating apparatus situated in the kitchens out of harm's way and forcing hot air into the wings by one guarded vent would be ideal. Can our heating engineer suggest an installation that comes ready-made, needing only an extension which any tinsmith...
can supply? For his office at Ft. Chipewyan,
the agent gets complete satisfaction from a
compact "Duotherm" oil heater. It would
be economy to spend as much as $500
apiece for two such units. If this
experiment in education fails, such
heaters would be acceptable at many
other points where coal is costly.

Each wing has an air-space volume
of about 25,000 cubic feet, reducible in the
case of the chapel by partitioning to
half that figure. The chapel, with the
chancel sealed off would serve as a visual
education centre and concert hall.

There are no music-making
machines for the staff and pupils. I
propose the purchase of: or acquisition somehow of:
an inexpensive chapel organ
a record player (radio) for the primary
class. The teacher has the special words
a few small radios - these cost very
little when obtained by the Department.
a piano to shuttle between the dining-
room and the girls' assembly room
a small piano or harmonium for the
six-room academy.

Something might be done with those
museum piece pianos at the Mohawk
Institute where also there are some surplus
beds and furniture that simply congest
the attic which I have suggested should
be sleeping quarters. But there is no
use sending freight to join the Chipewyan
plies in the drill hall. Some of this
staff is useless and other things, though
are a menace to the existence of anything good because anything animate or inanimate which shows any weakness gets picked at and done to death in short order by these people and the habit of destroying is progressively strengthened. I have had to improve their baseballs from which, for the lack of a few stitches in time, the covers had fallen off and the string was unravelling. When compelled to, they retrieved the covers from their vast playing field.

Some of this sort of thing could be prevented or overcome by a more adequate staff in numbers and quality — and the Principal is likely to make some suggestions. For the present I am concentrating on those inadequacies of plant and equipment which it would seem to be the policy and duty of our Department to set right. The sooner we do it, the sooner we shall be in a position to request the removal of ineffectuals if it is demonstrable that there are any. A day-school installation of comparable size scattered over a few northern reserves would have involved an initial outlay of $100,000 with no guarantee that it would exert anything like equal conditioning influence on as many children. The fraction of the sum quoted which we undertook to spend has not yet been fully expended and I have requested that the pace be accelerated while acknowledging the commendable economy that has been practised. The utmost economy, however, may not suffice to cope with the desiderata I have recorded above.

Garden land
Lac La Ronge School:

The bill for the clearing of this land will be rather more than anticipated.

In my recommendation in August I estimated the area of this patch at six acres. We were told that this estimate was excessive and that it looked more like just three acres. Now that it has been ploughed our bill is for seven acres.

I think, before payment is approved, I should go over the boundaries with a measuring tape.

It looks like good land but I am more competent in arithmetic than in agronomy. I shall urge the Principal to plan its exploitation. Root crops that the boys could harvest at Sept. 1st seem preferable to the "small fruits" that would have to be picked during vacation.

Perhaps a letter from Ottawa, not quoting me, would convince the Principal that the most immediately profitable crop is to be preferred.

Lac La Ronge School-Laundry Equipment:

May I suggest holding up payment for the new washer until the matter referred to in the attached copy of letter to Stanley Brock Ltd receives further attention.

The Reverend Principal told me today that he had certified the account for payment yesterday. I am hoping that this letter will go forward in the same mail. Normally there is no mail out of here on Saturdays.

Mr. Supt. Jones is out of town today and I did not wish to delay attention to this matter. It is, of course, only one factor in retarding the setting-up of laundry equipment here. Other factors are:

Illness of the engineer, Mr. Waterhouse; The Gordon's boiler is still at local foundry; The boiler inspector has to certify the boilers; I have not finalized a diagram for the installation which will permit the addition of other units as they become available. The dimensions of the space available are not those on which we were counting. The Chapleau machinery requires overhead shafting which cannot be arranged here. With some re-conditioning and thoughtful installation it would be usable elsewhere.

The plan here is to combine the new units with those from St. Albans' which, though individually good, are collectively the cause of too long a working day and detract from school efficiency.

Superintendent of Education, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Kitchen and Dining Room Equipment,
Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School.

Herewith in duplicate is an inventory taken yesterday of the marginally noted items.

Your attention is invited to the obvious shortage that exists in many items; for instance there are only 156 table knives available for an enrollment of 210 pupils. In many other cases undesirable make shifts have been made. Because of the shortage of dishes the children in many cases have to eat out of bread-baking pans.

May I suggest that the copy of this inventory be sent over to the dietitian of the Department of National Health and Welfare so that they may return a list of items which should be added to augment the existing supply of items which are short and to insert items which are not included in the inventory at all.

I should add that several of the large cooking pots (and 10 gal.) are enamel ware. These are, in most cases second hand and when used for vegetables, porridge or other solid foods, too frequently allow their contents to burn. Large-sized double boilers appear to be indicated.

A copy of this inventory is being left with the school and another copy with Mr. Jones, Superintendent.

On a previous report I recommended the purchase of; a Vegetable peeler, a meat grinder, a carving set and possibly a bread-slicing machine.

End of Message,

C. H. F. Clark
Educational Survey Officer.

Rev. Mr. Fisher:

Skating Rink: Mr. Supt. Jones has measured off an area 150 ft by 80 ft. and has ordered the materials for the siding. It is expected that the boys under supervision will dig the post-holes and make themselves useful in other ways. It should be possible to develop several hockey teams and to invite outside competition as well.

Assembly rooms and Chapel:

As the cold weather has now set in these rooms should be cleared out and cleaned out, using boys to do the work. The work benches in 33 should be moved into the laundry where after being covered with (old) masonite they may be used as folding and sorting tables.

Rev. O.W. Fisher,

PRINCE ALBERT, Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Fisher:

When I was at Lytton a few days ago, Canon Hives showed me an organ which he would sell for one hundred dollars. It sounded all right to me and showed very little wear and tear no broken keys or woodwork.

Your local C.P.R. office can give you a quotation on freight costs which I think would be a little more than from Winnipeg where you have another prospect at one hundred ninety-five dollars.

But perhaps by this time that local electric organ has been given another cut in price, or some philanthropic person or group has decided to present it to the school. It would certainly be a helpful acquisition to the school.

The Calgary price for mattresses ($4.50 plus freight) seems about as low as we shall get and I hope the firm will deal with you or Mr. Jones on that basis. I did not disclose my Government connections.

In regard to the work on the land for which I gave you a statement, the boys put in an additional twenty-one "boy-hours" and hence there is a fifty-dollar question to be addressed to Mr. Struthers. I hope that the money will provide several little radios (at reduced prices to the Government) for the boys' and girls' Assembly rooms.

By this time, perhaps, the rink is under construction.

I presume that the plumbers and carpenters have got on the job and have stayed so that your residence, the dishwashing room, the infirmary, and dormitories and staff quarters have become usable, and will be brought to completion in short order. If my presumptions are wrong, please let me know, Q/C Mr. Davis in Winnipeg.

Do I dare to hope that everybody, staff and students, is in good health again? I especially hope that your hand is mending well.

Please convey my regards to the staff -- I almost said "to my colleagues". I am glad to hear that you have received reinforcements.

Yours sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark.

Indian Affairs Branch.

Dear Mr. Jones:

I have a letter from Rev. Mr. Fisher with the bad news that to the epidemic of mumps there has been added measles - fourteen cases. Further to complicate matters the M & K Plumbing Company has done nothing at all on the job which they promised to begin over two weeks ago. I do not think that Mr. Fisher can stand much more of that sort of discouragement. If there is any other firm which could get on with the job forthwith I would, if I were there, invite them to do so.

In regard to the broken piece on the washer the agents are writing to the manufacturers to make a new one. Mr. Fisher as the consignee must submit a claim to the carriers naming the part: "Part No. 66; right hand bearing for 50 X 48 Globe Washer, serial no. 1213 M 7364". He will have to include a copy of the invoice and a statement of charges for removing the old part and re-assembling the machine.

Meanwhile if there is any welding shop in Prince Albert which can be trusted to do the job, they might be invited to try. They will have to supply the missing piece of metal.

In Elkhorn the Principal showed me a list of beds, etc., that he had shipped, saying that it might be necessary to make a few wooden bedsteads for the extra springs. I trust that the mattresses have been received.

I suppose that the Sanitarium got those trays back in satisfactory condition now that the school has got trays of its own.

Perhaps you have had word from Ottawa as to how those assembly rooms and the proposed chapel are to be heated. I have written to Ottawa suggesting the purchase of an organ from the Lytton Residential School.

Although the plane pilot says the ice is not yet dependable, I suppose the school rink is now furnishing some amusement.

I would imagine that the cold weather called a
halt to further work on preparing the garden land.

Now that Mr. Waterhouse should have recovered from the mumps (unless he has fallen a victim to the measles) he might get on with that comparatively simple job of adjusting the hot water pipes in Miss Hodd's room. The children cannot be expected to put up with those temperatures much longer, and the teacher's constant complaints are just one more unnecessary annoyance for a harassed Principal.

I hope that something has been done to overcome the shortages in kitchen and dining-room equipment and that the dishwashing is being done according to plan.

I asked Mr. Piercy to defer his inspection of the classroom work on the ground that sickness was making things difficult, but we cannot postpone a visit from him much longer and he has a quick eye for shortcomings.

Kindest regards to your wife and office colleagues.

Yours sincerely,

G.A.F. Clark
November 20th, 1948.

Rev. G. W. Fisher, L.Th.,
Principal

Mr. C. A. F. Clark,
C/o Mr. R. S. Davis,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Federal Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Clark:

Thanks for your letter of November 17th. After you left, I unfortunately had to spend six days in the hospital. The wound in my hand became infected, and the doctor advised me to lay up for a few days, particularly as I was running a rather high temperature. But I am glad to say I am feeling quite all right now.

So far, your plumbers have not shown up, so most things are as they were, save for the work that Waterhouse did in the hospital. Gilbert is doing a very good job there, but so far he has not got beyond working in the hospital building. I think it will be best for him to go to the other dormitory building next - Hut 30.

Re the mattresses, it is my understanding that Mr. Jones has wired Ottawa for authority to purchase.

About the organ you saw at Lytton, I don't know what to say. I wish the Government would take the matter in hand, and would purchase an organ and send it to us. We certainly need an instrument badly.

You will be sorry to hear we are having a measles epidemic now. To-day their ten boys and four girls down. I suppose this will last for quite a while.

May I ask that you do all you can to expedite the setting up of the laundry. Nothing more has been done, and we are finding it increasingly difficult to carry on as we are. It is really quite a bother to haul things backwards and forwards to St. Alban's.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Some time ago I wrote you regarding the lack of progress being made in the completion of the "set-up" of All Saints School, and in response to your Night Letter, I talked over quite frankly all the matters I had written about in my letters, with Mr. Clark. But I cannot say that things are very much better.

As possibly you may be aware, Mr. Clark has been in Prince Albert at least twice since the go ahead signal was given to get the Barracks buildings ready for occupation. He has submitted certain plans and suggestions to the Indian Affairs Branch, covering Laundry, Garden, Dormitories, Hospital, and What-not? And with all this things are still going round in circles. The fact seems to be that no one person appears to have authority to really do things. To me it sometimes appears that the local Indian Agent and Mr. Clark are at cross purposes. Mr. Jones had one plan, and Mr. Clark comes in and scraps the plan. This is what has happened in connection with the laundry. The result is, whether Mr. Clark's plan is the better or not, the fact remains, that while we have the laundry equipment, we still have no laundry at All Saints, and all laundry is being done at St. Alban's for both schools, which while it was all right as a temporary measure (for a few weeks) is not suitable for the length of time we have been operating.

The cause of the trouble is in my opinion, that no overall plan was drawn up for the setting up of the school from the point of view of the utilizing of the buildings to the best advantage. I feel that an architect should have been employed to have drawn the plans. Nothing of this kind was done.

Then the Government did not appropriate enough money for the carrying out of the work. I understand $10,000.00 was allowed. Again not enough men have been employed. The idea seems to have been also to get the job done as cheaply as possible, though at the same time some men employed have received top wages. Our own Mr. Waterhouse has done a considerable amount of the plumbing work. And so it goes on.

I wonder if you can tell me just what Mr. Clark's position is. I know what his official title is. But he seems to have so much to say re the planning of the school, and yet appears to have little authority to spend money to get things done. And in the end I feel I am getting blamed all round for many things for which I am not responsible. I do wish some action could be taken to get things really finished.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY.

Lac la Ronge Residential Schools,
Complaints by Church Officials.

As mention of my activities in regard to this school is frequently being made, the Director may wish a resume of my attempts to follow the instructions which you gave me in October to expedite matters.

With one exception, any lay-outs or alterations that I am said to have demanded are in these files and copies were furnished to our field officials, the Principal and the workmen on the job. The one exception is the latest suggestion for a laundry installation in Hut 33 of which I made only one drawing to scale and gave that to the Principal with an oral description only to Mr. Superintendent Jones. I have not seen or heard that any other plans or alterations were ever finalized on paper. The plans, if any, for the Principal's residence, married quarters and staff rooms were largely, I believe, determined by the Principal himself and he had more time and opportunity than anyone else to supervise construction and prevent the causes for complaints now being received.

As the records show, I did in August intervene in regard to the classrooms so as to plan adequate fenestration and blackboard space with some attention to heating.

I accept full responsibility for planning the infirmary which is usable as a dormitory for both boys and girls during periods when attendance may be low and dormitories 29, 30 and 31 may be closed.

I was not authorized to reduce the allotment of air space in dormitories. In buildings ten feet high and twenty-three feet wide single beds would be allowable along each wall on a scale of one every four feet. Thus a dormitory wing 100 feet long could accommodate sixty beds with little space between. For the pupilage of 210 the dormitory space used should be 460 feet in length at a minimum and if reasonable spacing of beds is desired 525 feet is suggested. In either case it requires two buildings and a considerable part of a third building to accommodate 210 pupils, staff and storage facilities.
The Regional Supervisor has indicated that there might well be some staff adjustments. Some of the personnel concerning whom the Principal expressed to me varying degrees of dissatisfaction are:

Mr. Harris, the office man
Mrs. Harris, the nurse
Mr. Calrow, the fireman
Mr. Egerton, a boys' supervisor
Mr. Edwards
Miss Joyce, a girls' supervisor
Miss Neville,
Miss Hauver, the primary teacher
Mr. Waterhouse, the engineer

As some of these people insisted on expressing their grievances to me, I find myself in agreement with Mr. Ostrander that a number of changes should be made.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Indian Residential School

With reference to your requisitions of 7th January
and 18th January, we are requesting the Departmental Purchasing
Agent to purchase the majority of the items asked for on
the requisition dated 7th January, with the exception of the
furniture for the Principal's residence and for the quarters
of the married members of the staff.

We have not yet requested the Purchasing Agent to
order the items mentioned on your requisition of 18th January.
The action in this regard is due to the destruction of the
Principal's residence by fire. It is presumed that the quarters
for the married members of the staff may have been altered.

As a consequence of the conditions which have now
arisen, we feel that a new requisition should be forwarded
for the furnishings, as no doubt you will wish to increase
these to provide furnishings for the building that will be
occupied by the Principal, as you state in your telegram
of 23rd January that these furnishings were destroyed by
the fire.

We are not ordering a new potato peeler as we discussed
this request with Regional Supervisor Ostrander, and we were
informed that there is a potato peeler at the school at the
present time which could easily be repaired and used.

When submitting the new requisition, you should
forward two lists as follows:

......2
(a) Furniture for Principal's residence.
(b) Furnishings for the quarters for the married members of the staff.

We would also appreciate receiving sketches of the plan of the quarters to be used by the married members of the staff and the names of the occupants.

We have not ordered the 230 window blinds. We understand that at least half the windows in most of the buildings face north, and in addition, that in some of the buildings there appears to be no need for shutting out light or obscuring the view from outside. We would appreciate it if you would survey the building with the Principal and advise us how many window blinds you consider are actually necessary.

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

I have just returned from a visit to the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School and I find that Mr. Mayo is making a remarkably good job of bringing order out of chaos at that school. He has been informed that he is to be replaced by a Reverend Mr. Scrase on the 15th of this month.

Mr. Mayo is very conscientious, and although he took temporary charge of the Lac la Ronge School, following the death of the Reverend Mr. C.W. Fisher, more or less unwillingly, he would now be glad to continue to the end of the present term.

I would be very glad if the officials of the M.S.C.C. could be persuaded to delay the appointment of Mr. Scrase at that school until after the 30th of June. I do not know Mr. Scrase, and it may be presumption on my part to suggest that he will not be as successful as Mr. Mayo, in setting up the school. However, I have a great deal of confidence in Mr. Mayo, and his sound judgment, and I do not like to see another change of principals during the present term. The management of the school has suffered greatly by inefficiency during this term, and conditions will certainly not be improved by making another change of principals toward the end of the term. Mr. Mayo did not ask me to write on his behalf, but he did inform me that he is willing to stay until the end of the term if it is considered desirable.

For the first time since the school was opened, Mr. Jones, our Superintendent, feels that real progress is being made, and that, in Mr. Mayo, he has a man with whom he can really do business. In fairness to Mr. Jones I believe that every effort should be made to persuade the Church Authorities to allow Mr. Mayo to remain at least until the end of June.

Authority has not yet been received for repairing the Principal's residence, damaged by fire, therefore the residence cannot possibly be ready for occupancy by Mr. Scrase and his family on the 15th of February. Mr. Mayo is living at a hotel in Prince Albert, at the expense of the school, and if Mr. Scrase arrives with his family, in Prince Albert on the 15th of February, they, too, will have to live at the hotel. This suggests that it is unwise to move Mr. Scrase to Prince Albert at the present time. The whole of the interior of the Principal's residence is covered with ice and littered with debris of all kinds. Naturally, all of the windows are broken, and have to be closed up temporarily in order to heat the building sufficiently to thaw out the ice and clean it out in preparation for repairing. From its present appearance I would say that it will take several days of heating the building before any action can be taken to repair it, consequently it will be seen that it is impossible to have it ready by the 15th of February, in view of the fact that authority has not yet been received to commence. The contractor has suggested that it will take about two weeks to do the work....
two weeks to do the work from the date of commencement. Possibly it can be done in two weeks, but I am extremely doubtful.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
7th February, 1949.

Further to my night letter of January 23rd, reporting fire in Hut No. 32, Prince Albert Army Camp:

The interior of the hut in question was completely renovated for use, except for minor details. One portion was storage for school supplies, food, clothing and classroom materials and was in use. The other portion had been made ready as office and Principal's quarters. The Acting Principal, Mr. Mayo, had made arrangements to move in January 24th. Mrs. Davidson, School Matron, had taken up temporary quarters in this building.

Mrs. Davidson left the building at 7.30 a.m. for breakfast in the dining hall. Mr. Kirton, Department of Public Works caretaker walked past the building at 8.00 a.m. and neither Mrs. Davidson nor Mr. Kirton noted any indication of fire. However, when Mr. Kirton returned to his home at 8.15 a.m., he saw smoke pouring out of one window of the building. He raised the alarm and called the City Fire Department. I arrived at 8.25 a.m., the fire department arrived and were in action at 8.30 a.m.

When the fire was extinguished, Mr. Fred Turner, City Fire Chief, and I examined the building. The east end of the building was badly burned but not beyond repair. The office and storage quarters were damaged only by smoke and water. The school supplies stored in the west end of the building were slightly damaged by smoke and water but practically all are usable.

The whole of the furnishings supplied by our Branch for the Principal's living quarters must be considered a total loss, with the exception of one bed outfit, which can be refinished. The refrigerator and electric stove were salvaged and placed in the Agency Warehouse. Mr. Ramag, Department of Public Works, has since condemned both declaring them useless and in the case of the refrigerator, a menace. He made arrangements for both articles to be demolished.

As a point of interest, the building heating unit valued at $4,000.00 is intact and undamaged.

Dear Mr. Jones:

Having reference to our conversation and my inspection of the building, being building #32 at Ex. 122 C.V.T.S., Prince Albert. I recommend that all chimneys in all buildings be examined, wood work will be re-arranged so as to allow for air space of not less than 2" between brick and woodwork. All insulation be removed when such insulation is in contact with brick or woodwork.

The brick surfaces should be plastered and all chimneys left in a condition where there shall be no contact with any wood or other structural material. There shall further be an air space of not less than 2" between all structural material and any brick surface, thus allowing of free circulation of air, thus allowing of dissipation of heat.

A further and complete report shall be forwarded to you at the earliest possible moment.

ESJ/AG
Feb. 18, 1949.

Mrs. Philan:

Laundry, Lac la Ronge:

The installation cost was high and will be high also for setting it up in the Drill Hall lean-to where a chimney will be necessary and a hot water tank will have to be added. Moreover, space in the Drill Hall will hardly be adequate for the size of installation required unless the vehicle shelter and engineer's garage and workshop are disposed elsewhere.

I suggest that Stanley Brock, Ltd. of Winnipeg, who sold us the machinery, be requested to have their traveler call at Prince Albert and look over the present installation and also at the suggested site. He could then tell us what is wrong with the present set-up (a) what adjustments are needed (b) how the machinery should be set up in the Drill Hall—using the new units and the usable old ones so that laundering is not a time-consuming chore.

The Drill Hall would, I agree, have been the more convenient site, but the school, without notice to us, took two-thirds of the space for a garage and workshop.

C.A.T. Clark

19th February, 1949.

Stanley Brock, Ltd.,
145 Market Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Attention: Mr. Busby

Dear Mr. Busby:

You are no doubt aware that we are operating an Indian Residential School in the military camp at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. Your firm supplied the laundry machinery (see Purchase Order 31447, dated 25th June, 1948).

At present the machinery is placed in what is known as Building 33, but we have had complaints that it is difficult to keep the water lines from freezing.

It is proposed to transfer the machinery to the building formerly used as a drill hall. I would also add that we have had several complaints regarding the operation of the machinery, due partly or wholly, I believe, to faulty installation.

If one of your experts on laundry machinery is in the vicinity of the camp in the near future, we would appreciate it if he would look over the situation with a view to making suggestions to the management and also submitting us a report along the following lines:

(a) Is there anything wrong with the present setup?
(b) Are any adjustments required?
(c) What units received from the Chapleau school are usable?
(d) The manner in which the machinery should be setup in the drill hall - using the new units and the usable old units so that the laundering may be handled as quickly and as conveniently as possible.
If you can co-operate with us in the near future with regard to the above, we would appreciate hearing from you as soon as possible, so that we may notify our Indian Superintendent at Prince Albert and also the Principal of the school that your representative may be expected.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Dear Doctor Keenleyside,-

With reference to Department letter of the 1st instant, File 656-5 (E.I.), returning Carlton Agency Voucher #42 in favour of the M. & K. Plumbing and Heating Company, Prince Albert, for $1559.17, enclosed is copy of a letter received from Superintendent E.S. Jones, of the Carlton Agency, in this connection. Also enclosed are rough drafts prepared by Mr. G.A.F. Clark, on which most of the work covered by this voucher was outlined.

I discussed this matter with Superintendent Jones when I visited the Carlton Agency recently, and our examination of the invoices at that time disclosed the fact that the invoices which showed expenditure of $667.41 on Hut #21, and $891.76 on Hut #30 were not entirely correct as to the buildings on which the expenditure took place. On $891.76 shown as Hut #30, approximately $640.00 should have been shown as expended on Building #33 for the purpose of converting part of that building into a laundry. The discrepancy was not noticed when the voucher was originally submitted.

Plans had been made, and work commenced to install the laundry machinery in Building #27 (lean-to of the drill hall). In Mr. Jones' absence the late Reverend Mr. Fisher apparently persuaded Mr. Clark to change Mr. Jones' plans and have the laundry in Building #33 which, I am certain, was a mistake. The original intention was to have the laundry, storage place for clothing, and sewing and mending room all under one roof. The lean-to of Building #27 was quite suitable for this purpose. Under the present arrangement the clothing has to be washed in Building #33 and this results in a lot of carrying of clothing back and forth between that building and Building #27 for mending and storage purposes.

At the time of my last visit to the Lac la Ronge School, the 3rd and 4th of February, the plumbers were completing the installation of the laundry machinery in Building #33, and arrangements had been made to try it the following day, the 5th of February. As I had returned to Regina the night of the 4th and 5th, I was not there when the laundry machinery was put to work, but the remarks of Mr. Jones in the last paragraph of the letter enclosed would indicate that they had trouble with the water lines in the laundry as the result of freezing. I am not surprised at this, and there is no doubt in my mind that the laundry will have to be installed in Building #27, as originally intended.

The part of Building #33 in which the laundry was installed was the kitchen. The kitchen ranges and other kitchen equipment were moved out of the space in order to install the laundry machinery. The expense in this connection was not serious, but the installation of the laundry machinery cost a considerable amount of money, which may be considered to have been wasted. Mr. Mayo is now in charge at the Lac la Ronge School, and he admits that there was a serious mistake made in not installing the laundry machinery in Building #27 and he is quite satisfied that it must be installed in that building before it will be satisfactory. He even suggested that if it was decided by the Department that it was the fault of the late Mr. Fisher that the change was made without Mr. Jones' approval, he would prefer...
to see all of the cost of re-assembling the laundry machinery in Building #27 assumed by the school than to see the laundry kept in its present unsatisfactory location. This, of course, will be a matter for the Department to decide with the Church Authorities. In any case, regardless of the decision as to who should pay the cost of re-installing the machinery in Building #27, it should be done in the spring as soon as the weather is suitable. I have instructed Mr. Jones to have the M. & K. Plumbing Company submit a quotation covering the change immediately after the end of the present fiscal year, and I have informed him that I shall recommend it.

In the meantime I would recommend that Voucher #42 for $1,559.17, be paid, as the work referred to therein was performed, and the M. & K. Plumbing and Heating Company should be paid.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
