You will recall our previous correspondence concerning the use of certain of the buildings at this former Basic Training Centre as temporary quarters for the Liz Ronge Indian Residential School.

By now, you will have received reports from the District Engineer concerning the burning of building No. 32 at this camp. I understand that the technical report covering the causes of this fire indicates faulty construction as the main reason for its partial destruction.

Unfortunately, this has deprived the administration of the school of a principal's residence. This has happened at a time when we were appointing a new principal to replace the Reverend Mr. Fisher who died suddenly. The new principal is a married man with two small children and we are anxious to provide him with a suitable residence. Originally we were intending to approach you with regard to repairing building No. 32, partially destroyed by the fire mentioned above. However, it has now been drawn to our attention that the Provincial Department of Reconstruction intends to vacate this building. I attach, for your information, a copy of a letter from the Honourable Mr. Sturdy to your District Resident Architect in this regard. There are
five small suites in building No. 22 which are at present being rented. It is presumed that the occupants are the families of provincial civil servants connected with the Forestry School and that when these officials are moved to the new site of the school, these suites will be vacated.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if this building No. 22 could be made available for use as a principal's residence, staff residence and additional classroom when vacated by the provincial department concerned. In this way an expenditure of approximately $5,000.00 in restoring building 12 can be avoided and suitable accommodation provided for the new principal.

Yours very truly,

H. L. KEENLEYSIDE

Deputy Minister.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 24th instant, File 656-5 (E), with which was enclosed copy of a letter from the Deputy Minister, Department of Public Works, to the Deputy Minister, Department of Mines & Resources, regarding the prospective use of Building #22 instead of Building #32 which has been partially destroyed by fire.

Extract from the quarterly report of the Saskatchewan Administrative Region for the period ending March 31st, 1949.

I am still of the opinion that the residential school at Prince Albert known as the Lac la Ronge School should be further enlarged in order to provide accommodation for the large number of children in the northern part of the province where we have no school facilities, and where the establishment of day schools is impractical. Of course, a large school requires a capable Principal, with a competent and trustworthy staff. There has been some improvement in the personnel at the Lac La Ronge School during recent months, but further improvement is needed. Much of the trouble of the late Mr. Fisher could be attributed to an incompetent staff, and many of the complaints about the operation of the school could be traced directly to incompetence.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

Please find attached the blueprints of the dormitory block now under construction at the Wabasca C.E. Residential School. We have examined these in some detail to ascertain their suitability for erection at Lac la Ronge. You will recall our discussion concerning the use of the playrooms as classrooms on a temporary basis.

Our conclusions are as follows:

(1) In their present form the playrooms of this dormitory block would not be suitable as classrooms as they have only a fenestration of 10%. It would be possible to convert them by

(a) Changing the windows to 12 lights 12" x 18". This would probably involve a change of all the windows of the building in order to have conformity of appearance.

(b) The installation of proper electric lighting facilities.

(2) The removal of recreational space from a dormitory block would be exceedingly difficult for supervisory personnel. You are well aware of the need for playing space in our residential schools, particularly in areas where the winters are long and cold.
In view of the decreased appropriation presently available for the construction of new buildings, I would prefer to proceed with the erection of day schools and delay the erection of this dormitory block. However, this is a matter of policy which I would like to discuss with you at an opportune time.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 5th instant, File 656-5 (E.I.), with which was enclosed copy of a letter which the Director received from Reverend H.G. Cook, of the Anglican Indian School Administration, and relating to the expenditure of $674.51 in hotel accommodation, meals, etc. for the Principals of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School while awaiting preparation of suitable accommodation for them on the school premises.

While it may be true that the Church Authorities were put to some expense through the fact that there was no residence accommodation for the Principals at the Lac la Ronge School for a period, it does not appear to me that it was all the fault of the Department. Fisher would act as Principal at that school and also at the St. Alban's School. He had accommodation for himself at the St. Alban's School, for which the Department was paying rent. The fact that Mr. Fisher was physically unsuited to such a difficult position is certainly not the fault of the Department. If he had been physically suited, much of our difficulty in connection with this school would have been lessened, and some considerable proportion of the cost of the opening of the new Lac la Ronge School would also have been less under proper management.

It is my opinion that it would be reasonable for our Department to make a grant to the Church of a portion of the cost of providing accommodation for Mr. Mayo and the Reverend Mr. Scrase. Certainly I do not think that our Department should pay all of it as it covered meals, as well as hotel accommodation. With reference to Army Message dated May 23rd and my reply dated May 24th in connection with the situation at the Lac La Ronge School in Prince Albert. I quote the Department's Army Message exactly as it arrived in my office.

"Canon Cook disturb threats resignation stop
Lac La Ronge School Prince Albert stop can you report
on additional alterations and equipment required stop
funds available now but may not be in July as no indication supplementary estimates stop has Jones reports
Principals residence as requested official letter
May 10."

It will be seen that the wording of this Army Message as it reached me made it very difficult to understand. In the first place I had not received a copy of official letter of May 10th presumed to have been sent to Mr. Jones. Now, upon enquiry and examination of the files in the office of the Carlton Agency, I find that Mr. Jones has not received a letter from the Department dated May 10th in connection with the Lac La Ronge School. Therefore, I am assuming that the Army Message refers to Department letter of May 11th which relates to matters regarding the Lac La Ronge School and in particular to living quarters for the Principal.

I telephoned from Prince Albert to Mr. Scovill in my office at Regina and was informed that the confirmation of the Army Message changed it only to the extent that the word "stop" following the word "resignation" should be "staff".
Some of the staff at the Lac La Ronge School have been threatening to resign at different times for months. I can only repeat what has been stated in a letter Mr. Jones addressed to the Department recently, the resignation of some of these would result in no serious loss to the Lac La Ronge School.

Part of the cause of dissatisfaction among the staff recently has been the result of an order from the Fire Chief for the city of Prince Albert, that certain electrical equipment must not be used in some of the buildings, where the wiring is not suited for the use of such equipment. We have had one serious fire in these buildings which resulted in the loss of the building intended for the Principal's residence and it was found that the cause was due to faulty wiring. There have been other threatened fires in some of the buildings for the same reason. It is my opinion that the order with regard to the use of electrical equipment in these buildings should be strictly followed.

On examination of building No. 22 today, which is the first opportunity I have had to examine that particular building, I found that it was wired with conduit in accordance with the requirements of Prince Albert City regulations, therefore, safe to use with all kinds of electrical equipment. I would now recommend that Building No. 21 be re-wired with conduit to conform with city regulations, as different kinds of electrical equipment should be used in that particular building, in view of the fact that it is used for the purpose of an infirmary, and the wiring must be as safe as possible. A requisition in this connection will be submitted by Mr. Jones as soon as he obtains a quotation thereon.

Again referring to Building No. 22. This building has actually returned to the control of the Department of Public Works and very soon will be available for the use of the Lac La Ronge Residential School for school purposes. With this in mind, Rev. Scrase, Mr. Jones and I examined the building today with a view to preparing it for use. I have arranged with Mr. Norman Thompson, Regional Architect, Department of Public Works, Saskatoon, to have a blue print prepared regarding necessary changes in this building for school purposes. When Mr. Jones has received the blue print, he will submit a requisition and quotations to the Department at once to carry out the proposed alterations in that building.
When the alterations have been completed in Building No. 22, it will provide room for the following: Chapel, four fairly large rooms for single members of the staff, one two-roomed suite which will be used by the Matron as a bedroom and living room and office combined, three three-roomed suites for married members of the school staff, also a staff sitting room.

Some of the dissatisfaction of the staff results from the fact that the classroom teachers have been given very small private rooms in the dormitories and they feel that this is not satisfactory to them. They say that having spent the day in the classroom with the children, they should not have to assume responsibility for their care in the dormitories through the night. I am inclined to agree, however, I certainly think we should insist upon one member of the staff, not a teacher, sleeping in a private room connected with the dormitories for obvious reasons.

It is to be hoped that the necessary formalities may be completed at this end in order to make use of the funds now available by the end of June and we are all acting with that in view.

The matter which has been the cause of the greatest controversy in connection with the Lac La Ronge School has been the living quarters for the Principal. I believe Rev. Scrase is doing and will do excellent work in connection with the management of the Lac La Ronge School. For that reason I would like to see him settled with suitable living quarters separate from all other buildings. Therefore, I would recommend that Building No. 2 be made suitable for a Principal's residence. This Building was turned over to our Department some time ago and from time to time consideration has been given to the best means of putting it to use. I have now concluded that it is the building which should be prepared for the principal's residence. I have discussed this with Mr. Jones and Mr. Scrase and they both agree. The cost of putting this building in good shape for the Principal's residence would probably be as much as $4,000.00, which I do not consider too high a price to pay for a suitable residence for a Principal of a residential School.

When the architect visits Prince Albert this week in connection with the other matters at the Lac La Ronge School, he is being asked to prepare plans for renovating Building No. 2.
Mr. Jones will then take the necessary action to prepare a requisition and obtain quotations toward that end, submitting them to the Department at the earliest possible date in the hope that the work can be carried out within the month of June.

I may say in connection with these proposals that I am well aware that we will have difficulties in carrying out all of the proposals by the end of June, after which I understand there may not be funds available for the purpose. However, I trust that, if it is found impossible to have the work completed within the required time, a further appropriation may be secured.

I wish to say definitely at this time, that the situation with regard to Lac La Ronge School and the future thereof, is not as disturbing as the Department has been led to believe. All matters are gradually coming under the control of those chiefly concerned, Rev. Scrase and Mr. Jones. I have never had any doubt as to the ability of Mr. Jones to carry out the necessary work in this connection, if he is given the required authority and support. After meeting Rev. Scrase today, I am prepared to say that I have little doubt as to the ability of Rev. Scrase to do his share towards that end.

J. P. B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Accommodation for Principal and Staff
All Saints' Anglican Indian School,
(Lac la Ronge, Prince Albert, Sask.)

Referring to our considerable correspondence and conversations with your Branch on the above subject, I have just received a report from our Principal in which he states that he, in company with your Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Jones, went over the whole situation at Prince Albert on 25th May, 1949. As a result of this investigation and discussion Mr. Ostrander recommended as follows:

(a) That building #2, one of the old R.C.M.P. houses, be fixed up as the Principal's Residence.

(b) That Hut #22 be fixed up to include Chapel, matron's quarters, staff sitting room, three suites for married personnel and six single rooms for staff members.

(c) That the Hospital building be re-wired and battleship linoleum put on the floors.

Mr. Ostrander has had a draftsman in Prince Albert taking measurements for plans covering the above and it is understood that, as soon as these plans are ready, contractors will be invited to bid on the work.

In view of the fact, as advised your Branch previously on several occasions, that we are experiencing great difficulty in retaining staff at this School because of the lack of proper or suitable staff accommodation, it will be appreciated if you will give favourable consideration to the work as soon as possible after you receive the tenders. You will agree, I am certain, that in the circumstances it is of the highest importance that this work be completed at an early date and particularly before the staff re-assemble for the fall term.

General Turner is leaving for Prince Albert on Monday next, 20th June, and I should be glad of an opportunity to discuss this matter with you

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Recreational Equipment - All Saints' (Lac la Ronge) Indian Residential School,
Prince Albert, Sask.

The Principal of the above School proposes to have a hockey rink and hopes that, in co-operation with civic organizations, he will be able to place a hockey team in one of the local hockey leagues next winter. He feels, and in this I agree, that this would bring the Indian boys into closer acquaintanceship with the white boys in the city to the benefit of all concerned.

In order to operate this team and provide equipment for other boys at the School to participate in hockey the minimum requirements are as follows:

- 24 hockey sticks,
- 6 pucks,
- 18 pairs shoes and skates,
- 2 sets goalies pads, protectors and gauntlets.

It is appreciated that normally you do not supply such sports equipment but, in view of the beneficial advantages of a closer acquaintance and co-operation between the pupils and the white population could be effected through the medium of hockey, perhaps you would be prepared to assist us in the supplying of the necessary equipment. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you will advise us, as early as possible, what you can do in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Root House - All Saints' (Iac la Ronge)
Indian Residential School, Prince Albert.

At the above School four acres of ground have been planted in potatoes and a fair amount sown in turnips, carrots, beets, etc.

It is essential, therefore, that a suitable Root House be provided at this School before the coming autumn because otherwise the crop of vegetables will be lost through freezing when the cold weather sets in.

Mr. Jones, your local Superintendent, advised me during my recent visit to Prince Albert that he was obtaining up-to-date plans on the Root House from the University of Saskatchewan and that as soon as he receives these plans he proposes to send them to you with a request for authority to invite tenders.

In view of the extreme urgency of this service it is requested that authority to invite tenders be granted as early as possible.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Tools - All Saints' (Lac la Ronge) Indian Residential School, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

When the above School was opened last fall all the tools required for maintenance of buildings, including plumbing, heating, etc., were provided by our Engineer as his personal property. This particular individual has now left our employ and, naturally, has taken his tools with him with the result that practically no tools whatsoever are available at the School.

As this is a newly established school it is presumed that you are prepared to supply the necessary tools under the provision of your "Formula" dated 21st June, 1948 (your file 150-97). Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Drill Hall - All Saints' (Iac la Ronge) Indian Residential School
Prince Albert, Sask.

The Drill Hall at the above School is admirably suited for recreation and other activities of the pupils during wet weather in the Autumn and Spring and during the winter months. So far as the weather period is concerned this Administration is prepared to provide the necessary heating so that the building may be used for the benefit of the pupils.

At the present time it is impossible to use this Drill Hall for recreation, etc. because of a considerable quantity of stores belonging to your Department that are now stacked on the main floor. I was given to understand, however, that your Mr. Clark is recommending that the lumber, which forms the greater part of these stores, be sold or otherwise disposed of. It would be appreciated if you can make arrangements to have the equipment, supplies, etc., now stacked on the main floor of this Drill Hall cleared out during the summer so that this building may be available for recreational, etc. activities of the pupils from the commencement of the next school term.

I was informed by your Mr. Jones that he is much in favour of this Drill Hall being made available for activities of pupils as outlined above.

Yours sincerely,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Dear Canon Cook,

Laundry at Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

Reference to your letter of July 22nd.

The removal of the laundry to the drill hall will require, I am informed, some changes in the use to which the drill hall is presently being subjected, together with the restoration of certain facilities and the addition of others.

The original plan anticipated the use of sufficient floor space to allow for:
(1) A machine laundry installed according to acceptable commercial standards,
(2) Home laundry facilities of the type found in Indian homes.

The purposes of these installations were:
(1) To provide the proper pattern and procedure for girls to train for commercial laundry work,
(2) To reduce the time spent in institutional chores,
(3) To give practice in household laundry methods looking to the improvement of household practice.

Unfortunately these ideals seem to have been forgotten and the floor space available for laundry work was reduced to 26'6" x 22' 8". This space could be enlarged if the room taken up by the storage of the school truck and automobiles were made available for the purpose originally intended. I understand that a garage building may become available.

Through lack of appreciation of the diverse uses to which the building was suited the group of toilets was removed, leaving no sanitary conveniences for the boys and girls who it was anticipated would be present in the building for recreational and vocational training. These facilities should be restored and their restoration would further reduce the floor space presently available for laundry purposes.

The heating units required for the laundry necessitate the installation of a chimney acceptable to the Prince Albert fire inspector. A hot water tank should also be added. The siting of these two additions is further inconvenienced by the presence of the vehicles and the machine shop.

Convenient passage doors and adequate lighting and ventilation of this low-ceilinged lean-to are considerations of primary importance. The health of adult and student workers in some cramped installations is said to have suffered. I am assured that a transfer of the machinery from its present site (where all the foregoing considerations have received expert consideration) to the limited area that has lately been suggested would arouse more adverse comment from more people than does the present procedure of transporting clothes to and from the machinery. Moreover, in the building...
where the machinery is presently installed there is ample covered space for the airing and drying of clothes. This is not the case in the drill hall which has been used for the storage of coal.

It would seem, therefore, that a preliminary step to the transfer of the laundry machinery would be to house the vehicles and the machine-shop elsewhere and to restore sanitary conveniences to the drill hall.

We also understand that the toilets which were originally located in this building were removed. It would also be necessary to install a new chimney and a hot water tank. Considerable cleaning would also be necessary in this building, as part of it has been used for the storage of coal.

From the information contained in the letter from Mr. Busby, it was evident that the new laundry machinery has been properly installed and presumably is giving satisfactory service. To remove it to another building will involve considerable expense, and there is a possibility that the new location would also have certain disadvantages. It appears to us that the present method of transferring the clothes to and from the building where the laundry machinery is located should not present any unsurmountable difficulties.

Taking the above into consideration, we believe that the laundry machinery should remain in the present building.

Sincerely yours,

SPECIFICATIONS OF ALTERATIONS FOR
BLDG. "2-NO I22 C.A. (B) T.G. PRINCE ALBERT SASK.

Specifications of material to be used and work to be done in making certain alterations to building #2-No. I22 C.A.(B). T.G. Prince Albert for Indian Affairs Branch all in accordance with accompanying drawing.

The contractor to tender on a first class job, complete in every respect including all necessary fees and inspection charges.

Rates of wages paid for this work shall comply with schedule of wages as approved by the Federal Department of Labour.

West section of building to be completely closed off by new partitions as shown in heavy lines on drawing. All new walls except as otherwise specified, to be constructed of 2"x4" studs on 16" centers, covered with plasterboard on both sides.

Where openings are to be filled in or blocked up, material used is to match existing and joins shall be smooth, neat, and true.

All doors shall be renewed except double doors to living room which shall be planed and sanded as required to put in first class shape. New doors to be of best quality fir of sizes noted and shall be slab doors.

All floors to be repaired where necessary. Floors to be sanded throughout with machine sander.

All new baseboard, window, and door trim to be installed throughout and to be selected by officer in charge. Baseboard to be 6" bullnose and 3/8" quarter round.

Contractor to supply and install all necessary hardware required including locksets for new doors. Each closet to be equipped.

Each closet to be equipped with one tier of shelving and metal rod.

Hand railings on existing stairs to be removed and replaced by partition constructed from floor to ceiling of 2"x3" studs on 16" centers covered with gyproc boarding on both sides.

Treads and risers of existing stairs to be removed and new treads and risers replaced on existing stringers if they are in good condition. Otherwise repair or replace stringers as necessary. New treads to be covered with AA battleship linoleum and edged with suitable metal trim.

New basement stairs to be constructed where indicated. Stair treads and risers to be of good quality 7/8" kiln dried fir. Stringers to be of 2"x10" fir of housed construction.

New cupboards as shown in kitchen to be constructed according to detail drawing. Cupboards to have masonite splashboard 1'8" high. Top to be covered with AA brown battleship linoleum and edged with suitable metal trim. Cupboard doors to have metal pulls and friction type catches. Cupboards to be constructed of 3/8" fir veneer, and shelving to be 7/8" fir.

Ground floor joists to be repaired or replaced as necessary and floor leveled up. Install three new 6"x6" beams running east and west and one 8"x8" post under the middle of each beam in basement.

Basement to be excavated as necessary to leave at least 7'-6" clearance from top of finished floor to under side of floor joists. Post footings to be 24"x24"x12" deep. 6" cinder fill to be laid as base with 4" concrete slab poured over. Materials used to be best quality portland cement and either crushed rock having maximum size of 3/8" or good grade of clean fine gravel not larger than 3/8". Mix to be 1 part of portland cement to 4 parts combined aggregate. Floor to be sprinkled with dry portland cement and have trowelled finish. Contractor to jack up building to enable this work to be carried out.
Coal chute and bin to be installed in basement under portion of building to be closed off. Bin to have sliding plank opening.

Kitchen floor to be covered with AA battleship linoleum. Felt paper to be cemented to wood floor and lino cemented to paper. Lino to run from baseboard to baseboard then quarter round fastened down. All joints to be rolled and weighted. Bathrooms to have kentile laid over wooden floor in same manner as linoleum.

Chimney to be repaired and rebuilt as necessary to put in first class shape. If new bricks are required they are to be of same color and texture as existing. Chimney to be thoroughly cleaned out.

All windows to be repaired and reglazed and new caulking put in.

Damaged shingles and siding on roof and walls to be repaired or replaced with best quality cedar shingles and siding.

Interior of building to be painted throughout with one primer coat and two finish coats of oil paint. Colors to be selected by officer of Indian Affairs Branch. All floors that are not to be covered with linoleum or tile are to be varnished three coats after sanding.

All repairs made to exterior of building to be painted to match existing, otherwise exterior of building not to be painted in this contract.

ELECTRICAL- Scope of work- It is the intention of this specification to provide for a complete re-wiring installation and the contractor will be expected to provide and install all necessary equipment and accessories as may be required to complete the layout, whether or not included in this specification. Contractor shall include an amount of $850.00 to cover the supplying of all electric light fixtures on ground and first floors. Fixtures are to be selected by officer of Dept of Mines and Resources.

RULES- Supply and install all necessary wiring and fittings to meet the requirements of the Canadian Electrical Code and comply with the Saskatchewan Power Commissions regulations.

CERTIFICATES- The contractor shall pay for all permits and inspection fees and on completion of job shall deliver to the architect a certificate of approval.

CUTTING AND REPAIRING- This contractor shall do all the cutting necessary for the proper installation of this work and repair any damage to the building done by him or his workmen, employing only skilled labour. All cutting to be done before general contractor installs new plasterboard.

GENERAL- Wiring for lighting 115 volt 3 wire main, 2 wire branches.

I have received your letter of the 5th instant, File 656-5 (E.1), with which was enclosed draft of a letter which it is proposed to send to Canon Cook.

I agree with all that it is proposed to embody in the letter referred to, but I would add, for your information, that it appears to me that the Department and the Church have been working at cross-purposes in connection with the location of the laundry. Dear Canon Cook:

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

We received your letter of July 22nd in connection with the laundry at the above school. We communicated with Regional Supervisor Ostrander. In your letter you recommended that the laundry machinery be transferred from its present location to the drill hall.

It is our understanding that at the present time the drill hall is used for storage of the school truck and automobiles. We also understand that the toilets which were originally located in this building were removed. It would also be necessary to install a new chimney and a hot water tank. Considerable cleaning would also be necessary in this building, as part of it has been used for the storage of coal.

From the information contained in the letter from Mr. Busby, it was evident that the new laundry machinery has been properly installed and presumably is giving satisfactory service.
To remove it to another building will involve considerable expense, and there is a possibility that the new location would also have certain disadvantages. It appears to us that the present method of transferring the clothes to and from the building where the laundry machinery is located should not present any unsurmountable difficulties.

Taking the above into consideration, we believe that the laundry machinery should remain in the present building.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,

Reference is made to Departmental letter 656-5 (E.I) dated July 18, 1949, regarding root-house for the Lac La Ronge Residential School.

I am of the opinion a root house should be supplied. With this in mind, plans were obtained from the University of Saskatchewan for building a Bank Root House. It was found the cost of this would be around three thousand dollars.

I then called in a contractor with a view to obtaining prices on constructing a suitable structure 18' x 28' along the lines outlined in plans from the University which included use of rock-wool insulation in one end of the cement lean-to of the drill hall. The estimated cost amounted to over two thousand dollars.

Finally, I discussed the matter with Mr. J. Ramage of the Department of Public Works, and a contractor as to the feasibility of putting a structure in the building outlined above, packing with shavings and banking the outside wall with earth. Mr. Ramage is definitely of the opinion this would prove suitable and estimated the cost at $800.00. This figure does not include the cost of six thousand feet of lumber required. We have suitable lumber stored in the drill hall which can be used, if approval is given.

Suggest we ask what this year's harvest has amounted to and where it is to be stored. Can we also ask a root-house to be included in estimates?
May we please be advised.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

OTTAWA, October 13, 1949.

PRIVY COUNCIL OFFICE

Requesting authority for acceptance of the tender of Harvey Lunn Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in an amount of $13,567.00, to carry out work of renovating additional buildings in the Prince Albert Military Camp to be used in connection with the operation of the Lac la Bonge Indian Residential School.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
October 23, 1949

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for renovating additional buildings in the Prince Albert Military Camp, to be used in connection with the operation of the Lac la Bonge Indian Residential School;

THAT efforts have been made by Departmental officials to obtain competitive tenders for the carrying out of the work required and it has only been found possible to secure a tender from Harvey Lunan Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in the sum of $13,567.00;

THAT it is considered that these repairs are necessary for the welfare of the staff and two hundred children attending this school.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for acceptance of the tender of Harvey Lunan Construction Company to carry out the work required for an amount of $13,567.00.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
Ottawa, October 12, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Lac La Bonge Indian Residential School
Carleton Indian Agency, Saskatchewan,

The above mentioned Residential School is now located in the former military camp outside of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. The school has been in operation since June, 1948, in the location just mentioned. It is operated under the auspices of the M.S.C.C. and Canon Cook has brought to our attention on several occasions the necessity of providing a proper teachers' residence, also a separate building for other members of the school staff.

It is reported that building No. 2 at the camp could be used for a principal's residence and building No. 22, for other members of the staff. Both these buildings will require renovation in order to be suitable.

With the assistance of Mr. J. Ramage, District Resident Architect of the Public Works Department, of Saskatoon, detailed information has been prepared regarding the repairs required to both buildings. Following this, Mr. Regional Supervisor Ostrander has endeavoured to secure tenders on the work required. He forwarded the following quotations from Harvey Lunam Construction Company, General Contractor, Regina, Sask., for the repairs required according to plans and specifications:

Building No. 2 ............. $6,293.00
Building No. 22 (Repairs) $5,624.00
Separate quotation for painting building No. 22 .... 1,650.00 7,274.00

On receipt of these prices Mr. Ostrander submitted them to Mr.
Ramage, who states that he considers the prices quoted by the above contractor are exceptionally reasonable. In the matter of the length of possible service Mr. Ramage states that with the repairs suggested these buildings would give untroubled service for approximately 15 years.

Mr. Regional Supervisor Ostrander states it is not possible to obtain any other quotations than that of Harvey Lunam Construction Company and recommends that his tender for the work be accepted.

In the Supplementary Estimates for the current fiscal year an amount of $22,000 was provided for repairing the buildings mentioned above and as the repairs should be made at the earliest possible date, I enclose, for the Minister's approval, Memorandum to Council requesting authority to accept the tender mentioned above from Harvey Lunam Construction Company.

Due to the fact that almost weekly last Spring and Summer weaknesses developed in the heating and water system at the All Saints Residential School, I had an understanding with Mr. Waterhouse the School's Engineer to make replacement of parts he deemed absolutely urgent and necessary for the operation of the school, should break-downs occur during my absence. The hot water jackets were replaced during my absence in the North.

The delay in my reply is due to the fact that Mr. Waterhouse left the employ of the Church Authorities after the water jackets were replaced. I held up the accounts hoping to learn of Mr. Waterhouse' whereabouts. I did not hear, consequently, the accounts went forward to the Department. He now writes as follows:

"Four of the water jackets had not been in use for some time. Two that were in use leaked so badly that two buildings were left without hot water when heat and pressure was applied. The remaining four also leaked rendering them useless. The water jackets originally installed were of the iron type, the new ones are malleable, it is claimed they have double the life."

Previous to having trouble with the water jackets, replacements had amounted to valves, elbows, connections etc. The above was not anticipated and it was unfortunate the replacements became necessary during my absence. Had I been on hand, authority would have been obtained before proceeding.

Memorandum:

As you are aware, the above school is conducted in the former military camp at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. The management has been successful in raising a very large amount of vegetables and potatoes during the past summer, and a proper root house is necessary to store them.

The Harvey Lunam Construction Company, who are now doing other work at this school, have submitted a tender in an amount of $985.00 for the erection of a root house. Superintendent Jones considers the amount reasonable, and as it is advisable to have the vegetables and potatoes properly stored to be used for food purposes during the winter, I would appreciate it if you would approve acceptance of the tender of the Harvey Lunam Construction Company in the amount stated above.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

A long distance call was received this afternoon from Superintendent E.S. Jones, Prince Albert, Sask.

In connection with building #2 which is being converted into a residence for the Principal, Supt. Jones stated that some difficulty had been encountered in view of the fact that when they attempted to dig the basement a spring was struck.

Mr. Ramage, architect of the Public Works Department, also spoke to me about the matter and his suggestion was that the basement should only be placed under part of the building and the rest of the building should be strengthened by using some extra lumber that is on hand and the result would be that the Principal's residence would be a bungalow. This appears to meet with the approval of all parties concerned and Mr. Ramage was very insistent that it was the best possible move that could be made at the present time and would result in our having a suitable residence for the Principal. The extra expenditure involved to carry out Mr. Ramage's suggestion would be $1,000. Mr. Ramage further stated that he would be in the vicinity of Prince Albert within the next few weeks in view of the fact that a new Post Office is being constructed in that town and he would give the work his personal supervision without cost to the Department.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
November 24th, 1949.

Memorandum:

MAJOR D.M. MACKAY

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

P.C. 5329 dated October 20th, 1949, approved an expenditure of $13,567.00 for renovating additional buildings in the Prince Albert Military Camp to be used in connection with the Lac la Ronge Residential School.

Included in the above Order-in-Council was provision for converting the building known as No. 2 into a residence for the Principal. Superintendent Jones telephoned us and stated that when the contractor attempted to dig the basement under this building, a spring was struck.

Mr. Jones consulted Mr. Ramage, Architect of the Public Works Department at Prince Albert. Both Mr. Jones and Mr. Ramage spoke to us over the telephone, and Mr. Ramage stated that as a result of striking the spring, it was not possible to place a basement under the whole of the building. His suggestion was that a basement should be placed under a part of the building, and the balance of the building should be strengthened by using extra lumber on hand. This would result in converting the building into a bungalow, which would meet with the approval of all parties concerned.

Mr. Ramage was very insistent on the fact that the suggestion just mentioned was the best possible move that could be made at the present time, and would result in providing a suitable residence for the Principal.

Reference is made to letter 656-5 (E.1) dated October 20, 1949 in connection with Agency Vouchers No. 642 (107) and 664 (107).

Due to the fact that almost weekly last Spring and Summer weaknesses developed in the heating and water system at the All Saints Residential School, I had an understanding with Mr. Waterhouse the School's Engineer to make replacement of the parts he deemed absolutely urgent and necessary for the operation of the school, should break-downs occur during my absence. The hot water jackets were replaced during my absence in the North.

The delay in my reply is due to the fact that Mr. Waterhouse left the employ of the Church authorities after the water jackets were replaced. I held up the accounts hoping to learn of Mr. Waterhouse' whereabouts. I did not hear, consequently, the accounts went forward to the Department. He now writes as follows:

"Four of the water jackets had not been in use for some time. Two that were in use leaked so badly that two buildings were left without hot water when heat and pressure were applied. The remaining four also leaked rendering them useless. The water jackets originally installed were of the iron type, the new ones are malleable, it is claimed they have double the life."

Previous to having trouble with the water jackets, replacements had amounted to valves, elbows, connections etc. The above was not anticipated and it was unfortunate the replacements became necessary during my absence. Had I been on hand, authority would have been obtained before proceeding.

Regarding voucher 664 (107) in favour of the Northern Hardware, as previously explained, this firm's bookkeeping was in a terrible mess. We could not get them to render accounts. This particular account extended over 1948 and into 1949.

(Sgd) E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
November 22, 1949.
